pages.subtitle: Just my baby and me
pages.title: NaturalMOM: A warm birth cocoon
pages.content:
As soon as my baby was born I held her tight. I would not let the midwife take her away from me for weighing or injections. And definitely not for bathing. Not yet! I wanted some time with her first.

I knew that all my baby needed was to lie on my chest with me. The best incubator in the world is between my breasts. That is what a baby needs, food, warmth and touch.

At the clinic, they want to tell you what to do. But I listened to my instincts as a new mom. It was the time for my new family to be together. My baby was hearing the voices of her parents for the first time. I spoke to her while her dad made noises and sang.

I put her to my breast. At first she only licked my nipple and then suckled for a few seconds before giving up. It took the help of the midwife to show both of us how to get her to latch on properly. That took at least an hour. Now when I feed her I can see her sparkling eyes looking at me.

The time for a bathing and weighing will come. I will make sure she gets all her vaccinations on time. But not yet. Now it’s time to get to know her. Deep down I know that the best thing I can do right now is to feed her often and keep her close.

**MAMA HELP: Your time with your newborn is precious. You have both done such a good job! Spend time bonding and cuddling. It is the first time you are meeting this precious bundle. The world can wait.**

pages.subtitle: Will they ever go away?
pages.title: ProudMOM: My baby has spots
pages.content:
My baby was a beautiful newborn. Even the nurses told me how pretty she was. She had a lot of dark hair and perfect little fingernails. I felt so proud to show her off!

But after 2 weeks she started to get pimples all over her face. They started on her left cheek and spread to cover her whole forehead and chin. She also had crusty areas over her eyebrows and behind her ears and in her hair.

It didn’t look very nice and I felt embarrassed when people asked to see her. Sometimes I was tempted to squeeze her pimples. But my mother told me it was better to leave them alone – no special creams or ointments, just clean water. Luckily she couldn’t see herself and didn’t seem to mind!

I found it difficult to look at other babies. Why did they look so perfect when my baby was covered in spots? I worried that they would never go away. I wondered what had caused them. Was it something I did or ate when I was pregnant?

Luckily by the time she was 6 weeks old the spots had gone and her skin was smooth again. She still had some crusts on her head but they were hard to see because of her hair. She’s back to being the beautiful baby she was when she was born, just a bit chubbier now!

**MAMA HELP: Most bumps and blotches on a newborn baby are harmless and clear up by themselves. Your baby’s new skin is adjusting to the world.**

pages.subtitle: Why have a tetanus vaccination?
pages.description: Giving birth puts you at risk
pages.title: Why have a tetanus vaccination?
pages.content:
Tetanus is a serious disease and is dangerous for both pregnant women and newborn babies. You should get vaccinated so that you and your baby do not get tetanus.

You can get tetanus through a deep wound, a cut or a burn. Giving birth puts you and your baby at risk of tetanus. Having a tetanus vaccination can protect you both.

You may be able to get a tetanus vaccination at a health facility. Ask your health worker about it. You will need 1 vaccination at your first visit and another at least a month later.

You will get the vaccination by injection. Your arm may get a bit red and swollen where the needle was put in. You might feel a bit unwell, but it will not last long. Put something cold on your arm, if the area hurts, and get some rest.

Vaccinations will protect you from germs, but they do not work if you already have an illness. So get vaccinated when you are not sick. Do not wait till you are sick because then it is too late and vaccination will not help you.

pages.subtitle: Clean, safe water
pages.description: How can I make water clean?
pages.title: Clean, safe water
pages.content:
It is very important to drink and to use clean, safe water while you are pregnant. Water keeps you fresh and well, and can help to wash away germs in your body.

Sometimes, water looks clean, but has invisible germs in it which can make you and your baby very sick. Avoid using dirty water by preparing clean water in the morning for each day.

If there is no clean water where you live, you can make water clean. Pour the water through a clean cotton cloth, and then boil it. This gets rid of the germs. Cool, boiled water is safe to drink. Boil up a large bucket for the day. Cover it and keep it in a cool area out of the way. This will stop flies and dirt getting in.

If you cannot filter and boil your water, ask your health worker about other methods of making your water safe to drink.

Buying bottled water is usually clean and safe. Always check that the seal on the bottle you buy is not broken. A broken seal means that the bottle has been opened before. It could have been refilled with dirty water if the seal is broken, so do not drink it.

pages.subtitle: When to offer solid food?
pages.description: When your baby reaches 6 months old
pages.title: When to offer solid food?
pages.content:
Eating solid food is a big step!

You can tell if your baby is ready to start eating solid food. It is when she is over 6 months old. A baby who is ready to start solids can usually do these things:

- She holds her head up.

- She sits up well when supported. You may have to sit your baby on your lap at first.

- She makes chewing motions. Your baby should be able to move food to the back of her mouth and swallow.

- She is curious about what you are eating. When babies look at your food and stretch their hands out to it, this is a sign that they are ready to eat solid food.

- She is a healthy weight. Most babies are ready to eat soft solids when they have doubled their birth weight. This is usually at about 6 months.

Your baby may be showing these signs before 6 months. But it is safer if you wait until she is 6 months old before giving her mashed foods. By then her digestive system is stronger. This means there is less chance of her having a stomach problem or a bad reaction to food.

pages.subtitle: Mealtimes with my baby
pages.title: Mealtimes with my baby
pages.content:
Your baby needs to eat solid foods when he is 6 months old. But he also still needs breastmilk.

As he grows older, he will need more food and a greater variety of food. But babies can be fussy eaters, and they can lose interest in food easily.

Here are some tips to make sure your baby eats well:

- Feed him lots of tasty foods. Take your time. Sit and talk to him while he eats. Eating is a new skill for him, and he is learning.

- If your baby refuses to eat, be patient. Do not force him. Do not give him sugar, or unhealthy foods. They have no goodness, and are bad for your baby.

- Give him lots of colours, tastes and textures. As babies grow, their tastes change often. What your baby may hate now, he may love in a few weeks!

- Make mealtimes fun. Make sure he is comfortable and that mealtimes are enjoyable for you both.

- Make eye contact, smile and talk to him. Let his meals be a social time. It will help him to eat, and it will also help him learn social skills and new words.

- If your baby is easily distracted while eating, take him to a quiet place and gently encourage him to eat.

pages.subtitle: Is she getting enough milk?
pages.title: ConfusedMOM: My newborn feeds so much
pages.content:
ConfusedMOM: My newborn feeds so much: Is she getting enough milk?

I had just given birth at the hospital when the nurse handed me my baby girl. She said: you must give her your breast now. Then she walked away. I was in shock. How do I feed her? I had no idea...

I put her mouth to my nipple and thought she would suck – but she didn’t. She didn’t seem to know what to do or how to get my breast into her mouth. All night I tried. And my baby was crying and crying. Eventually I got my nipple into her mouth and she would suck a bit then stop. But she would wake up again and cry and want more.

It went on like this all night. But she did pass her first poo.

Then she slept almost the whole day. When I left the hospital the next day, it was the same story at home. She was up all night crying and then slept most of the day.

Luckily at home I’ve had my mother to help. But it’s been a few sleepless nights now and the exhaustion is getting to me. Baby has her own ideas about when to sleep. So my life is in reverse. I am up all night but can’t really sleep in the day. I can’t remember when I last slept properly.

My baby cries a lot and I am not sure she is getting enough milk. I don’t know if I should give her formula as well because she seems so hungry. I keep on and on trying. She looks as if she is gaining weight and she is passing stools and urine just fine.

But she feeds non-stop and when I remove my breast she cries. I think I am the one who needs support.

**MAMA HELP: Newborn babies really are hard work! They cry a lot. They also feed a lot. But if your baby is gaining weight, passing stools and has wet nappies, then you’re both doing well. Remember to take your baby back to the clinic for regular check-ups. The nurse will make sure she is growing and feeding well.**

pages.subtitle: This is what it feels like...
pages.description: This is what it feels like...
pages.title: ProudMOM: Worried about labour?
pages.content:
The biggest question I had during my pregnancy was this one: what will labour be like? What do contractions feel like? I asked friends who'd given birth. Mostly, the answer I heard was that a contraction feels like a bad menstrual cramp.

Let me tell you what it felt like for me...

Early labour did feel like really strong menstrual cramps. It was uncomfortable, almost painful - but manageable. I felt the dull ache at the bottom of my abdomen, just like cramps. That lasted about 2-3 hours.

Then, as my labour progressed, the pain got more intense. It didn't feel like period pains anymore. It got sharper and stronger. Luckily, there were breaks in the pain to rest. The pain would hit for a few seconds and then go away completely. I could still function during the breaks. I was able to talk to my husband and midwife. I felt I could handle what was happening to my body.

Then the pain got stronger. This was the final phase I had learned about. Breaks between contractions were shorter. I won't lie; the pain was fierce. It was hard to find a comfortable position. I just had to get through each contraction.

There were some moments towards the end that were scary. I felt tired and I just wanted it to stop. But the nurses were there to talk me through it all. They told me to just handle one contraction at a time... Just one at a time. And when I started pushing the pain seemed to get less. I just knew I had to push that baby out! And I did.

I don’t want to scare anybody who is about to give birth. I just want to prepare you for the most amazing experience of your life. Labour is challenging. But if you know what to expect, it’s a bit less scary.

**MAMA HELP: Make sure you are ready for birth. Make plans get to the clinic on time. Ask friends about labour and get their tips. The more you know about labour the more likely you are to have a relaxed and healthy labour and birth.**

pages.subtitle: Your baby starts to walk.
pages.title: 11 months old
pages.content:
Your baby may say words, or make sounds that seem like words. Her brain is growing, and so is her ability to speak. Listen to her carefully and respond to her sounds. This will encourage her.

She is nearly a whole year old now! Even if she doesn't understand exactly what’s going on, at this age, festivals and celebrations with family and friends give her feelings of security and community. She will enjoy simple celebrations, close to home. She may feel overwhelmed if there are too many people around.

You may notice your baby is still finding out about objects by putting them in her mouth. She may also climb onto a chair to get to things up high! Take care now, watch her and make sure harmful objects are out of the way.

Your baby wants to please you, so it is never too soon to teach her how to help out. Make chores fun by turning it into a game. Break the task into small parts and do it with her.

Your baby may be walking already, or she will take her first steps soon.

You can have fun teaching her to walk. Stand or kneel in front of her and hold out your hands. Try holding both her hands and walking her towards you. She may take her first steps with her arms out to the side and bent at the elbows. She may also turn out her feet and stick out her bottom for balance.

pages.subtitle: A whole new world for your baby
pages.description: A whole new world for your baby
pages.title: Your New Baby
pages.content:
Your newborn is new to this big, noisy world! You can see he moves in a jerky way as he gets used to it. Soon, his movements will be smoother.

You may worry your baby isn't getting enough milk. If your baby is feeding every 2 to 3 hours, or at least 8 times a day, then that is enough. The colour of your baby's stools is a good way to check. They are black at first and turn yellow by day 4.

Your baby can suck, grasp, blink and search for your nipple. Sometimes he will look straight into your eyes. It is good to respond by looking back and smiling and nodding. He is learning fast!

At around two weeks watch for your baby trying to lift his head when he's lying on his belly. He might turn his head from side to side as well. This helps develop his neck muscles.

As he approaches 1 month old, your baby begins to lose his newborn quiver and jumpiness. He is growing stronger every day and learning about the world around him.

One exciting change is he's beginning to make baby noises. This is his way of talking to you! Try to make baby noises back. Keep talking even when you put him down and move away.

pages.subtitle: Why do I get headaches?
pages.title: Why do I get headaches?
pages.content:
It is common to get headaches during pregnancy, particularly in the first 3 months.

Headaches may be caused by pregnancy hormones. Feeling tired or stressed can tense your muscles and give you a headache. Missing meals and feeling hungry might bring on a headache. Or having more sleep than usual, or too little sleep.

Here are some things you can do:

- Make sure you can take a break during the day and rest. Explain to your family you need more rest while your body is growing a baby. Sit or lie down somewhere quiet, and sleep if you need to.

- Dip a cloth in warm, clean water and squeeze out to make a warm pad. Put it around your eyes and nose. Or you could try a cool cloth on your forehead or at the base of your neck.

- Ask someone to massage your neck and shoulders.

**Danger signs?** Headache, blurred vision and pain under your ribs can be signs of high blood pressure. Go to see a health worker as soon as you can if you feel like this.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby crawl?
pages.title: When will my baby crawl?
pages.content:
Crawling is your baby’s next big step after sitting up. It is usually, but not always, a key step towards being able to walk.

Your baby may start learning to crawl when she is between 6 and 9 months old. This means that she will probably be crawling well by the time she is 1 year old.

But not all babies crawl. You may find that your baby likes to shuffle around on her bottom instead of crawling on her hands and knees. Or she may like to move around on her belly.

Some babies never crawl at all. Instead, they move straight to pulling themselves up, standing, and walking. It is getting active that is important, not how your baby does it.

Babies develop differently. If you are worried that your baby is slow to start crawling or moving around, talk to a health worker.

pages.subtitle: Why does my baby cry?
pages.title: Why does my baby cry?
pages.content:
All babies cry. This is how they tell us what they need, or communicate. Some cry more than others.

Hunger is usually the reason why your baby cries. So if he cries, let him breastfeed as long as he wants. He will soon be soothed as his belly fills.

Some babies cry if they feel uncomfortable. Check if your baby's clothes are too tight, or if his nappy is soiled.

He may also be feeling too warm or too cold. Check how many layers of clothing he has on. He should be cosy with just 1 more layer of clothing than you.

Your baby may also just want to rest or be held.

Here are 3 ways to comfort your crying baby:

- **Swaddle him in a blanket.** Babies like to feel snug and secure like they did in the womb.

- **Hold him against you with a sling.** The rhythm of your heartbeat may soothe him.

- **Sing to him** or rock him gently.

If your baby cries without stopping, or the cry is more high-pitched than normal, take him to your health worker.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby sleep?
pages.description: Her sleep will change as she grows
pages.title: When will my baby sleep?
pages.content:
By 3 or 4 months, most babies are sleeping for 15 hours a day. Around 10 of those hours are at night. Your baby will have the rest of her sleep in daytime naps. By 6 months, your baby may sleep for as long as 7 hours at night. If your baby sleeps for longer, she is probably waking up but is falling back to sleep without your help.

As your baby grows older, she will sleep for about 11 to 12 hours during the night. Your baby may also take a nap twice a day. These naps will both be about 1 hour long. Until her second birthday, she will need between 13 and 14 hours of sleep a day.

If she goes to bed at the same time every day, she will fall asleep more easily. This is because she will expect to be put down to sleep.

Try not to do too much with your baby if you want her to sleep. Instead, take her to a dark, quiet place. Sing to her, or talk quietly to her. This will help her to relax.

pages.subtitle: How to squeeze out my breastmilk?
pages.description: Here is how to do it
pages.title: How do I squeeze out my breastmilk?
pages.content:
Find a jug or bowl for your milk. Wash it well and rinse with boiling water to kill any germs. Wash your hands and get comfortable, just as if you were breastfeeding your baby.

Massage your breast gently and smoothly behind your nipple to help the milk deep inside your breasts to flow.

Then, with your thumb and first finger, make a big half-moon shape around your breast. Gently squeeze your thumb and first finger together, count to 3, and release.

Keep squeezing and releasing until you see milk appearing on your nipple. Be patient, it may take a while. Thinking about your baby may help the milk to flow.

Change breasts when the flow slows down.

After squeezing out your milk into the bowl, cover it with a clean lid. This will keep insects, dust and germs out of your milk.

Find a cool place to store your milk. If you do not have a fridge, find a place in your home that is away from any heat or sunlight. You can keep breastmilk in this cool place for up to 6 hours.

If squeezing out your breastmilk seems like a nuisance, remember that your breastmilk is really healthy for your baby. The more you do it, the easier it will become and the quicker you will get!

pages.subtitle: How long will labour last?
pages.title: How long will labour last?
pages.content:
For your first baby, labour may take about 8 hours. But it could be much shorter or much longer. It is unlikely to last more than 18 hours. Once your cervix (the opening to your womb) has opened fully, it could take 1 or 2 hours of pushing before your baby is born.

If you have had a baby before, labour will probably be faster this time around. About 5 hours is common. It is unlikely to last more than 12 hours. It may only take you around 10 minutes to push your baby out. Every labour is different, so even if you have done this all before you may be surprised by how fast, or slow, this labour is.

Keep upright and move around in labour, as this may help everything to happen more quickly.

After your baby is born, your body pushes the placenta out. This often takes from 5 to 15 minutes. But it can take up to 1 hour.

Very occasionally, labour can happen really fast. This is more likely if you have had a baby before. It is important to trust your instincts so you know what your body is telling you, then you can get help in time. Some babies just cannot wait!

pages.subtitle: Start taking it easy, mom
pages.title: Month 4
pages.content:
Your baby is now about the size of your hand. He is growing, and developing all his senses. When he is born he will be able to see, taste, smell and hear.

The circle of darker skin around your nipples will be getting larger as your breasts grow. This dark area helps your baby to find the breast once he is born and makes it easier for him to latch on and get milk. You may find your breasts grow quite quickly and feel much heavier.

Your skin may be changing as well. Dark patches of skin may develop on your face. Or you may get a dark line down your tummy. These can be made worse by being out in the sun, so cover your skin and head, or stay in the shade. They will fade after your baby is born.

Pregnancy makes the joints in your body looser. So you may find you get aches and pains when you carry something heavy. Take care when lifting things. Divide heavy shopping into smaller loads. You may need more rest as well. Try to rest each afternoon and go to bed early if you are feeling tired. Growing a baby is hard work!

pages.subtitle: Mtoto wangu hulia usiku kucha na kulala mchana kutwa!
pages.description: Mtoto wangu hulia usiku kucha na kulala mchana kutwa!
pages.title: Mama Mchanga: Nisaidie!
pages.content:
Tulipokuwa hospitalini, mtoto wangu hakulia sana. Kilio kilianza tulipofika nyumbani. Alilia tangu usiku huo wa kwanza.

Nilikuwa nikimnyonyesha vizuri kwani sikuwa na shida na hilo. Nilifahamu mikao ya kutumia. Wauguzi walikuwa wamenionyesha kwenye kliniki. Hata hivyo, mtoto alilia usiku kucha, kila siku. Angelala mchana wote na kulia usiku kucha.

Nilihofia usiku ulipofika. Mtoto wangu alitoa yowe kana kwamba alikuwa na maumivu. Singemuacha pekee yake. Niliketi naye usiku kucha. Hii ilinifisha moyo sana. Nilifikiri ningepatwa na wazimu kwa kukosa kulala.

Kina mama wengine waliniambia ningefanya mambo tofauti. Ningehakikisha kuwa mtoto yuko macho wakati wa mchana ndiposa awe mchovu kufikia usiku. Au ningemuacha tu aendelee kulia.

Lakini nilikuwa na umri wa miaka 18 na nilifanya nililoweza kufanya tu.

Mtoto wangu alipofikisha miezi 6 aliwacha kulia. Huo ndio wakati wa kwanza ambao nilianza kufurahia kuwa mama!

Mtoto wangu anafikisha miaka 2 sasa na anaendelea vizuri! Pia mimi niko mzima. Siku za kwanza ndizo zilizokuwa ngumu lakini sote tulifanikiwa!

**MSAADA WA MAMA: Kila mtoto ni tofauti lakini watoto wote hulia. Kumsikiza mtoto wako akilia kwa muda mrefu kunaweza kukutia hofu na hata kukukasirisha. Huenda usiweze kumnyamazisha mtoto huyo. Hata hivyo unapaswa kutulia na ufanye lolote ili kumtuliza hadi atakaponyamaza. Ikiwa unajua hana njaa, uchovu, hajajikojolea wala hana maumivu, pata ushauri kutoka kwa mtu unayeamini. Kwa pamoja, mnaweza kuamua ikiwa mtoto anahitaji kuonwa na daktari.**

pages.subtitle: Can I avoid malaria?
pages.description: Here is how to protect yourself
pages.title: Can I avoid malaria?
pages.content:
Malaria can make you and your baby very sick. You may become anaemic - this is when you do not have enough iron in your blood, which makes you short of breath and weak. Here are some ways to protect yourself and your baby from malaria:

- Sleep under an insecticide-treated bed net, even if the weather is hot.

- Mosquitoes are attracted to dark colours. Wear light-coloured clothing, especially if you go out in the evening.

- Stop mosquitoes getting to your skin by wearing long sleeves and full-length clothes.

- A mosquito repellent on your skin will help to keep mosquitoes away. Use an indoor spray or mosquito coils in the house as well.

- Mosquitoes live in stagnant water, rotting leaves and damp areas. Check that there are none of these around your home.

The health facility may give you medicine to take to help prevent malaria.

pages.subtitle: My baby has diarrhoea
pages.description: How can I care for her?
pages.title: My baby has diarrhoea
pages.content:
If your baby has diarrhoea, she needs to replace the fluids she is losing, or she will get dehydrated. This means that her body does not have enough water to keep going. Keep offering your breast and let her feed as often as she wants.

Do not give her any fruit juice, cola or sugary drinks. These drinks can make diarrhoea worse.

**If she is younger than 6 months**, she does not need any water. Breastmilk will give her all she needs.

**If she is older than 6 months**, give her small sips of clean, safe water between feeds. If you can, try giving her sips of oral rehydration solution (ORS), a few times an hour. ORS is a powder which is dissolved in a litre of clean, boiled and cooled water. You can store this and use it over 8-12 hours. Give your baby 15-20 teaspoons of ORS after each loose stool. Spread the teaspoons out over half an hour.

Take your baby to a health worker as soon as possible if:

- she has diarrhoea for more than 1 day

- she has dry skin or lips

- she is passing water that is dark yellow and she is passing water less often

- the soft spot in her head is sunken

- she refuses to drink, has blood in her stools or has a swollen tummy

- she vomits for more than a day, or has a fever which lasts more than a day.

pages.subtitle: Month3 Swa Ke pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 3
pages.content:
Mtoto wako bado ni mdogo kiasi cha kutoshea ndani ya kiganja cha mkono wako. Anaota nywele kichwani, na nywele nyororo kote mwilini mwake. Kwenye ncha za vidole vyake anaanza kupata alama ndogondogo za vidole.

Tumboni mwako, mtoto wako anaelea kwa usalama katika majimaji. Anakingwa dhidi ya mitikisiko na anapewa joto na majimaji hayo. Watoto wanaweza kupata kwikwi. Hii unahisi mara kwa mara kama mdundo wa ngoma tumboni mwako, inayoweza kudumu dakika chache.

Kwa sasa unaweza kuwa unahisi hali ya kichefuchefu imepungua na kujikuta una njaa ghafla. Kula vizuri. Kumbuka kula vyakula vya aina mbalimbali kila siku. Kula kiasi zaidi cha chakula katika kila mlo. Hakikisha chakula chako ni salama na freshi, hakijachacha wala si cha zamani.

Pia kwa utaratibu utahisi uchovu unaendelea kupungua na unapata nguvu zaidi. Kondo la nyuma ama plasenta kwa sasa imekua tumboni mwako na inamsaidia mtoto wako. Itatoka mara tu baada ya mtoto wako kuzaliwa.

Unaweza kuona kama nguo zako zimeanza kukubana zaidi kwenye kiuno na kifua. Mimba yako itaanza kuonekana hivi karibuni, kama kitambi kidogo chini ya tumbo lako.

Kuwa mjamzito hukufanya upungukiwe na kinga dhidi ya vijidudu, kwa hivyo unaweza kupata kikohozi na mafua mara nyingi zaidi. Nawa mikono yako kwa sabuni na maji safi na salama mara kwa mara. Ndiyo njia bora zaidi ya kuondoa vijidudu.

pages.subtitle: Why do I need folic acid?
pages.title: Why do I need folic acid?
pages.content:
Folic acid is a vitamin. It helps to protect your baby from developing faults in his spine, called spina bifida. You can get folic acid by eating the right food while you are pregnant.

It's good to eat plenty of dark green vegetables like kale and spinach, as well as potatoes, peanuts and eggs. These foods contain folic acid.

Folic acid is also found in fruit like mangoes and papayas.

When you are cooking, you could try to leave the vegetables a bit crunchy. This preserves their goodness.

In the first 3 months of your pregnancy, your baby's brain and nerve systems are growing fast. Your body needs plenty of folic acid at this time. You can start taking a daily iron and folic acid tablet early in your pregnancy. You can get them at a health facility. Go as soon as you think you are pregnant.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby walk?
pages.description: When she is 12 to 18 months old
pages.title: When will my baby walk?
pages.content:
Most babies take their first steps at about 12 months old. Many are walking well by the time they reach 14 or 15 months old.

Do not worry if your child takes a little longer. Many children do not walk until they are 17 or 18 months old.

When your baby takes her first steps, give her some help. She will hold on to your hands, or use walls or furniture for support. Give her lots of praise and cuddles for her efforts!

It may take your baby several more months to develop the confidence and balance she needs to take her first steps alone. It will then be another few months before her walking is controlled and steady.

Learning to walk is an important part of your baby growing up. It marks the change from being a baby to becoming a child.

If you are worried about how your baby is developing, talk to a health worker.

pages.subtitle: Take care now, your baby can explore!
pages.description: Take care now, your baby can explore!
pages.title: 1-year-old
pages.content:
Happy birthday, baby! Soon, your child will get more independent, find his sense of humour and best of all, learn to say he loves you.

Your child may still not like you leaving him. This is natural. If there is plenty of time for goodbyes, he will have time to adjust.

It is exciting when your child says proper words. But he still won't be able to say what he wants or how he feels using words. He will use body language for some time. He may raise his arms for "up" or point a finger for "What's that?"

He might use one word for many things. Listen to the tone. He will say the same word in different ways using different gestures.

He can pick up small objects between his thumb and forefinger more easily now. He may pick up things he finds on the floor and put them in his mouth. Check what is on the floor to make sure nothing can harm him.

He is watching everything you do. Children love to copy people, especially their parents. This is how they learn. He will copy your words and the sound of your language, too.

He may have many teeth now. Keep them clean with a small brush with soft bristles and a small smear of toothpaste

Look at your lovely child and remember the journey you have travelled together - from that tiny helpless newborn to the energetic 1 year old.

Good luck for the future.

pages.subtitle: Month6 Swa Ke pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 6
pages.content:
Tumboni mwako, mtoto wako sasa anaamka na kulala katika vipindi mahususi. Sasa anaweza kufumba na kufumbua macho yake, na kunyonya kidole chake au kidole gumba chake! Hii husaidia kukuza misuli yake ya kunyonyea ili awe na nguvu za kutosha za kunyonya mara tu anapozaliwa. Ubongo wake unakua kwa haraka sasa.

Sasa anaweza kujibu sauti. Mwanzoni, atasikia tu sauti kutoka mwilini mwako, kama vile mapigo yako ya moyo. Lakini polepole ataanza kusikia kelele kutoka nje ya mwili wako. Mwimbie mtoto wako ili asikie sauti yako.

Unaweza kuhisi kama mimba yako iko juu karibu na mbavu zako, jambo ambalo litakufanya uhisi kukosa hewa. Kula kunaweza kuwa kugumu kwa sababu tumbo lako linaweza kuwa limefinywa na mtoto wako anayekua. Kula milo midogomidogo mara nyingi zaidi na vitafunio kati ya milo.

Mtoto wako kadri anavyokua ndivyo tumbo lako linakua. Ngozi juu ya tumbo lako inavutika na inaweza kuwasha. Unaweza ukaona mistari myekundu kwenye tumbo, kiuno, makalio na matiti yako. Hizi ni alama za kuvutika na zitafifia na kuwa alama hafifu baada ya kujifungua. Unaweza kupata mikakamao ya miguu au mishipa kuvimba.

Matiti yako sasa yamejaa zaidi na ni mazito zaidi. Hii ni kwa sababu yanatayarishwa kutengeneza maziwa kwa ajili ya mtoto wako.

pages.subtitle: 9monthold Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 9
pages.content:
Mtoto wako amezoea mazingira yake na anapenda vitu ambavyo amevizoea. Katika umri huu, anaweza kuwa anang'ang'ania vitu na anahitaji kukengeushwa. Anaweza kuhisi utulivu zaidi ikiwa anaweza kuwa na blanketi lake au kitu chake cha kuchezea anachokipenda zaidi, ili abebe kiasi fulani cha alichokizoea nyumbani anapotoka nje. Kupata muda wa kukaa kimya mbali na kelele na wageni kunaweza pia kumsaidia kuzoea.

Kwa sasa, mtoto wako anakumbuka vitu, kama vile wapi vitu vyake vya kuchezea vinawekwa. Anaweza pia kuiga vitendo alivyoona kama wiki mbili zilizopita. Lakini bado hawezi kukumbuka kila kitu. Uwezo wa kumbukumbu ya mtoto wako ya muda mrefu unaweza usiwe umekua hadi atakapofikisha umri wa miaka miwili au mitatu.

Kubwabwaja kwa mtoto wako kunaweza kuanza kusikika kama maneno halisi. Mtoto wako anafikiria anasema kitu, kwa hivyo mjibu kama kwamba anasema kitu! Atajifunza kuhusu mazungumzo na kujieleleza kwa uso kutoka kwako unapoongea naye na kumwangalia.

Mtoto wako bado anaelewa zaidi kutokana na sauti yako inavyotoka kuliko maneno yako halisi. Anajua wakati amekufurahisha, kwa hivyo mpe pongezi nyingi.

Utu wa mtoto wako inaanza kujitokeza sasa. Anaweza kuwa mtu mchangamfu na kuwapa tabasamu watu wote anaokutana nao, au anaweza kuwa mwenye aibu na kuficha uso wake. Mtoto wako sasa anajua jinsi ya kupata usikivu wako, anaweza kukupungia mkono anapokuona ukielekea mlangoni.

pages.subtitle: Maisha yangu tayari yanabadilika...
pages.title: BABA Mtendaji: Mtoto yuko njiani!
pages.content:
Mke wangu karibu amafikia miezi 3 ya ujauzito wake. Tuna furaha! Tunahisi kama tayari tuko na mtoto hapa, hata ingawa hakuna mwingine anayeweza kuona hili chubuko dogo.

Hatujaambia watu wengi kwa sababu tungali waangalifu kuwa tunaweza kupoteza hili chubuko dogo. Tutakuwa tumetoka kwenye eneo la hatari baada ya miezi 3. Sasa niko mwangalifu sana kwa mke wangu, kwa kuwa amebeba kitu cha thamani. Anaonekana maridadi sana, kiasi mwenye umbo la mviringo na anayeonekana kuwa laini na kung’aa zaidi. Najaribu kutobishana naye au kujitetea kwa kuwa sitaki kumkasirisha yeye au mtoto.

Tayari nahisi utofauti kiasi katika maisha yetu. Hataki kwenda kuwatembelea marafiki sana. Anapendelea kukaa nyumbani au kwenda katika matembezi wakati wa jioni. Na baada ya matembezi kwa kawaida yeye huwa amechoka sana. Sijali na ni vizuri kuongea kuhusu maisha yetu ya usoni kama wazazi tukiwa tumelala kitandani tukiwa tumeshikana mikono. Nahisi kuwa nimekosa kuwatembelea marafiki lakini ninahisi mwenye hatia kumuacha pekee yake nyumbani.

Amekuwa akijihisi mgonjwa wakati wa asubuhi. Tuliambiwa kuwa anapaswa kumega biskuti kavu au chai ya tangawizi na ilionekana kusaidia. Vitu vingi vilimfanya kuhisi kichefuchefu kama vile moshi wa sigara au baadhi ya vyakula.

Sasa huwa tunakula chakula kilicho na afya zaidi. Nimeungana naye katika mabadiliko haya yote ya lishe kwa sababu pia nahisi ni bora zaidi kwa afya. Mimi si mjamzito lakini pia huhisi vyema zaidi baada ya mlo wenye afya!

Hata hivyo, wakati mwingine mimi hukasirika kiasi, kwa kuwa kila kitu huonekana kikizunguka mke wangu na maisha mapya yaliyo ndani yake. Haonekani kuyatambua mahitaji yangu, matakwa yangu au mambo ninayotaka kufanya. Mwanamume wakati mwingine huhitaji kujiondoa kidogo kutoka kwa mazungumzo yanayohusu mtoto!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Ni vigumu kwa kina mama wengi kulenga mtu mwingine yeyote wakati wa ujauzito. Huwa wenye furaha sana na kushugulika na mtoto anayekua! Msaidie kufanya chaguo jema, kula vyema na kuzingatia safari zake za kliniki.**

pages.subtitle: Is my baby growing well?
pages.description: Yes, if you see these signs
pages.title: Is my baby growing well?
pages.content:
A baby who is growing well will be lively, full of energy and want to play.

Does he look straight at you? He may even smile at you! So you know he can see well.

Have you noticed when you pick him up how much heavier he is getting? This shows that he is feeding well.

Does he turn towards new sounds? This means that he hears well.

If your baby is sleepy, lacks energy and does not want to play, then it is important that you take him to a health worker to see what is wrong.

If your baby has been sick or if you are worried about him, measure his upper arm every month with string. Mark the string, so you know how much he has grown the next time you measure him. If his arm gets bigger, then he is growing. If his arm stays the same or is smaller, he needs more food.

Regular check-ups with a health worker will help you be sure that he is growing well. Try to take him every few months to be weighed. While you are there, you could ask the health worker any questions you have. Try to ask all your questions in 1 visit. This will save you time.

pages.subtitle: Why use a condom?
pages.description: It will protect you and your baby from HIV
pages.title: Why use a condom?
pages.content:
You can become HIV+ if you have unprotected sex with a person who is HIV+. You can protect yourself by always using a condom when you have sex.

Condoms prevent you and your baby against infections you get from sex (STIs), like HIV.

Some health facilities offer free condoms.

Talk to your partner about the benefits of using a condom. Tell him that you want to use a condom to protect your baby from HIV. Your partner may feel that condoms make sex less fun. But condoms are made of very thin latex and can hardly be felt. If used correctly, they do not make sex less enjoyable. Keep practising; you will soon not even notice the condom during sex.

Get your health worker to show you how to use the condom correctly.

Many think that HIV can be passed on by mosquito bites. This is untrue. You will not catch HIV by sharing food and water with someone who is HIV+ or by being around someone who is coughing. Nor will you catch HIV by hugging or kissing an infected person.

The best way to protect yourself is by using a condom every time you have sex. Simply washing yourself after sex will not protect you against HIV.

You may be able to get tested for HIV at the health facility. Ask your partner to get tested too. Knowing early means you can get the right care and treatment, so that you can have a healthy pregnancy and a healthy baby.

pages.subtitle: Do I need to eat more?
pages.description: Eat more to grow a healthy baby
pages.title: Do I need to eat more?
pages.content:
The best rule to remember is to try to eat when you are hungry. Try to eat a mixture of different coloured foods every day and you will gain weight steadily as your baby grows.

You may find that your appetite changes throughout your pregnancy:

- In the first few weeks, your appetite may decrease dramatically and you may not feel like eating proper meals, especially if you are nauseous or are vomiting.

- During the middle part of your pregnancy, your appetite may be the same as before you were pregnant or it may be slightly increased.

- Towards the end of your pregnancy, your appetite will probably increase. Eat fruit, vegetables, and nuts, eggs fish, chicken and meat. Explain to your family that you need more food to grow a healthy baby. Ask them if you can buy more of these foods. You need an extra handful of food with each meal. You may also need a small snack between meals.

You may start craving certain foods. Some pregnant women crave non-foods such as soil. Eating soil or other non-foods can be harmful to you and your baby. Do not eat them. Soil can cause constipation or give you worms.

pages.subtitle: Nahisi maumivu ninaponyonyesha!
pages.title: Upendo wa MAMA: Matiti yangu yamevimba na ni magumu
pages.content:
Nilipoanza kunyonyesha mtoto wangu, kwa kweli hakuna aliyeniambia cha kufanya. Nilitaka kufanya kila kitu kikawaida iwezekanavyo. Kwani hata mbwa au farasi hawafundishwi jinsi ya kuwanyonyesha watoto wao, au wao hufundishwa?

Niliweza kufanya hivyo vyema kidogo kwa siku chache. Kisha chuchu ya titi langu la kushoto ikavimba sana. Mara baadaye nikahisi bonge gumu katika titi langu. Lilikuwa jekundu na lenye joto. Rafiki yangu aliniambia kuwa hii ilikuwa dakti ya maziwa iliyoziba au mastitisi. Alisema kuwa nilipaswa kuwa mwangalifu isije ikageuka kuwa maambukizi.

Hii ilitendeka vipi? Matiti yangu yaligeuka na kuwa makubwa sana na kujaa maziwa. Yalikuwa yamegeuka na kuwa mipira migumu ya soka iliyo na chuchu ndogo zilizochomoka. Mtoto wangu alijaribu kukamata na kunyonya chuchu ili kupata maziwa. Lakini sikujua kuwa titi linapaswa kuingia zaidi ndani ya mdomo wa mtoto. Chuchu yangu ilifaa kuwa nyuma ya kinywa ikielekea kwenye koo wala si upande wa mbele ambapo midomo iko. Hivyo mtoto wangu hakuwa ananyonya vyema.

Lakini sasa titi langu lilikuwa gumu na lenye uchungu! Nilianza kukanda sehemu iliyokuwa ngumu nilipokuwa nikinyonyesha, nikijaribu kuondoa maziwa yote ili kuondoa uvimbe.

Kisha marafiki wakaniambia kuhusu majani ya kabichi! Uyaweke kwenye friji na uyafunge kwenye titi lako yakiwa baridi. Uyaweke pale kwa saa moja au mbili. Unaweza kuyabadilisha na kuweka mengine yanapokuwa na joto au kunyauka.

Hivyo nikajaribu! Huku nikiendelea na kujikanda ninaponyonyesha, pia nilijiwekelea kitambaa vuguvugu ili kufanya uvimbe kuwa laini. Baada ya siku tatu, uvimbe uliisha na titi langu likawa lororo tena na halikuwa gumu wala kuwa na joto kama ilivyokuwa hapo awali! Nashukuru!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Mastitisi itapungua iwapo utaachilia maziwa kutiririka kupitia matiti yako. Usiache kunyonyesha kwa kuwa hii itafanya hali kuwa mbaya zaidi. Hakikisha kuwa mtoto wako anaingiza titi mdomoni mwake inavyofaa. Jaribu njia tofauti za kunyonyesha ili umsaidie mtoto kujishikiza.**

pages.subtitle: My body is not the same.
pages.description: My body is not the same.
pages.title: RealMother: After the birth
pages.content:
I had a long labour and a difficult delivery. I needed stitches for a tear. Once or twice I’ve leaked a small amount of urine when I’ve sneezed. The nurses told me to practice squeezing my muscles as if trying to stop the flow of urine. Now I practise doing this every time my baby feeds so that I don’t forget.

It’s been a few weeks now and I’m starting to fit into some of my old clothes again. I have lost some of the pregnancy weight. But I still don’t feel the way I did before. I look at myself in the mirror and see a dark line down my belly and stretch marks. The skin over my belly still feels loose and soft. My husband says I still look good, but I’m not so sure. I feel older… and tired!

I know my body is healing and recovering from the birth. I look at my beautiful child and I think it was all worth it to have him. But I didn’t expect to feel so different! I suppose I AM different… I’m a mother now.

**MAMA HELP: The postpartum (after birth) period lasts from right after the delivery to 8 weeks after you’ve given birth. Your body is healing from the pregnancy and birth. You will go back to the clinic for a check up after 6 – 8 weeks.**

pages.subtitle: My baby is getting teeth!
pages.description: Teeth come between 3 months and 1 year
pages.title: My baby is getting teeth!
pages.content:
Most babies get their first tooth at around 6 months. But babies can get their first tooth any time between 3 months and 1 year. It usually appears on the bottom, at the front.

If your baby is teething, you may notice these signs:

- he has red and swollen gums and his face and cheeks are red

- he is dribbling a lot

- he tries to rub his gums and his ear on the same side as a tooth is growing

- he wakes up in the night because of the pain

When your baby is 2 years old, he should have a full set of 20 baby teeth.

It is best to start brushing your baby's teeth as soon as they appear. Use a soft toothbrush and a bit of toothpaste, if you have it. Try to clean both the surface of your baby's teeth and the gums.

Some teething babies find it difficult to feed. When your baby sucks during feeding, more blood rushes to the swollen gums. The gums are very sensitive. This is why he may turn away from your breast.

Understandably, teething makes babies irritable and unsettled. Do your best to cuddle and comfort him.

pages.subtitle: How can I feel less nauseous?
pages.title: How can I feel less nauseous?
pages.content:
Feeling like vomiting? This is normal. Lots of women feel like this in pregnancy.

Everyone feels different. Some feel just a bit nauseous in the morning, and some find certain smells make them feel nauseous all day. Most women feel better by 3 months, but it could last longer.

Try changing what you eat. Choose foods without much fat, and with no strong smell or taste. You could avoid spicy food, too. Some women find they can eat cold food but not hot food.

If you feel nauseous mostly in the mornings, it might help if you can eat some plain rice, or a biscuit, before you get up.

Also, try eating small meals, but more often.

A ginger biscuit, some ginger or lemon grated into a cup of tea or even just the smell of freshly grated ginger or lemon can help. You could also try mint tea, or chewing mints.

Explain to your family and friends how you are feeling and what you need. Do not feel guilty about asking for help with things like shopping, cooking and other chores.

Feeling nauseous and vomiting is normal in pregnancy, but if you are vomiting many times a day, if you are unable to eat and drink without vomiting, and if you are losing weight, you may need treatment by a health worker.

pages.subtitle: Postnatal danger signs
pages.title: Postnatal danger signs
pages.content:
It is really important to take care of your own body as well as your baby. If you feel fit and well you will cope better with the demands of everyday life

It is easy to focus all of your attention on your baby and forget about yourself. But your body has been through a lot. If you have problems, act early.

Plan ahead in case there is an emergency. Decide who will look after your other children if you or your baby are ill. Also decide how you will get to a health worker or health facility and who you will take with you.

Try to find the fastest route and the quickest form of transport. You may need some money for this, so start putting a little bit aside just in case. It will give you peace of mind.

If you have any of these signs, go to a health worker for help.

- You are bleeding heavily

- You are breathless and have a pain in your chest

- You have a fever and feel unwell

- You cannot pass urine

- Your belly feels tender

- You have sticky, smelly fluid coming from your vagina

- It stings when you pass water

Get help quickly so you can recover quickly too.

Remember, boys and girls need the same amount of check-ups.

pages.subtitle: Why is my skin changing?
pages.title: Why is my skin changing?
pages.content:
While you are pregnant, your hormones might affect your skin. You may notice stretch marks appearing as your belly grows, or the colour of your skin may change on some parts of your body.

Your skin may get more sensitive. This is partly because of higher hormone levels. But your skin also becomes more stretched and delicate. It is a good idea to wear loose, comfortable clothing to help with this.

If you wash regularly and keep your skin clean during pregnancy, it will help. Use soap and clean, safe water. Make sure that you rinse all the soap off your skin. Any soap left behind could cause itching and soreness. Now is a good time to use oils and creams to keep your body soft and smooth.

You may see a dark line appear on your belly. It can be as wide as your thumb, and sometimes crosses your belly button. The line shows up where your stomach muscles stretch to give your baby more room. It fades a few weeks after you have given birth.

You might see darker or lighter patches on your forehead, cheeks, and neck. This is caused by your body making a hormone to protect your skin against sunlight. Being out in the sun will make the patches darker, making them show more. To protect your skin, cover your head and body when you go out. The patches fade about 3 months after your baby’s birth.

pages.subtitle: Eat more food now!
pages.description: You need more energy when breastfeeding
pages.title: Eat more food now!
pages.content:
Breastfeeding can make you very hungry! You will need to eat more than normal. Your body is very good at making milk, but if you do not eat enough you may feel tired and faint.

Try to eat lots of fresh fruits like oranges, mangoes, water melon, pineapples, papayas and vegetables like Sukuma wiki, Cabbages, tomatoes, onions, kunde, pumpkin leaves, carrots, peas. Eating foods of a variety of colours, so you get plenty of vitamins and minerals. Eat energy-giving food like ugali, rice, chapati, bananas, potatoes, cassava. Eat protein, found in eggs, fish, chicken, milk, beans and meat. Try to have milk or nuts each day. Eat a good variety of foods, and your body will get all it needs to feed your baby well.

Try to eat 3 main meals a day at regular times. Eat plenty of snacks throughout the day, to keep up your energy levels. Good snacks are dried fruit, nuts, fresh fruit and vegetables and seeds.

Breastfeeding can make you feel thirsty. Have a drink before you feed your baby. Clean, safe water is good. You do not have to drink milk to make milk, but you do need to drink plenty of clean, safe water. Do not drink too much coffee, cola or fizzy drinks. Just 1 or 2 glasses of these a day is enough.

If you do not want to eat, it could be a sign that you need extra support. If it is a struggle to eat, and you are forcing yourself, talk to your health worker.

pages.subtitle: My baby is on the move!
pages.description: Make sure he plays in a safe area
pages.title: My baby is on the move!
pages.content:
Now your baby is mobile, it is time to make sure that he can play safely.

Make sure your baby cannot reach buckets of water or hot stoves or fires.

Wedge cupboard doors shut and move boxes and baskets high up where he cannot reach them.

Cleaning materials like bleach and washing powder can harm a baby, so lock these away.

Go down on your hands and knees so you can see the world from your baby’s angle. Dangling cords or plants may tempt him to reach up and pull things over on himself.

Put purses and shopping up high so he cannot reach them. Even simple everyday things like lipstick and make-up can harm him.

Make sure that medicines and tablets are out of his reach.

Keep him away from latrines and dirty washing.

The ground can also be home to worms. If you can, clean the floor with soap and water before your baby plays there. This will help keep him safe, and stop him getting worms. If you cannot clean the floor, put down a large, clean blanket or mat.

When your baby is standing and walking, make sure you cover his feet with loose socks or slippers. This will protect him from worms

pages.subtitle: My baby can hold on!
pages.description: Your baby is learning when she grasps objects
pages.title: My baby can hold on!
pages.content:
Playing with objects is fun for your baby, and it helps her to develop her mental and physical skills.

Learning how to hold things opens up a whole new world of play for your baby. It is also the first step towards your baby doing things for herself, such as eating, brushing her teeth, reading, writing and doing chores.

Your baby has a strong instinct to grasp from birth. At first, she is happy just looking at interesting objects, but soon she wants to grasp them. She starts to use this skill when she is about 3 months old. Colourful objects are good for helping your baby to learn this skill. Have fun with your baby by dangling an object within her reach. Watch her try to grab it!

Objects and toys with different textures are great for exploring. The difference between soft and hard will help excite your baby's senses. Give her safe objects made of soft material to play with.

By the time your baby is about 5 months old, she starts to explore by putting objects in her mouth. This is natural, and helps your baby to learn.

Choose objects or toys that are safe to put in your baby’s mouth. They should be easy to clean, with no sharp edges, strings, or small pieces. Clean them often.

pages.subtitle: How to cook food safely
pages.title: How to cook food safely
pages.content:
Bad or stale food can make you sick. Try to cook fresh meals every day. Keep your cooking and eating area clean and store food in a cool, dry place.

- Cook all meat and chicken well, until it has no pink bits.

- Cook eggs well, until they are firm. Boil milk to kill any germs.

- If you get your food from food stalls, select stalls with clean work areas. Make sure that the stall you choose is popular, so that you can be sure that food has not been sitting out for too long and has been safe for others.

- Wash your hands with soap before you prepare meals, after using the toilet and after handling animals.

- Wash all dishes and cooking areas with soapy water to get rid of any food remains.

If you have sores or cuts on your hands, keep them clean and covered with a clean cloth.

Keep animals away from the cooking area. Animals can spread germs and make you sick.

pages.subtitle: Can I prevent infections?
pages.title: Can I prevent infections?
pages.content:
It is important to be clean, especially when you are pregnant. Being clean protects you from germs, which cause infections. This reduces your risk of catching infections.

Here is how you can make sure you stay clean:

- Wash your hands with soap. This is an easy way to stop the germs that cause diarrhoea. Wash your hands when you come home, before cooking and eating, after using the toilet and after dealing with animals. You need clean, safe water and soap. Make sure that you wash your wrists, hands and nails. Wash the soap off your hands with clean, safe water.

- Every time you use the toilet, clean yourself well. Wash yourself from front to back. Wash your hands with soap soon after.

- If you wear underwear, use cotton underwear that lets air to your skin. And drink lots of clean, safe water. This will help prevent infections in your water.

- Wash your whole body often. Regular bathing will keep you healthy and less prone to illness.

pages.subtitle: Your baby can understand words!
pages.title: 10 months old
pages.content:
Your baby starts to understand simple words and phrases. Try repeating his words back to him, using adult language.

Slowly, he will learn to be independent, and will cry less when you leave him. But, sometimes, leaving him goes badly and there will be tears! If he has something that smells of you, like clothes you have worn, it will help him to settle.

At this age, your baby can sit confidently and may walk while he holds onto furniture. He may even let go for a second and stand without support, or even take a few steps if you hold his hands.

Around this age, your baby will learn to hand-feed himself an entire meal. He will want to drink from a cup. This is a new skill, and he will need to practice for a few months to learn how!

Your baby can understand simple instructions now. But this doesn’t mean he will always pay attention to the word ‘no’! He will understand ‘no’ better if it is mainly used to help him learn the difference between right and wrong, and safe and unsafe.

pages.subtitle: The birth of your baby
pages.title: The birth of your baby
pages.content:
When your baby is low down and ready to be born, your contractions will feel different. You will feel the pressure of your baby's head between your legs. With each contraction you may get 2 or 3 strong urges to push.

Work with your body and push when you get a strong urge. With every push, your baby will move down a little. Try not to hold your breath, but take several little breaths when you're pushing.

At the end of the contraction, you may feel your baby slip back a bit. Do not worry. As long as your baby keeps on moving a little further each time, you are doing fine.

When your baby's head is far down, you may feel a hot, stinging sensation. This will happen as the opening of your vagina starts to stretch around your baby's head.

Your attendant will tell you when she can see your baby's head. You may need to stop pushing at this point to slow things down.

Take short, panting breaths for the next 2 or 3 contractions. This helps make sure that your baby is born gently and slowly, and will help stop you tearing.

pages.subtitle: Your baby loves to play
pages.title: 3 months old
pages.content:
Your baby is getting more flexible. He may enjoy opening and closing his fingers, or clapping his hands.

Your baby's sense of humour is developing, too. A tickle or a noisy kiss on his tummy is likely to make him chuckle.

Right from birth, your baby loves to be touched. It's important for his growth and development. A massage after a bath or a nice long cuddle before bed will be good for both of you.

Just playing helps your baby's brain grow. As his brain develops, he is getting more curious. He may play with a small toy that he can hold and shake about. He will be learning about colour, shape and size, too. He also learns from the noise a toy makes and from feeling if it is soft or hard.

Your baby will start to giggle and smile when you make funny faces and she will enjoy lots of silliness. She will also enjoy hearing lots of sounds. Click your tongue, whistle or make animal noises. She will love it.

pages.subtitle: Shouldn’t pregnancy be happy?
pages.title: CityMOM: Worried all the time
pages.content:
Pregnancy should be an exciting time. All the things that are happening inside my body should fill me with happiness. But at the moment all I feel is worried.

I worry about everything. What will the labour be like? Could I miscarry? Will something go wrong? What if my waters break in public? What if there is something wrong with my baby? I am also having nightmares when I sleep.

When I wake up in the morning I don't have the energy to get out of bed. I can feel my baby moving around inside me but I'm filled with thoughts about what could go wrong. I love this baby with all my heart. My dream is that it will have a wonderful life. But the closer my due date comes, the more I worry about what will happen to me and my baby. Is this crazy?

I wonder if it is normal to feel this way during pregnancy? In the beginning I was so happy and excited. Perhaps it is just that I am scared of labour, or scared of the reality of my situation. Either way, I love my baby and will do what is best.

**MAMA HELP: Worry is one of the most common things moms report in pregnancy. It is more common than morning sickness and food cravings. You're not crazy. You're just pregnant!**

pages.subtitle: I am wasting away
pages.title: BusyLady: Too thin after baby
pages.content:
I have always been tiny. But for the year after I gave birth to my boy, people told me I looked like a walking skeleton.

A week after birth I was already back in my old clothes. But the weight loss didn’t stop there. My baby seemed to be always attached to my breast. And as he fed, I got thinner and thinner.

I had been breastfeeding for 9 months when I caught sight of myself in a shop window in town. I was shocked: I was just skin and bone. Others had kept staring and asking if I was sick. So I decided to see a doctor.

He told me that my body had stopped absorbing nutrients and that it was going to take some time to come right. I was put on an eating programme of healthy food. I had to eat a lot of energy food and fresh food to get vitamins.

The doctor also told me to start moving my baby onto solid foods. He showed me how to do this.

Now that I have started to gain strength, I feel much better. I have not gained any weight, but I have not lost any either.

For a long time, the thought of another pregnancy scared me. I didn’t think my body would cope. But I am starting to think I could do it again! This time round, I would eat carefully and make sure to put a lot of good food in my body. Now I know that I must take care of myself so that I can take care of my family.

**MAMA HELP: If you are not sure you can stick to a healthy diet on your own, ask your healthcare worker for help. You will need to eat foods rich in good fats, vitamins and minerals. These are essential for a healthy baby and a healthy mom.**

pages.subtitle: Feel tired and weak?
pages.title: Feel tired and weak?
pages.content:
You need a lot of extra iron in your blood in pregnancy. The iron helps your baby grow so that he is not born too early and can be born healthy. Iron also helps to reduce the amount you bleed at the birth. You can get iron by eating food which contains iron.

Without enough iron, your body will not get as much oxygen. This is called iron-deficiency anaemia. It will make you feel tired and weak.

Try to eat plenty of iron-rich foods every day. There are lots of iron-rich foods:

- Green, leafy vegetables

- Eggs, poultry, fish, and meat

To get enough iron, try to have a mixture of all these foods.

Some health workers will give you free iron tablets. When you take them each day, have some fruit, or fruit juice. This will help your body take in more of the iron.

Try not to drink black tea or coffee with meals, or when you take your tablets, as these drinks make it difficult for your body to get iron.

pages.subtitle: She cries all night and sleeps all day!
pages.description: She cries all night and sleeps all day!
pages.title: YoungMother: Help!
pages.content:
At the hospital my baby did not cry much. It started when we got home. She cried right through that first night.

I was breastfeeding her fine, I had no problem with that. I knew which positions to use. The nurses had shown me at the clinic. But she just cried all night, every night. She would sleep all day and cry all night.

I came to fear the nights. She screamed like she was in pain. I couldn’t leave her alone. I sat with her all night. It would tear my heart apart. I thought I would go mad from lack of sleep.

Other moms tell me I should have done things differently. I should have kept her awake during the day to make her more tired at night. Or I should have just left her to cry.

But I was 18 at the time and I just did the best I could.

Then when she reached 6 months, the crying stopped. That was the first time I started to enjoy being a mother!

She turns 2 this year and she is doing well! And I am doing well. The early days were hard. But we both got through it all okay!

**MAMA HELP: Every baby is different but all babies cry. Listening to your baby cry for hours can make you worried, even angry. You may not be able to stop him from crying. But remain calm and do your best to soothe him until he settles down. If you know he is not hungry, tired, wet or in pain, get a second opinion from someone you trust. Together you can decide if your baby needs to see a doctor.**

pages.subtitle: Why do I need to rest?
pages.description: Growing a baby is hard work!
pages.title: Why do I need to rest?
pages.content:
Growing a baby can make you feel very tired. Rest as often as possible. Explain to your boss, and your family that your body is working hard to grow your baby. Only do the most important tasks at home, and ask your family to help.

As your baby grows inside you, he will need more food. Slowly increase the amount of food you eat as your belly grows. Have an extra handful of food with each meal. Eat small amounts, often through the day. Carry some food with you when you go to work.

As your baby grows, he will start to press on your bladder, the place where your urine collects. This will make you want to pass urine more often, perhaps disturbing your sleep. Try not to drink anything for an hour before you go to bed. This may help. Drink plenty of clean, safe water throughout the day, though.

You may have leg cramps. Your leg muscles are carrying the increasing weight of your baby. This can make your legs ache or feel very tired. If you wake because of a cramp, try to stretch the muscle. Straighten your leg and flex your ankles and toes. You can also try massaging the cramped muscle. Try not to stand for long periods or sit with your legs crossed.

Sleep on your left side, with a cushion or a pad of cloth between your knees. This may help you to get more comfortable at night.

pages.subtitle: I found my own way.
pages.title: NaturalMother: Breastfeeding confusion!
pages.content:
There are so many people giving me advice about feeding my newborn baby, I just don't know what to think! Some of my friends say I must stick to certain times in the day to feed my baby like every 4 hours on the hour.

But I can't possibly let her cry when she seems to be hungry and I can't force her to drink when she is not. So I just pick her up when she is restless and starts to niggle and put her on my breast. Usually she latches on and starts drinking until she is full. Then my breast, which was quite hard and full before, becomes soft and feels empty.

I try to let her drink from both my breasts to relieve the discomfort I am feeling when they get too full. My baby usually becomes very sleepy after drinking, so I gently hold her upright and let her burp and then put her down to sleep. And judging from the size of her yellow and smelly poop, she must get enough food!

Then another mother told me that I must give her cooled, boiled water between feeds from when she is 6 months because babies can get dehydrated. It is quite hot in the day, so I thought I would give it a try. But my baby has not sucked on anything else than on my breasts. So when I tried to put a cup in her mouth, she pulled a face and didn't want it.

She makes 3 to 4 big wees in the day. The urine is pretty clear and not yellow or dark, so I think that she drinks enough liquid. Her skin is also rosy and her face gets rounder every day. I had her weighed at the clinic and she is putting on the right amount of weight, so I am starting to relax now.

I found my way. My nipples were quite sore in the beginning but then somebody told me that my baby has to take my breast further into her mouth. My nipple mustn’t get squeezed on her hard palate, but rather be further back in her mouth, where it is softer. Since I did that, it doesn’t hurt anymore when I feed her.

Sometimes she doesn’t latch on properly and then I let her open her mouth wider and latch on again. Sometimes it works right away but sometimes we both have to try a couple of times. It gets easier the more often we do it.

Now I find breastfeeding easy and natural, and so convenient that I can go anywhere and feed my baby wherever I want!

**MAMA HELP: Your baby is getting enough milk if she is having regular feeds, 6 to 8 wet nappies a day and gaining weight. She needs no other food or liquid other than breastmilk for the first 6 months.**

pages.subtitle: Nitamnyamazisha vipi?
pages.title: Baba wa mara ya kwanza: Mtoto analia
pages.content:
Kabla ya mtoto wangu kuzaliwa kitu kimoja nilichojua ni kuwa niliwafanya watoto wachanga walie. Ni mara ngapi mama yangu mdogo au binamu alikuwa amenipatia mtoto na akalia. Ni kama alikuwa anajua sitakuwa baba!

Kabla ya wangu kuja, niliwaza: na ikiwa mtoto wangu atafanya hivyo pia?

Niliamua kuwa sitaki hii ifanyike – kwa hivyo nilichukua hatua ya kubaini ni kwa nini watoto wachanga hulia. Niliwauliza shangazi zangu wenye ujuzi! Haya ndiyo waliyosema: ... kuna sababu nne za mtoto kulia: ana njaa, ana maumivu, amejikojolea, au amechoka.

Lakini watoto hawawezi kulia kwa sababu ya kukasirika pia?

Bila shaka wanaweza kufurahi bila sababu yoyote. Binti yangu aliponipa tabasamu kuu kwa mara ya kwanza ni alipokuwa karibu na majuma 6. Ilikuwa wakati wangu bora kabisa! Ilikuwa ni kama alikuwa mtu mkubwa. Watoto wachanga hutabasamu kwa mama na baba wao na watu wengine wanaowatambua. Wanajikaza na kutoa kicheko cha chinichini, kububujika na kuchekacheka.

Sasa naonekana natumia muda mwingi nikifanya vitu vinavyomfurahisha msichana wangu – Nakunja sura, naiga sauti za wanyama, naruka kama chura, na kuvuta miguu yake.

Anapolia nachunguza vitu 4. Kwanza nahakikisha amelishwa vizuri, ana nepi kavu, alilala vizuri usiku na hana miba kwenye suruali yake.

Ninapokuwa na hakika kuwa yuko sawa, mimi sasa hujishughulisha na kumchangamsha kabisa... Najua baadhi ya nyimbo nzuri. Naweza kumchezea densi. Kumsomea hadithi. Kumtekenya miguu yake...

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Mtoto anayelia anaweza kumsumbua sana mzazi. Kwanza pitia orodha ya vitu 4 vya BABA wa mara ya kwanza ili uhakikishe mtoto ana utulivu. Baada ya kuhakikisha, inaweza kuwa ni wakati wa kuleta wimbo na kucheza densi!**

pages.subtitle: Look into your baby’s eyes, Mom!
pages.description: Look into your baby’s eyes, Mom!
pages.title: 1 month old
pages.content:
About now, your baby will begin to focus both eyes on an object. He will watch if you move a toy in front of him. But, when it disappears, your baby will forget it exists!

Your baby’s memory gets better all the time. He will forget the toy, but he always knows your voice, and remembers this from when he was in your womb.

Washing your baby can be fun for you both. Get a clean towel and wash him with plenty of clean, safe water. Make sure the water feels warm but not hot. Most babies will relax and enjoy the water. It may even remind him of being inside you. Never leave him alone when he is in water.

It is good to look at your baby’s face and make eye contact. This helps him begin to learn social skills. Soon, your baby will recognise your face. He may prefer you to other people. He may make baby noises and kick with pleasure when he sees you. You will see his first smile soon!

Your baby is also noticing his surroundings. Noises will start to interest him, and he will like colourful patterns.

By now, your baby may be able to lift his head and chest when he is lying on his belly. Learning to control his head is an important milestone for him.

Your baby is also listening to you more each day. When you speak, he may stop what he is doing to listen to you. Keep talking to him, repeating his noises. Speaking to your baby will comfort him and encourage him to talk to you.

pages.subtitle: My life is changing already...
pages.title: PracticalDAD: Baby on the way!
pages.content:
My wife is almost 3 months into her pregnancy. We are happy and excited! It feels as if the baby is already here with us, even though nobody else can even see the little bump.

We haven’t told many people yet because we are still cautious that we could lose this little bump. We will be out of the danger zone after 3 months. I am very careful with my wife now, since she is carrying precious cargo. She looks so beautiful, somehow rounder and softer and more radiant. I try not to argue or get my way because I don’t want to upset her or the baby.

I already feel quite a difference in our lives. She doesn’t want to go out to visit friends as much. She would rather stay at home or go for an evening walk. And after that she is usually very tired. I don’t mind and it’s nice to talk about our future lives as parents lying in bed and holding hands. I do miss seeing my friends but I feel guilty leaving her at home alone.

She has been feeling sick in the mornings. We were told she should nibble on dry biscuits or ginger tea and it seemed to help. Lots of things made her feel nauseous like cigarette smoke or car fumes or some foods.

We eat a more healthy food now. I’ve joined her in all these changes in her diet because I also feel it’s healthier. I’m not even pregnant but I also feel better after a healthy meal!

But sometimes I get a bit irritable, because everything seems to revolve around my wife and the new life inside of her. She doesn’t seem to notice my desires or wishes or the things I want to do. A man does need a break from baby talk sometimes!

**MAMA HELP: It’s hard for many moms to focus on anyone else during pregnancy. They are too excited and busy growing a baby! Help her to make good choices, eat well and keep her clinic visits.**

pages.subtitle: What happened to my life?
pages.title: NewMother: My newborn is hard work!
pages.content:
I was shocked to learn how much time it takes to look after a newborn baby!

Before my baby daughter was born, I thought newborns slept all the time. I thought: What’s the big deal, why do women complain about having a tiny baby?

But mine would wake up and cry the moment I tried to get on with any tasks. Then I had to feed her. That took about an hour until she was burped and her nappy was changed and she was put to sleep again. I couldn't get to do anything!

In the beginning, she woke up 2 or 3 times during the night. It took me some time to get used to waking up all the time. Eventually I started to sleep very lightly because I was listening for my baby’s noises. She slept right next to our bed in a big box.

But the sleepless nights affected me. I was constantly tired and tearful. By the time my little girl was 6 months old, she would still wake up a few times in the night to feed. But by then she slept next to me in the bed so I could just roll over and offer her my breast. Then we all fell asleep again.

During the day my daughter was alert and awake. I had even less time to do my chores because she wanted my attention.

A helpful friend gave me good advice. She told me to take the time to feed her properly during the day so she wasn’t hungry in the night. That way, she wouldn’t wake me up to drink all the time. She told me that by 6 months, babies are ready to sleep right through the night.

I so was happy to hear that! Now I look forward to my sleep again!

**MAMA HELP: Babies like routine. It prepares them for what to expect next in their day. Try a gentle daily routine where you do the same things at around the same time each day. It’s likely your baby will eat and sleep better.**

pages.subtitle: Will I need a caesarean?
pages.title: Will I need a caesarean?
pages.content:
Sometimes an operation is the safest way to have your baby. You can only have a caesarean at a health facility.

An operation may be needed if you are having more than 1 baby, or if your baby is not in a good position to be born.

If you have been in labour for more than 12 hours, you may need an operation to help your baby to be born. If you are labouring at home, this is the time to go to the health facility to see if there is a problem.

If you are bleeding during labour, an operation may be needed very quickly.

If you had an operation with a previous baby, you may need one with this baby as well. In this case, make sure you plan to have this baby in a health facility.

You may be asleep while you have the operation, or you may have an injection in your spine so you feel no pain. A cut is made in your stomach. Your baby will be delivered by the doctor and then you are stitched up again. You will see your baby as soon as she is born, or when you wake up if you have been asleep for the operation.

After the operation, you will need to be looked after for several days while the cut heals. You will bleed from your vagina for a few weeks, just as you would with a normal birth.

pages.subtitle: Help your baby boy heal
pages.description: Here’s how to care for your circumcised baby boy
pages.title: Help your baby boy heal
pages.content:
If your baby’s penis is bandaged, the bandage should fall off within 2 days. If it does not, soak the penis in warm water, and gently unwrap the bandage. Apply antiseptic if the health facility gave it to you. If not, petroleum jelly can protect the wound from germs.

There may be some blood on your baby boy's nappy for a few hours after the procedure. Keep the nappy area clean. Wash his penis gently with clean, safe water and mild soap 3 times a day.

Change his nappy as soon as it gets wet, to avoid infection. You can also give him some nappy-free time. Fresh air will help the wound to dry. Dressing your baby in loose clothing also helps the healing process.

Your baby may feel some pain. Give him a painkiller if the health worker prescribed it. Offer him your breast to comfort him.

The wound should heal within 1 or 2 weeks. Take him to the health facility if his penis is red and swollen after 2 to 3 days, if he is still bleeding or if he is passing water less often than normal.

Remember: it is never safe to circumcise a girl at any age. Girls should not be circumcised at all.

pages.subtitle: I am constipated, help!
pages.description: Eat lots of fruit and vegetables
pages.title: I am constipated, help!
pages.content:
Being constipated means you are not passing stools. You might have to strain more. Or you might be unable to fully empty your bowels. Your stools might also be unusually hard, lumpy, large or small.

Lots of women get constipated in pregnancy. It has different causes:

- As your baby gets bigger, your womb presses down on your pelvic area. This makes constipation more likely.

- Pregnancy hormones can also slow the movement of food through your body.

- A lack of exercise can also slow your digestive system down.

You can help your body by eating more fruit and vegetables. Try dark green leafy vegetables like kale and spinach, and also eat raw guava, taro and mushrooms. Vegetables and fruit are high in fibre, which will help to make your stools softer and easier to pass. Drink plenty of clean, safe water. This will also help prevent constipation.

If you take iron tablets to stop you getting anaemic, they can cause constipation. Do not stop taking the tablets, as they are very important for you and your baby’s health. Instead, ask your doctor or health worker for a different type of iron tablet and drink more clean, safe water; eat well and make sure you get some exercise every day.

pages.subtitle: Je, si ujauzito unapaswa kuwa wa kufurahia?
pages.description: Je, si ujauzito unapaswa kuwa wa kufurahia?
pages.title: MAMA wa Mjini: Ana wasiwasi wakati wote
pages.content:
Kipindi cha ujauzito kinapaswa kuwa cha kufurahia. Kila kinachotendeka mwilini mwangu kinapaswa kunijaza na furaha. Lakini kwa sasa ninachohisi ni wasiwasi tu.

Mimi huwa na wasiwasi kuhusu kila kitu. Je, leba itakuaje? Mimba yangu inaweza kuharibika? Kuna jambo mbaya litakalotendeka? Na iwapo maji yangu yatapasuka mbele ya watu? Na iwapo mtoto wangu ana tatizo? Pia hupata ndoto za kutisha ninapolala.

Ninapoamka asubuhi sina nguvu ya kutoka kitandani. Ninaweza kuhisi mtoto akisonga ndani yangu lakini bado huwa na mawazo mengi kuhusu jambo baya linaloweza kutokea. Nampenda mtoto huyu kwa moyo wangu wote. Ndoto yangu ni kuwa atakuwa na maisha mazuri sana. Lakini jinsi siku yangu ya kuzaa inavyokaribia, ndivyo ninavyozidi kuwa na wasiwasi zaidi kuhusu kitakachotendeka kwangu na kwa mtoto. Hii si kawaida?

Nashangaa iwapo ni kawaida kuhisi hivi wakati wa ujauzito. Mwanzoni nilikuwa mwenye furaha sana. Huenda ikawa naogopa leba tu, au naogopa ukweli kuhusu hali yangu. Lolote lile, nampenda mtoto wangu na nitafanya nitakaloweza kulifanya kwa njia bora zaidi.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Wasiwasi ni mojawapo ya mambo ambayo kina mama huripoti sana wakati wa ujauzito. Hutokea sana kuliko kichefuchefu cha mjamzito asubuhi na tamaa kubwa ya vyakula fulani. Wewe si wazimu. Una mimba tu!**

pages.subtitle: Is she getting enough milk?
pages.title: Is she getting enough milk?
pages.content:
If your baby is feeding at least 6 to 8 times a day, and you are comfortable feeding her, she is probably getting enough milk. You will be able to see her swallow while she is feeding, and your breasts will feel emptier and softer after feeds.

Another good sign is if your baby changes rhythm while sucking and pauses during feeds. She should start feeding again when she is ready, and come off your breast when she wants to.
