Your baby's nappies can also show if your baby is getting enough milk. Her stools should be a yellow colour and she should pass them at least once a day. When you change her nappy, the water she passes should be pale and should have no smell. She should have at least 6 to 8 wet nappies every day.

A baby who gets enough milk will also have firm, healthy coloured skin that bounces back when lightly pinched.

If you are worried that your baby is not getting enough milk, ask a health worker. They will be able to check that your baby is healthy.

pages.subtitle: Your baby can copy you
pages.title: 9 months old
pages.content:
Your baby is used to her surroundings and she likes familiar things. At this age, she may be clingy and need distracting. She may feel calmer if she can keep her own blanket or favourite toy with her, so she carries a little bit of home when she goes out. Quiet time away from noise and strangers will also help her to adjust.

By now, your baby remembers things, like where her toys are kept. She can also copy actions she has seen as far back as two weeks ago. But she still can’t remember everything. Your baby's long-lasting memory may not develop until she is two or three years old.

Your baby's babbling may begin to sound more like real words. Your baby thinks she is saying something, so respond as if she really is! She’ll learn about conversation and facial expressions from you when you talk to her and look at her.

Your baby still understands more from your tone than from your actual words. She knows when she has made you happy, so offer lots of praise.

Your baby's personality is really coming out now. She may be sociable and smile at everyone she meets, or she may be shy and hide her face. Your baby knows how to get your attention now, and she may wave goodbye when she sees you go to the door.

pages.subtitle: How much will my baby sleep?
pages.title: How much will my baby sleep?
pages.content:
Newborn babies sleep a lot! You can expect your baby to be asleep for up to 18 hours a day for the first few weeks.

He may not sleep for more than 3 or 4 hours at once, day or night. This means that you will not be sleeping for long either.

Your baby sleeps for shorter amounts of time than an adult, and he sleeps much more lightly. This type of sleep is a normal part of his brain development.

He will sleep more deeply, and for longer, from when he is about 6 to 8 weeks old. Most babies then begin to sleep for less time during the day and longer at night. However, they will still wake up to feed during the night.

Some babies sleep through the night when they are as young as 8 weeks old. But it’s more likely that your nights will be interrupted for at least the first 5 or 6 months. Try to sleep when your baby does. Take naps during the day. This will keep you energised.

pages.subtitle: I feel a bit crazy!
pages.title: Motherof4: Horrible pregnancy hormones
pages.content:
I've realised something about myself - I'm not very easy to live with when I'm pregnant. When I was pregnant with my first child, I remember being surprised at how angry I would get with my husband. We had terrible fights! But now I’m quite sure it was just the pregnancy hormones. Thankfully once my daughter was born things settled down. But it didn't do my marriage much good.

Now, ten years later, I’m pregnant with twins. And those crazy pregnancy hormones are playing with my moods again! There have been a few days when I really and truly just lost my temper. But this time it’s not just my husband who has had to deal with my moods.

Recently, I stormed off down a dirt road crying my eyes out in anger at something so small I can’t even remember what it was. Last week, I sulked in a room on my own when we visited my husband’s family for dinner. When I came out, I found my husband had taken my advice and gone home without me!

I also shouted at friends who were staying in our home with us when I came home from my job to find the dishes unwashed! Then there was the day I slammed our front door in the face of somebody who was trying to sell me vegetables.

I even burst into tears when somebody said something kind to me and helped me into the train carriage!

Thank goodness the rollercoaster is almost over... I just hope that I will be forgiven for my mood swings by the time baby comes.

**MAMA HELP: It's common to have mood swings during pregnancy. This is partly because of the change you face in your life. It is also partly because of the rise in hormone levels in your body. This can affect your mood, making you feel tearful or easily irritated.**

pages.subtitle: Why do I need regular check-ups?
pages.title: Why do I need regular check-ups?
pages.content:
When you are pregnant, it is a good idea to have regular check-ups by a health worker or health facility. It is best to have at least 4 visits while you are pregnant. Try to make the first visit for just after you missed your period.

Here is why regular check-ups make sense:

- At the check-up, a health worker will do tests to make sure that you and your baby are well.

- If there are problems when you are pregnant, your health worker will find them early. This will give you the best chance of getting the right treatment so you and your baby are healthy.

- If you have questions about your pregnancy, your health worker is the best person to ask. She will answer your questions and will give you the right information.

- You may be able to get free iron and folic acid tablets from your health worker. These tablets give you the strength to carry your baby and help your baby to grow well.

- You will feel reassured your baby is growing well.

Find out how to get to your nearest health worker or health facility. Talk to your family about why you need to visit regularly during pregnancy. Ask them for help if you need transport.

If you are worried, ask a close friend or a family member to go with you. If it is a long way, you may want to carry some food and water with you.

pages.subtitle: What happens in early labour?
pages.description: Your body softens and starts to open
pages.title: What happens in early labour?
pages.content:
Your body is meant to give birth. It will stretch and open in labour.

First, your cervix (the opening to your womb) has to shorten and soften. Feel your nose: it is firm. Now feel your lips: they are soft and stretchy. Your cervix starts out firm like your nose. In early labour, it becomes soft and stretchy like your lips.

Next, your cervix starts to open and widen. You may not notice this starting. Your womb may be contracting very gently. It might feel like the cramps you get with your period.

As time passes, you will get increasingly painful contractions. They will start to come regularly.

Everybody's labour is different. But usually, early contractions are more than 5 minutes apart and short, perhaps only 30 or 40 seconds long. They will not bother you much yet.

For some women, early labour starts and stops. For others, it moves smoothly into full labour, which gets stronger until your baby is born.

pages.subtitle: Your baby is coming NOW!
pages.description: Here’s how your body will give birth
pages.title: Your baby is coming NOW!
pages.content:
As labour goes on, contractions last longer and come more often.

This is the strong, active phase of labour. Contractions in strong labour open your cervix more rapidly, ready for your baby to pass through. You probably will not be able to talk through these contractions, or make eye contact or even smile at people. You will have to stop what you are doing, curl up or kneel down and focus completely on coping with the contraction. Each one may leave you sweating and you may find you make loud groaning noises through the contraction.

Contractions may come as often as every 3 to 4 minutes and last 60 to 90 seconds. Between contractions, move around to get comfortable, have a cool drink, and talk to those around you.

Listen to your body and try different positions to stay comfortable.

Pass water often.

If you can, have a wash with warm, clean, safe water, or even take a warm shower or bath to ease the pain.

pages.subtitle: Je, anapata maziwa ya kutosha?
pages.title: MAMA aliyechanganyikiwa: Mtoto wangu ananyonya sana
pages.content:
Nilikuwa nimejifungua tu hospitalini muuguzi aliponipatia mtoto wangu msichana. Akasema: lazima umpe titi lako sasa hivi. Kisha akaondoka. Nilikuwa kwa mshtuko. Nitamnyonyesha vipi? Sikuwa na ufahamu wowote…

Niliweka kinywa chake kwenye chuchu yangu na nikadhani kuwa atanyonya – lakini hakufanya hivyo. Hakuonekana aliyejua la kufanya au jinsi ya kuweka titi langu kinyani mwake. Nilijaribu usiku kucha. Na mtoto wangu aliendelea kulia. Hatimaye niliweza kuiweka chuchu yangu kinywani mwake, angenyonya kidogo na kuacha. Lakini angeamka tena na kulia na kutaka zaidi.

Niliendelea hivi usiku kucha. Lakini alitoa kinyesi cha kwanza. Kisha alilala karibu siku nzima. Nilipoondoka hospitalini siku iliyofuata, ilikuwa vivyo hivyo nyumbani. Alikuwa macho usiku kucha akilia na kisha kulala sehemu kubwa ya siku.

Kwa bahati nzuri nyumbani, nimekuwa na mama yangu kunisaidia. Lakini umekuwa usiku kadhaa wa kutolala na sasa uchovu meanza kuniandama. Mtoto wangu ana mawazo yake mwenyewe kuhusu wakati wa kulala. Kwa hivyo, maisha yangu yamegeuzwa. Niko macho usiku kucha bali tena siwezi kulala mchana. Sikumbuki ni lini nilipolala vizuri.

Mtoto wangu hulia sana na sina uhakika iwapo anapata maziwa ya kutosha. Sijui nimpe maziwa ya fomyula pia kwa sababu anaonekana mwenye njaa. Nazidi kujaribu. Anaonekana anayeongeza uzani na anatoa vinyesi na mkojo vyema tu.

Lakini ananyonya bila kukoma na ninapoondoa titi langu yeye hulia. Nadhani ni mimi ninayehitaji usaidizi.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Watoto wachanga ni kazi nyingi! Wao hulia sana. Wao hula sana pia. Lakini iwapo mtoto wako anaongeza uzani, kutoa kinyesi na nepi zake ni baridi, basi nyinyi nyote mnaendelea vizuri. Kumbuka kumrudisha mtoto wako kwenye kliniki kwa uchunguzi wa mara kwa mara. Muuguzi atahakikisha kuwa anakua na kunyonya vizuri.**

pages.subtitle: Can I drink alcohol?
pages.description: Alcohol is harmful to you and your baby
pages.title: Can I drink alcohol?
pages.content:
It is better not to drink alcohol while you are pregnant, and also while you are breastfeeding. This will keep your baby safe and healthy.

A small amount of alcohol is usually safe, and if you had a small amount of alcohol before you knew you were pregnant, do not worry. But it is best not to drink any alcohol while you are pregnant.

Here’s why. Alcohol is a harmful substance. When you drink alcohol, it rapidly reaches your baby via your bloodstream. Heavy drinking can cause pregnancy loss and premature birth. Too much alcohol can even increase the risk of your baby being stillborn.

If you drink too much alcohol during pregnancy, it can damage your developing baby's cells forever. This could affect how your baby's face, organs and brain grow.

Remember that traditional medicines from the market often contain alcohol. So they are not good for you at all! They are bad for you and your baby, so do not use them.

pages.subtitle: I can feel it in my bones!
pages.description: I can feel it in my bones!
pages.title: readyDAD: I’m the man
pages.content:
The closer we get to the birth of our child, the stronger I feel. It is so clear in my mind: I want to care for this child and support it.

I have never looked after anything before, not even my little cousins who were bullied in the schoolyard. I always wished I could help them back then. But now I know I really can help my own child. I feel like I’m becoming a better man!

Being a father will be good for me. It’s reminding me that I do have the power to protect others from danger. I am filled with such happiness when I think of myself as the father and the caregiver.

I want to be faithful to my wife and to this child. I don’t want to be a father who is only there for the big moments in a child’s life. Or the man who stands up only to discipline the child when it misbehaves.

I want to be there for every part of this kid’s life. When I think about the job of a father, I cannot think of any other that could be more important!

**MAMA HELP: Being a father is a job for life. Even if you are no longer in a relationship with a child’s mother, there are responsibilities. These are to your child. But being a father comes with all the rewards as well. You’ll feel love and pride as your watch your healthy, happy child grow up.**

pages.subtitle: 1yearold Swa Ke baby
pages.description: Kuwa mwangalifu sasa, mtoto wako anaweza kuchunguza!
pages.title: Umri wa mwaka 1
pages.content:
Mtoto! Furahia siku ya kuzaliwa. Hivi karibuni, mtoto wako atajitegemea zaidi, atapata ucheshi wake na zaidi ya yote, atajifunza kusema kwamba anakupenda.

Mtoto wako bado anaweza kuwa hapendi ukimwacha. Hili ni jambo la kawaida. Ikiwa kuna muda mwingi wa kusema kwa heri, atapata muda wa kuzoea.

Ni jambo la kufurahisha mtoto wako anaposema maneno sawasawa. Lakini bado hataweza kusema anachotaka au anavyohisi kwa kutumia maneno. Atatumia lugha ya vitendo vya mwili kwa muda. Anaweza kuinua mikono yake kuelekeza "juu" au kunyosha kidole akimaanisha "Ile ni nini?"

Anaweza kutumia neno moja kumaanisha vitu vingi. Sikiliza sauti inavyotoka. Atasema neno lilelile kwa njia tofauti akitumia ishara tofauti.

Anaweza kuchukua vitu vidogo akitumia kidole gumba na kidole cha shahada kwa urahisi sasa. Anaweza kuokota vitu toka sakafuni na kuviweka mdomoni. Kagua vitu vilivyo sakafuni ili kuhakikisha hakuna kitu hatari kinachoweza kumdhuru.

Anatazama kila kitu unachofanya. Watoto hupenda kuiga watu, hasa wazazi wao. Hivi ndivyo wanavyojifunza. Ataiga maneno yako na sauti ya lugha yako pia.

Anaweza akawa na meno mengi sasa. Yaweke safi kwa mswaki mdogo ulio laini na kiasi kidogo cha dawa ya meno.

Mwangalie mtoto wako mpendwa na ukumbuke safari mliyosafiri pamoja - kuanzia yule mtoto mchanga asiyejiweza hadi mtoto wa mwaka 1 mwenye nguvu.

Kila la heri kwa siku zijazo.

pages.subtitle: 5 ways to stay healthy
pages.title: 5 ways to stay healthy in pregnancy
pages.content:
1. **Eat well.** Try to eat some fruits and vegetables every day. Eat ugali, rice, chapati, eggs, fish, and beans regularly. Add nuts to your food to make it even healthier. Fruits like oranges, mangoes, papayas and pineapples are good. Get lots of them. Try to have 1 extra handful of food with every meal. Do not go without food for too long. Carry some food with you if you have to go somewhere.

2. **Get check-ups** while you are pregnant. Try to have 4 visits to your health worker. Get your blood and urine tests and blood pressure checks done regularly. These tests help to find problems early. Then you can get treatment and keep yourself and your baby safe.

3. **Get tested for HIV.** If you are living with HIV, there are medicines to help keep you well and prevent your baby from being born HIV+. If you find out you are not HIV+, you can make sure you stay that way.

4. **Take your pregnancy tablets.** These iron and folic acid tablets help your baby grow well. You may also get medicine to help prevent malaria.

5. **Keep clean.** Wash your hands with soap before cooking and eating and after using the toilet.

pages.subtitle: Ninahisi hadi kwenye mifupa!
pages.title: Baba aliye tayari: Mimi ndiye mwanamume
pages.content:
Jinsi tunavyokaribia siku ya kuzaliwa kwa mtoto wetu ndivyo ninavyojihisi kuwa mwenye nguvu zaidi. Ni dhahiri sana katika mawazo yangu kuwa nataka kutunza na kusaidia mtoto huyu.

Sijawahi kutunza chochote kile, hata binamu zangu wadogo waliokuwa wakidhulumiwa katika uwanja wa shule. Ninatamani ningeweza kuwasaidia wakati ule. Lakini kwa sasa ninajua kwa hakika ninaweza kumsaidia mtoto wangu. Ninahisi kwamba ninazidi kuwa mwanamume mzuri!

Kuwa baba ni vizuri kwangu. Kunanikumbusha kuwa nina uwezo wa kukinga wengine dhidi ya hatari. Ninajawa na furaha ninapojifikiria kama baba na mtunzaji.

Nataka kuwa mwaminifu kwa mke wangu na mtoto huyu. Sitaki kuwa baba anayejitokeza tu katika majira ya raha katika maisha ya mtoto. Au kuwa mwanamume anayesimama tu kumuadhibu mtoto punde tu mtoto anapokosea.

Ninataka kuwa katika kila sehemu ya maisha ya mtoto huyu. Ninapofikiria kuhusu kazi ya baba, siwezi kufikiria kazi nyingine muhimu kuliko hiyo!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Kuwa baba ni kazi ya maisha. Hata ikiwa hauna uhusiano na mama ya mtoto, una majukumu. Majukumu haya ni kwa mtoto wako. Hata hivyo kuwa baba huja na malipo pia. Utahisi upendo na fahari unapomtazama mtoto wako mwenye afya na raha anapokua.**

pages.subtitle: Make your baby laugh
pages.title: 4 months old
pages.content:
Your baby is changing quickly. She can make basic sounds. She may even say something that sounds like ‘Ma-ma’ this month!

Don't worry if she doesn't. All babies develop at different rates.

So far, she has needed your full-time attention. Now she may be happy amusing herself sometimes. You may find her happily playing with her hands and feet!

At this age, it is good for your baby to be with loved ones or trusted friends. As she grows, your baby will need to learn social skills and how to interact with others. Your family will love having a cuddle! You can give her lots of cuddles when you get back.

Even though crying is still your baby's best form of communication, she is also getting a sense of humour. Play peek-a-boo with her. See if she laughs when your face appears from under a blanket.

At this age, if he is on his belly, he may lift up his head and shoulders, using his arms for support. Your baby may even be able to roll over from his front to his back. Encourage him by jiggling a toy on the side he usually rolls to. Clap and smile when he does!

pages.subtitle: Mtoto wangu na mimi tu
pages.title: MAMA wa Kawaida: Kifukofuko vuguvugu cha kuzalia
pages.content:
Mara tu mtoto wangu alipozaliwa nilimshika kwa nguvu. Singemruhusu mkunga kumchukua kutoka kwangu ili kumpima uzani au kumdunga sindano. Na hata pia kumuosha. Bado! Nilitaka muda na yeye kwanza.

Nilijua kuwa kile ambacho mtoto wangu alihitaji ni kulala kwenye kifua changu na mimi. Kitamizi bora zaidi ulimwenguni ni katikati ya matiti yangu. Hii ndiyo mtoto huhitaji, chakula, joto na mguso.

Katika kliniki, wataka kukwambia cha kufanya. Lakini nilisikiza silika zangu kama mama wa mara ya kwanza. Ulikuwa wakati wa familia yangu mpya kuwa pamoja. Mtoto wangu alikuwa akisikia sauti ya wazazi wake kwa mara ya kwanza. Niliongea naye huku baba yake akitoa sauti na kuimba.

Nilimuweka kwenye titi langu. Mara ya kwanza alilamba tu chuchu yangu kisha akanyonya kwa sekunde chache kabla ya kuacha. Iligharimu usaidizi wa mkunga kutuonyesha jinsi ya kumfanya kujishikiza kunyonya inavyofaa. Hii ilichukua angalau saa moja. Sasa ninapomnyonyesha ninaweza kuona macho yake yanayong’aa yakinitazama.

Wakati wa kuoga na kupima uzani utafika. Nitahakikisha kuwa amepata chanjo zake zote kwa wakati unaofaa. Lakini bado. Sasa ni wakati wa kumjua. Ndani yangu najua kuwa jambo bora zaidi ninalopaswa kufanya sasa hivi ni kumlisha mara kwa mara na kumuweka karibu.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Wakati wako na mtoto mchanga ni wa thamani. Nyote mumefanya kazi nzuri! Chukueni muda kijiunganisha na kukumbatiana. Ni mara ya kwanza unapokutana na zawadi hii ya thamani. Ulimwengu unaweza kusubiri.**

pages.subtitle: What solid food is best?
pages.description: Soft, mashed family food at 6 months old
pages.title: What solid food is best?
pages.content:
When your baby is 6 months old, he can have tiny portions of soft, mashed family food, as well as breastmilk.

Just a spoonful is enough at first. Sit facing him and offer some soft food on your clean finger or on a spoon. It may take him a while to know how to move the food around with his tongue and swallow it. Be patient. He will learn.

Give him mashed food once a day to begin, then twice a day and then 3 times a day. Offer him breastmilk before and after the mashed food.

Your baby's stools will change after eating food, getting darker and smellier. This is normal.

When your baby starts to pick up things for himself, you will know this is the time to give him more filling foods. Try hard-boiled eggs, well-chopped fish, or meat or mashed peas and beans, or dry bread if he is teething. Do not add salt or spices to your baby’s food.

Now he is moving around, your baby needs to eat 3 to 4 times a day. Give him snacks, as well as meals. His food must be soft, so he can mash it up with his tongue and swallow. Stay with him when he is eating, in case he chokes.

Wash his hands with soap and water before he eats.

Your breastmilk is still healthy for him, so breastfeed whenever he wants.

Now he is older, he can also have clean, safe water, but not cola, tea, coffee or sugary drinks.

pages.subtitle: Then I met my baby girl
pages.description: Then I met my baby girl
pages.title: MOMinpain: Will this labour ever end?
pages.content:
My pregnancy was physically easy. But I was very moody due to the pregnancy hormones. I disagreed with my husband all the time! So I was glad when my due date came. But it passed and my baby wasn’t showing any signs of arriving.

I waited and waited...

Then, 7 days after my due date I noticed some blood on my underwear. I got my things together and we went to the hospital. When I got there it was 9.30pm. There was no pain at all… until about 1am. Then it started!

I told myself to just hang in there as I knew it was a matter of time before my baby came. But by 10am the next morning I was tired and it was so painful.

I got panicky. I told the midwives I was dying. They said: well, first you need to push your baby out and then you can die on your own. But we need you to push first!

I got so angry with them. I was shouting at everyone.

They kept telling me to walk up and down the corridor.

My husband came back at 8pm that night. By then I was like a crazy person. First I told him to take my clothes off because I was too hot. Then I told him to dress me again because I was cold. The poor man just did whatever I asked!

Finally at 8.40pm I felt like pushing. The midwives were there. They told me to push when I felt like pushing - but that I should not force it. It was quick. Five minutes later at 8.45pm, I gave birth to my baby girl.

**MAMA HELP: Every woman’s labour is different, but eventually they all end in a baby! Find out as much as you can about the stages of labour before you give birth. Ask your mother and your friends to tell you their birth stories. Knowledge will give you confidence.**

pages.subtitle: Je, yatawahi kuisha?
pages.title: Mama mwenye fahari: Mtoto wangu ana madoadoa
pages.content:
Mtoto wangu alikuwa mrembo alipozaliwa. Hata wauguzi waliniambia jinsi alivyopendeza. Alikuwa na nywele nyingi nyeusi na kucha nzuri zaidi za mikono. Niliona fahari kuonyesha wengine mtoto wangu!

Lakini baada ya majuma 2 alianza kupata chunusi kwenye uso wote. Chunusi hizi zilianza kutokea kwenye shavu la kushoto na kuenea hadi kwenye paji lote la uso na kidevu. Pia alipata magamba juu ya nyusi zake, nyuma ya masikio na kwa nywele.

Niliaibika watu walipotaka kumuona mtoto wangu kwani uso wake haukuwa mzuri. Wakati mwingine nilishawishika kufinya chunusi hizi. Lakini mama yangu aliniambia ni heri niziache bila kutumia krimu au lihamu yoyote bali maji safi tu. Kwa bahati nzuri mtoto hangeweza kujiona na hakuonekana kujali!

Ilikuwa ni vigumu kwangu kuwaangalia watoto wengine. Mbona watoto wengine walionekana kuwa wazuri zaidi ilhali mtoto wangu alikuwa na madoadoa? Nilihofia kuwa madoadoa haya hayatapotea kamwe. Nilishangaa kilichoyasababisha. Je, lilikuwa jambo nililofanya au kitu nilichokula nilipokuwa mjamzito?

Kwa bahati nzuri, alipofikisha majuma 6 madoadoa yote yalipotea na ngozi yake ikawa laini tena. Bado alikuwa na baadhi ya magamba kichwani lakini ilikuwa vigumu kuyaona kwa sababu ya nywele yake. Amerejelea kuwa mtoto mrembo jinsi alivyokuwa alipozaliwa, isipokuwa ni mkubwa tu sasa!

**MSAADA WA MAMA: Uvimbe na madoadoa mengi kwa mtoto mchanga huwa haina madhara na hupotea yenyewe. Ngozi ya mtoto wako huwa ikijizoesha mazingira mapya.**

pages.subtitle: Can you feel your baby move?
pages.description: Can you feel your baby move?
pages.title: Month 5
pages.content:
Now your baby in your womb looks like a tiny newborn baby. Her eyes, eyebrows and eyelids have developed and her teeth are growing under her gums. The taste buds on her tongue are developing. She will be able to taste your milk from the first feed.

She has a creamy white substance covering her skin. This protects your baby’s skin and helps with the birth.

About this time, you may begin to feel your baby's movements. It feels like tiny bubbles inside you. At first, you may not be sure what it is. Gradually the movements become stronger and you can then be sure that it is your baby kicking. It is an exciting moment!

You could also start to feel breathless now and you may feel clumsy. This is because you are carrying more weight and your bump affects your balance.

You may have a heavier discharge and want to urinate more often.

If you notice some bleeding when you brush your teeth, it is because your pregnancy hormones are making your gums swell and become sore, which can lead to bleeding. Brush every day, but be gentle.

pages.subtitle: How to swaddle your baby
pages.title: How to swaddle your baby
pages.content:
You need a clean cloth large enough to wrap around your baby and tuck in. Lay a clean cloth on a flat surface. Position it like a diamond shape, with a point at the top, and fold down the top corner. Place your baby on his back with his neck on the fold.

Hold your baby's right arm down flat at his side. Pull the left corner of the blanket over his right arm and across his body. Then tuck it under his left arm and roll him to your left, and wrap whatever is remaining under his back. Tuck it in securely while making sure your baby can still bend his hips up and outwards.

Hold your baby's left arm down and pull the bottom corner up over his left shoulder. Tuck any extra material around his left arm.

Bring the loose right corner straight out to pull it taut. Then pull it across your baby's front and roll him to your right a bit, so you can wrap the corner all the way around his back.

Take care not to pull the cloth too tight or your baby could suffocate.

pages.subtitle: How do I know I'm pregnant?
pages.title: How do I know I’m pregnant?
pages.content:
Are you pregnant? How can you tell? The surest sign is a missed period, but you may find it hard to remember the date of your last period.

Do you have any of these signs of pregnancy?

- Your breasts look and feel different

- You notice some spots of blood in your underwear

- You feel nauseous

- You need to urinate more than usual

- You miss a period

If you think you are pregnant, it is best if you see a health worker. The earlier you find out, the sooner you can start planning for your new baby. A health worker will also be able to give you advice and help while you are pregnant.

The health worker will weigh you, check your blood pressure and test your urine, to make sure you and your baby are healthy.

Worried about seeing a health worker? Ask a friend to go with you.

pages.subtitle: 10monthold Swa ke baby
pages.description: Mtoto wako anaanza kuelewa maneno na misemo rahisi.
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 10
pages.content:
Mtoto wako anaanza kuelewa maneno na misemo rahisi. Jaribu kurudia maneno yake, ukitumia lugha ya watu mzima.

Polepole, atajifunza kujitegemea, na atapunguza kulia unapomwacha. Lakini, wakati mwingine, kumuacha kutakuwa kuchungu na atalia! Ikiwa ana kitu kilicho na harufu yako, kama vile nguo ulizokuwa umevaa, kitasaidia kumtuliza.

Katika umri huu, mtoto wako anaweza kuketi bila wasiwasi na anaweza kutembea akiwa anajishikilia kwenye samani. Anaweza hata kuachilia kwa muda mfupi na akasimama bila kujishikilia, au hata apige hatua chache ukimshikilia mikono yake.

Katika umri huu, mtoto wako atajifunza kujilisha kwa mikono mlo wote. Atataka kunywa kutoka kwenye kikombe. Hii ni stadi mpya, na atahitaji kufanya mazoezi kwa miezi kadhaa ili azoee!

Mtoto wako anaweza kuelewa maelekezo rahisi sasa. Lakini haimaanishi atakuwa akifuatilia neno 'hapana' kila wakati! Ataelewa neno 'hapana' vyema zaidi ikiwa linatumiwa hasa kumsaidia kujua tofauti ya jambo zuri na baya, na hali salama na hatari.

pages.subtitle: Is sex safe, now I'm pregnant?
pages.description: Sex in pregnancy is usually safe
pages.title: Is sex safe, now I’m pregnant?
pages.content:
Are you worried about sex while you are pregnant?

You can have sex just like you did before you were pregnant. Sex does not cause pregnancy loss.

However, if you feel pain in your belly, you are bleeding, or you had problems in a previous pregnancy, talk to your health worker first. It may be safer not to have sex until after your baby is born.

You may feel uncomfortable and may not want to have sex. Many women feel like that. Try to show love in other ways. Have a cuddle or a massage.

If you have are leaking sticky fluid (a discharge) or you are itching and you want to have sex, use a condom. It is safer. If you notice a discharge, you should also go to the health worker when you can.

It is a good idea to always use condoms while you are pregnant. They protect you and your baby against infections you can get from sex and from HIV.

You can get infections from having any type of unprotected sex with someone who has an infection that you can pass on by having sex, including HIV.

These infections can make you and your baby very sick. A health worker will test you for infections and will help you to manage them. Symptoms to look for include a rash around your vagina or pain when you pass urine.

Remember, you can have an infection with no symptoms. So it is a good idea to get tested.

pages.subtitle: 3monthold Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 3
pages.content:
Mtoto wako anaendelea kuwa mwepesi wa kutembeza viungo vyake. Anaweza kufurahia kufungua na kufunga vidole vyake, au kupiga makofi.

Ucheshi wa mtoto wako pia unakua. Kumtekenya au kumbusu kwa sauti kwenye tumbo kunaweza kumchekesha.

Tangu kuzaliwa kwake, mtoto wako hupenda kuguswa. Ni muhimu kwa ukuaji na maendeleo yake. Kumkanda taratibu mwilini wake baada ya kumuogesha au kumkumbatia kwa muda mrefu kabla hajalala ni kitu kizuri kwa nyote wawili.

Kucheza peke yake kunausaidia ubongo wa mtoto wako kukua. Ubongo wake unavyokua, ndivyo anavyozidi kuwa mdadisi.

Anaweza kucheza na kitu kidogo cha kuchezea anachoweza kushika na kutikisa. Atakuwa anajifunza pia kuhusu rangi, maumbo na ukubwa. Pia anajifunza kutokana na kelele za kitu anachochezea na kutokana na kukihisi kama ni nyororo au kigumu.

Mtoto wako ataanza kuchekacheka na kutabasamu unapokunja sura kumchekesha na atafurahia mizaha mingi. Atafurahia pia kusikia sauti nyingi. Piga kidoko kwa ulimi, mluzi au toa sauti za wanyama. Atazipenda.

pages.subtitle: Ninahofia kumuacha mtoto wangu
pages.title: Mama Mchovu: Mama mkwe anataka kusaidia
pages.content:
Mtoto wangu mvulana alipokuwa na majuma 3, nilikuwa mchovu. Sikuwa nimelala usiku kucha tangu nilipomzaa. Nilihisi kwamba mtoto wangu alijua kufanya mambo matatu tu: kula, kulala na kulia!

Mama mkwe aliona kwamba nilikuwa mchovu na akataka kunisaidia. Alisema kwamba angetunza mtoto ili nipumzike kidogo. Sikuweza kukataa. Lakini kumpa mama mkwe mtoto wangu ilikuwa vigumu zaidi hata kuliko kumsikia akilia!

Nilitazama jinsi mama mkwe alivyompakata mtoto. Sikuona kama alimpakata vyema kwani mimi singempakata hivyo. Ingawa nilijaribu kupata usingizi mdogo, nilikuwa nikimsikia mtoto wangu akilia katika chumba cha pili. Nilitaka tu kuenda na nimchukue mtoto wangu!

Ninafahamu kuwa mama mkwe alikuwa akijaribu kusaidia. Na alifanya kazi nzuri kwa kumlea mwanawe mvulana kwani mume wangu ni mwanamume mzuri sana. Lakini nilitaka kumlinda mtoto wangu sana. Nilitaka tu kupakata mvulana wangu wala nisimpe mtu mwingine yeyote.

Ninafahamu kuwa hakuna hatari itakayompata mtoto wangu, hivyo najaribu kutulia watu wengine wanapotaka kumpakata. Hata hivyo bado ninapata msisimko kisiri ninapoona kwamba tabasamu yake kwangu ndiyo kuu zaidi!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Wewe ni mama wa mara ya kwanza– ni kawaida kabisa kutotaka mtoto wako aondoke machoni mwako. Muda unaposonga, utazoea. Watu wa familia wanapotaka kumpakata mtoto wako, jaribu kuona jambo hili kama jambo zuri. Watu hawa ni wa msaada na wanampenda!**

pages.subtitle: Watch out! There’s a baby about
pages.description: Watch out! There’s a baby about
pages.title: 8 months old
pages.content:
By now, your baby may have started crawling, or shuffling on his bottom. When your baby is mobile, he will start to have bumps and falls. This is part of growing up. Enjoy watching him explore but make sure your house is a safe as you can make it.

Your baby is learning about objects by shaking, banging, dropping, and throwing them. He’s learning about what he can do to an object.

Your baby will start to show interest in things you use. Slowly, he will start to use objects properly. You may find him trying to brush his hair or drink from a cup.

Your baby's vision is much clearer now. He can see almost as well as you. Now he can recognise people and objects across a room. He may see a toy on the other side of the room and try to crawl towards it. His eyes are close to their final colour, too, though you may see small changes later.

Soon, your baby will start to stand and move around the room by holding onto walls and furniture.

pages.subtitle: Your baby gets curious
pages.title: 7 months old
pages.content:
Your baby will start to want to feed herself now. Perhaps she grabs the spoon you are feeding her with, or takes food from your plate? Try putting small chunks of soft foods on her plate. She will love picking them up and eating them! Remember girls need the same amount of food as boys.

Your baby may have a good appetite, but not many teeth. Start with food that a she can gum or easily move round her mouth.

At this age babies get curious. She might throw toys or pull her sister's hair! Your baby is just testing things out, not being bad.

She won’t remember things for very long, so reprimands will not mean much to her yet. But she can be distracted easily. So show her a toy or sing her a song to stop her doing things you don’t want her to do.

Don't worry if she has gaps between her teeth. The spaces between your baby's teeth will probably close up by the time she's three, once all of her baby teeth have grown.

Around now, your baby may get nervous about you going away. She is so attached to you that leaving her, even for a minute, may make her cry. This is normal, and short separations will help your baby socialize with other people. Soon she will learn that you always come back to her.

By now your baby's emotions are getting more obvious. She may blow a kiss to people she knows. She is also beginning to notice other people's moods and copy them. If she sees someone crying, she may start crying, too.

pages.subtitle: I have pain in my belly
pages.description: When to worry about belly pains
pages.title: I have pain in my belly
pages.content:
Aches, pains and cramps in your belly while you are pregnant are normal. They are usually nothing to worry about. Your body is changing to support your growing baby, and your womb is stretching to fit the baby as he grows.

Getting some rest usually eases the cramps. Try to relax. Sit down for a while with your feet up, or lie down on the side opposite to the where you feel the pain.

Sometimes belly pain can mean something is wrong:

- Stomach cramps, bleeding and pain in the centre of the lower belly in early pregnancy could mean that you are losing your baby. Go to the health facility if you feel like this. If the bleeding is heavy and you are soaking more than 1 pad an hour, you need to rush to the health facility.

- Painful cramps that start on one side and spread across your belly may mean that your pregnancy is growing in the wrong place. You may also have bleeding that is dark and watery. This happens in early pregnancy. Go to the health facility immediately.

- In later pregnancy, if you have pain in your lower belly, along with backache, stomach cramps and diarrhoea, it may mean that your baby is trying to be born early. Go to the health facility if you have frequent pains in late pregnancy, if you have bleeding or your waters break.

pages.subtitle: Keep your baby safe
pages.description: Ideas for making your home safe for your baby
pages.title: Keep your baby safe
pages.content:
Here are 4 ways you can keep your baby safe in your home:

- Check your home every day for objects that your baby could pick up. Make sure there are no small objects which could choke him, such as coins, within his reach. Put away sharp objects, such as knives, scissors and pens, and anything that is not safe to eat or drink.

- Check that nothing can fall on your baby. Make sure everything is secure. Any electrical wires or other rope or cords should be rolled up safely and out of his way!

- Keep your baby away from fire and water. Your baby wants to explore; he may touch flames and burn himself. Make sure he cannot touch anything hot when you are cooking. Try putting up a barrier. Keep him away from large containers of water. Keep them covered with tight-fitting lids on top, so he does not fall in.

- Remember, when your baby starts to walk and stand, he may want to climb! Take care that dangerous objects and wires are out of his reach, and watch him to make sure he cannot fall off chairs and tables.

pages.subtitle: Feed your baby solid foods
pages.title: 6 months old
pages.content:
Your baby is ready to start family food along with breastmilk! He can only have a tiny amount of food at first: just a spoonful is enough. He will enjoy mashed family food. Sit facing him and offer some soft food on your clean finger or on a spoon. It may take him a while to know how to move the food around with his tongue and swallow it. Be patient. He will learn.

Give him mashed food once a day to begin. Then twice a day and then three times a day. He may want some breastmilk before the mashed food, and some more breastmilk after the mashed food.

This could be the month your baby gets his first tooth. One of the bottom front teeth usually appears first.

He may start to use one hand more than the other. Then he may switch hands. But you won't really know whether he is right or left-handed until he's two or three years old. Let him hold a small object and pass it from hand to hand. This will help him develop his skills.

Your baby is probably getting more active now, and will enjoy the company of other babies!

Does your baby like a certain object or toy? If so, soon he will not be able to go anywhere without it. This is normal, and a sign of your baby's growing independence, because he can use a toy or cloth for reassurance instead of you.

pages.subtitle: My breasts are swollen
pages.description: Keep breastfeeding – it will help you
pages.title: My breasts are swollen
pages.content:
As your body starts making breastmilk, your breasts fill with milk. They may feel swollen and hard at first. Keep on breastfeeding. As your baby feeds more, your body will learn to make just the right amount of milk. Then your breasts will soften and feel comfortable.

For now, you can relieve the pressure by squeezing out a little of your milk. If your breasts feel too tender to touch, rinse a cloth in hot water (but not so hot that it hurts) and hold it on your breast. The milk will dribble out. Support your heavy breasts with a good bra or cloth.

If your breasts stay full for several days, it could be because your baby has not learnt to open his mouth wide enough when he takes your breast, and is not taking enough milk. Make sure he has a big mouthful of breast when he feeds. If your breast is very full, it could be difficult for him to get a good hold. Squeeze out a little milk before the feed so your breasts are softer and it is easier for him to fix on well.

Look out for signs that show he is asking to be fed, such as sucking his fist or becoming restless. It is easier to feed a hungry, wakeful baby than a hungry, screaming baby! Do not try and set a routine for your baby, but feed him as often as he wants.

After the feed, it may help to cool your breasts with cold, wet cloths.

pages.subtitle: Should I eat differently?
pages.description: You need foods in many colours
pages.title: Should I eat differently?
pages.content:
Now you are pregnant, it is important to try to eat well so your baby will grow well. You and your growing baby need lots of different foods.

A simple way to think about it is to eat lots of different coloured foods!

You could talk to your family about the food you need.

Try to eat some of each of these food types every day:

- Fruit and vegetables. Food like oranges, mangoes, water melon, pineapples, papayas, sukuma wiki, cabbages, tomatoes, onions, kunde, pumpkin leaves, carrots, peas. These protect your baby from being born with a problem.

- Starchy foods. These include ugali, rice, chapati, bananas, potatoes, cassava. These foods give you energy.

- Foods rich in protein. These include eggs, fish, chicken, milk, beans and meat. These are body building foods.

- Calcium-rich and dairy foods. These include milk, and nuts. They help your baby grow strong bones.

pages.subtitle: Why do I need vitamins?
pages.description: Vitamins keep you in good shape
pages.title: Why do I need vitamins?
pages.content:
Vitamins are important in your diet, especially when you are pregnant. They help your baby to grow healthily and keep your body in good shape for becoming a mother.

Eat a variety of fresh food of different colours each day to get vitamins:

- Eggs, orange-coloured fruit and vegetables like mangoes and papaya, sweet potato or carrots. These foods contain vitamin A, which helps your baby's organs and body systems to develop.

- Bananas, potatoes and chicken, brown rice and green vegetables. These foods supply B vitamins to help your body use protein, fats, and carbohydrates (starches). They also help to form new red blood cells and develop the brain and nerves.

- Citrus fruit like oranges, vegetables like potatoes and tomatoes. These are all good sources of vitamin C, which is needed for repairing and growing skin and body tissue. It also helps growth and strengthens bones and teeth.

- Oily fish like sardines, milk and eggs. These contain vitamin D, which helps to build bones and teeth and helps you to fight germs. Our bodies can also make vitamin D from sunlight.

pages.subtitle: Month7 Swa Ke pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 7
pages.content:
Sasa mtoto wako anaweza kufumbua macho yake na kugeuza kichwa chake kuelekea upande wa mwanga, hata akiwa tumboni! Sasa anaweza kusikia, na anaweza kupiga mateke na kuruka anaposikia sauti kubwa, na kutulia unapomwimbia na kuongea naye.

Hivi karibuni atageuka kichwa chini ndani yako. Kichwa chake kitatoka kwanza wakati wa kujifungua, kwa hiyo anageuka juu chini, tayari kwa uchungu wa kujifungua kuanza.

Mimba yako inavyokuwa kubwa zaidi, inaweza kuwa vigumu kutulia na kulala vizuri. Lala kwa upande na uweke mto kati ya miguu yako ili usaidie kushikilia mimba yako. Unaweza kuanza kuhisi maumivu ya nyonga kwa sababu sehemu ya mwili inayovutika inayoshikilia kiuno chako kwenye nyonga yako inaweza kulegea. Hii ni hali ya mwili wako kujitayarisha kwa uchungu wa kujifungua. Kupiga magoti na kuweka mikono chini kunaweza kusaidia.

Utahitaji kufanya mpango wa kuenda kwa mkunga au daktari wakati wa kujifungua. Panga jinsi utakavyosafiri kwenda huko, na labda umuombe rafiki au jamaa yako kama watakusaidia. Zungumza na familia yako na uhakikishe wanajua mahali unapohitaji kwenda.

Nenda kwenye kituo cha afya siku za mwishoni mwa ujauzito ili muuguzi au mfanyakazi wa kituo cha afya aweze kukagua kama wewe na mtoto ni wazima. Wanaweza kukueleza unachohitaji kwa ajili ya kujifungua na wakati gani wa kwenda kwenye kliniki ukipata uchungu wa kujifungua.

pages.subtitle: Kisha nikamuona mtoto wangu msichana.
pages.title: MAMA aliye na uchungu: Je, leba hii itawahi kuisha?
pages.content:
Ujauzito wangu ulikuwa rahisi kimwili. Lakini nilikuwa mwenye kubadilikabadilika kihisia kutokana na homoni za ujauzito. Nilikosana na mume wangu muda wote! Kwa hivyo nilifurahi tarehe yangu ya kujifungua ilivyofika. Lakini ulipita na mtoto wangu hakuwa akionyesha ishara za kufika.

Nilingoja na kungoja…

Kisha siku 7 baada ya terehe yangu tarajiwa niliona damu kwenye chupi yangu. Nilipanga vitu vyangu na tukaenda hospitalini. Nilipofika hapo ilikuwa saa tatu na nusu za usiku. Hakukuwa na uchungu wowote...hadi karibu saa saba za usiku. Kisha ikaanza!

Nilijiambia nivumilie tu, kwani nilijua ni muda tu kabla ya mtoto wangu kuja. Lakini kufikia saa nne asubuhi iliyofuata nilikuwa nimechoka na ilikuwa chungu sana.

Niliingiwa na hofu. Niliwaambia wakunga kuwa nilikuwa nafariki. Walisema: haya, kwanza unahitaji kusukuma mtoto wako nje na kisha ufe kivyako. Lakini tunataka usukume kwanza! Nilikasirishwa sana nao. Nilikuwa napigia kila mtu kelele.

Waliendelea kuniambia nitembee juu na chini kwenye ushoroba.

Mume wangu alirudi saa mbili usiku huo. Wakati huo nilikuwa kama mwenye wazimu. Kwanza nilimuambia anivue nguo kwa sababu nilikuwa na joto sana. Kisha nikamwambia anivishe tena kwa sababu nilikuwa na baridi. Alifanya lolote nililomwambia!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: leba ya kila mwanamke ni tofauti, lakini mwishowe zote hupelekea kupata mtoto! Tafuta habari nyingi iwezekanavyo kuhusu vipindi vya leba kabla ya kuzaa. Muulize mama yako na marafiki wakusimulie hadithi zao za kuzaa. Habari itakupa ujasiri.**

pages.subtitle: Your feelings after pregnancy loss
pages.title: Your feelings after pregnancy loss
pages.content:
Everyone feels differently about pregnancy loss.

This may be a difficult time for you. It may take a few weeks for your body to recover. And while your body is going through all these changes, your emotions may be in turmoil, too.

Allow yourself to feel what you feel. Pregnancy loss is an emotional time. Some people grieve for the loss as they would for a close relative or friend. We all grieve, and it can affect your mind and body in different ways. Or you may feel relieved for many reasons.

Remember that early pregnancy loss is common. It is very unlikely to have happened because of anything you did or did not do.

You might feel angry with those close to you or toward friends or other members of the family who are pregnant or who have had a baby. You might feel overwhelming sorrow. It may seem that everything you had hoped for has been taken away instantly. You may feel exhausted, but unable to sleep. Your everyday routine may seem meaningless. You may not want to eat, or find it hard to concentrate. Or you may feel none of these things.

Remember - you do not have to hide your feelings. Sharing your feelings with friends and family will help you.

We wish you the best of luck in the future.

pages.subtitle: Niligundua njia yangu mwenyewe.
pages.title: Mama wa Kawaida: Kuchanganyikiwa kuhusu kunyonyesha!
pages.content:
Kuna watu wengi wanaonishauri kuhusu ulishaji wa mtoto wangu mchanga, sijui jambo la kufikiria! Baadhi ya marafiki wangu wananieleza nizingiatie saa fulani ya siku ya kumlisha mtoto kama vile baada ya kila saa 4.

Lakini siwezi kumuacha alie anapoonekana mwenye njaa na siwezi kumlazimisha anywe wakati hajisikii. Mimi humchukua akianza kukosa utulivu na kunung’unika na kumuweka kwenye titi. Kwa kwaida anaanza kunyonya hadi ashibe. Kisha titi langu, liliokuwa gumu na lililojaa hapo awali, huhisi lororo na lisilo na chochote.

Mimi hujaribu kumpatia anyonye matiti yote ili aondoe usumbufu ninaohisi matiti yanapokuwa yamejaa. Mtoto wangu huhisi usingizi sana baada ya kunyonya, kwa hivyo huwa namshika angalie juu na kumwachilia apige mbweu na kisha namweka chini alale. Kulingana na kiasi cha kinyesi chake, lazima apate chakula cha kutosha.

Kisha mama mwingine aliniambia kuwa ni lazima nimpatie maji baridi, yaliyochemushwa katikati ya saa za kumlisha akiwa na miezi 6 kwa sababu watoto wanaweza kupungukiwa na maji mwilini. Kuna joto sana mchana, kwa hivyo nilifikiria kuwa nitajaribu. Lakini mtoto wangu hajala chochote ila tu kunyonya. Kwa hivyo nilipojaribu kumwekea kikombe kwa mdomo, alikasirika na hakutaka.

Yeye hutoa mkojo mwingi sana mara 3 hadi 4 kwa siku. Mkojo huwa safi na si wa njano au mzito, kwa hivyo nadhani anakunywa viowevu vya kutosha. Ngozi yake ni waridi na uso wake huendelea kung’aa kila wakati. Alipimwa kwenye klinki na anaendelea kuongeza uzani vizuri, kwa hivyo sina wasiwasi.

Niligundua njia yangu mwenyewe. Chuchu zangu zilikuwa chungu mwanzoni lakini niliambiwa kuwa lazima titi langu lisonge zaidi kwenye kinywa cha mtoto wangu. Si lazima chuchu yangu ifinywe na kaakaa lake, lakini ikae kwa mdomo, mahali ambapo ni nyororo. Tangu nifanye hivyo, haliniumi tena ninaponyonyesha.

Wakati mwingine hajishikizi vizuri na kwa hivyo mimi humuacha afungue mdomo kabisa na kujishikiza tena. Wakati mwingine inafanyika vizuri lakini wakati mwingine tunajaribu mara kadhaa. Inakuwa rahisi tunavyojaribu mara kwa mara.

Sasa nimepata unyonyeshaji kuwa rahisi na kawaida, na usio na matatizo hivi kwamba naweza kuenda mahali popote na kumnyonyesha mtoto wangu ninapotaka!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Mtoto wako anapata maziwa ya kutosha ikiwa ananyonya mara kwa mara, anakojoa mara 6 hadi 8 kwa siku na kuongeza uzani. Miezi 6 ya kwanza hahitaji chakula chochote au viowevu isipokuwa maziwa ya mama.**

pages.subtitle: Check-ups after birth
pages.description: Make sure you are both OK
pages.title: Check-ups after birth
pages.content:
It is good, and reassuring, to have health check-ups in the weeks after your baby is born, to make sure both you and your baby are OK.

Visit the health worker with your baby at least once during week 1 and again when she is 6 weeks old.

Take your baby to a health worker immediately if:

- Her belly is too cold or too hot

- She develops yellow eyes, hands and feet within the first day of his life

- She refuses to feed or sucks poorly

- She will not stop crying or if his cry sounds unusual

- She has a fit, is drowsy and not moving much, or has bluish skin or nails

- She is wheezing, grunting, or breathing quickly

- She is vomiting after every feed for more than a day, or has a swollen tummy

- The area around your baby's cord stump is red or smelly

These are signs that your baby is unwell, and needs treatment quickly.

pages.subtitle: I can feel my baby move!
pages.title: I can feel my baby move!
pages.content:
It is exciting when you first feel your baby move! If this is your first pregnancy, you may not be sure what you are feeling at first. The baby moving feels like gentle butterflies fluttering in your belly.

Your baby's movements will get stronger and more regular. By the middle of pregnancy they will feel like real kicks. In late pregnancy, you may see your whole belly moving as the baby moves around inside you.

Your baby will not move all the time. Like you, sometimes he will want to rest and sleep.

Take a moment to sit down and feel your baby move inside you each day.

You can get used to recognising the movements. Remember his daily routine, when he is awake and when he goes to sleep. You may find you wake up early because the baby is kicking. Or maybe the baby starts kicking when you sing or when you undress to wash.

If you think the movements have slowed down, have a long cold drink or a sweet snack and then sit quietly for a while. You should notice more movements. Tell your health worker if you notice a change in his routine.

If you have not felt your baby move yet, speak to your health worker. She will be able to check that all is well.

pages.subtitle: 6monthold Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 6
pages.content:
Mtoto wako yuko tayari kuanza kula vyakula vya familia pamoja na maziwa anayonyonya! Anaweza kula kiasi kidogo tu cha chakula mwanzoni: kijiko kimoja kinatosha. Atafurahia chakula cha familia kilichopondwa. Keti ukiwa unamwangalia na umpe chakula laini kwenye kidole chako safi au kwenye kijiko. Huenda ikamchukua muda kujua jinsi ya kusogeza chakula kwa ulimi wake na kukimeza. Kuwa na subira. Atajifunza.

Anza kwa kumpa chakula kilichopondwa mara moja kwa siku. Kisha mara mbili kwa siku na kisha mara tatu kwa siku. Anaweza akataka kunyonya maziwa kabla ya chakula kilichopondwa, na kunyonya maziwa tena baada ya chakula kilichopondwa.

Huu unaweza kuwa mwezi ambao mtoto wako ataota jino lake la kwanza. Kwa kawaida mojawapo ya meno ya chini ya mbele ndiyo huwa ya kwanza kuota.

Anaweza kuanza kutumia mkono mmoja zaidi ya mwingine. Kisha anaweza kubadilishana mikono. Lakini hutajua kama yeye ni mtu wa mkono wa kulia au wa kushoto hadi afikishe umri wa miaka miwili au mitatu. Mwache ashikilie kitu kidogo na akipitishe kutoka mkono mmoja hadi mwingine. Hili litamsaidia kuendeleza ustadi wake.

Mtoto wako inawezekana sasa anajishughulisha zaidi, na atafurahia kukaa na watoto wengine!

Je, mtoto wako anapenda kitu fulani au kitu fulani cha kuchezea? Ikiwa ndivyo, hivi karibuni hataweza kwenda mahali popote bila kitu hicho. Hili ni la kawaida, na dalili ya mtoto wako kukuza kujitegemea, kwa sababu anaweza kutumia kitu cha kuchezea au kitambaa kwa uthibitisho badala yako.

pages.subtitle: I didn't know I was pregnant!
pages.description: I didn't know I was pregnant!
pages.title: SurprisedMom: I’m in labour?
pages.content:
I did not even know I was pregnant until I went into labour and delivered my baby. That might sound strange. But I didn’t really gain any weight. Or, if I did, I never noticed because I have quite a big tummy anyway. Then quite suddenly one day, I woke up feeling really dizzy. I went to the clinic just to find out what it was. When I told the nurses how I felt, they decided to run some blood tests.

They came back and told me I was pregnant! I was so shocked I sank to the floor.

Then they told me that my blood pressure was too high and both the baby and I were at risk. They said that they needed to take me to the hospital right away and deliver my baby.

They called my parents and explained everything to them. My parents were so shocked, but at the same time they were very happy.

I was taken by ambulance straight to the hospital and they gave me a C-Section. They handed me my baby boy. A few hours before I had not even known I was pregnant and now I had a baby boy!

**MAMA HELP: A missed period is the first sign you could be pregnant. A test at the clinic will confirm this. The clinic staff will tell you about the regular clinic visits you need to make through pregnancy to keep you and baby safe. Listen carefully to what they say. Try to do what they ask you to do.**

pages.subtitle: 5monthold Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 5
pages.content:
Mtoto wako bado hawezi kuonyesha hisia zake kama wewe. Lakini atakujulisha wakati amekasirika, amechoka au amefurahi. Ataonyesha upendo wake kwako kwa kuinua mikono yake anapotaka kuinuliwa. Anaweza pia kulia unapoondoka chumbani.

Kwa sasa, anaendelea kuwa na nguvu zaidi. Mkalishe sakafuni na utaona anaweza kuketi peke yake kwa muda. Mzingire na mito na ukae karibu naye kumkinga endapo ataanguka.

Anaweza akakushangaza kwa kubiringika ghafla! Usimwache kitandani au sehemu iliyoinuka ili asije akabiringika. Unaweza kubadilisha nepi yake akiwa amelalia kitambaa safi sakafuni.

Kuona kwa mtoto wako bado kunaendelea kukua. Sasa anaweza kuona vitu vidogo na kufuatilia vitu vinavyotembea. Jaribu kuficha kitu chake cha kuchezea anachokipenda zaidi kikiwa kinaonekana sehemu ndogo tu. Atafurahia kukifichua!

Mtoto wako sasa anaweza kukuiga. Toa ulimi wako nje, furisha mashavu yako uone kama atakuiga.

Mtoto wako sasa anaona na kusikia mazingira yake vizuri karibu kama wewe tu. Uwezo wake wa mawasiliano pia unaimarika kwa haraka. Sauti zake zinaonyesha hisia zake. Anaweza kuwa ana furaha, shauku, au akaridhika kwamba ametatua tatizo fulani.

Anaweza kuanza kubwabwaja, akirudia sauti kama vile "ba", "ma", "ga". Haya yote ni maendeleo kuelekea wakati atakapoanza kuongea.

pages.subtitle: Your first milk is the best
pages.description: First breastmilk is a precious gift
pages.title: Your first milk is the best
pages.content:
Your baby is here! Now what to do? Food, of course! And your breasts contain the very best food for your baby.

Plan to put your baby straight to the breast when he is born. It helps get feeding started, gives him your precious first milk and reduces the amount you bleed.

The first milk you make is very thick and creamy-coloured. It is called colostrum. Sometimes you may find this yellowy milk leaking from your breasts.

Colostrum is a precious gift for your baby. It is so good for him, it is like giving him his first vaccination! This first milk is rich in foods and antibodies.

Feed this special first milk to your baby as soon as he is born, within the first hour. It will give your baby the best start in life. Feeding him anything else is harmful and a waste of your special first milk.

Breastmilk alone is the best food. It is free, safe, prevents illness, and helps your baby to grow strong. Let him suckle often.

If you are living with HIV then your baby will need to take antiretrovirals (ARVs). The ARVs will protect him from getting HIV and you will need to feed them to him every day. Your health worker will test your baby for HIV at six weeks.

If you have any questions, ask your health worker.

pages.subtitle: Will they ever go down?
pages.title: BeginnerMom: Sore, swollen feet:
pages.content:
I thought I would get morning sickness, weird food cravings and swollen breasts during pregnancy. I thought I would feel loving and emotional. Or different in some way. But I feel totally normal!

Honestly I can understand those girls who say that they didn’t even know they were pregnant! If I hadn’t missed a period and gone to the clinic for a test I would never have known. No morning sickness. No cravings. I feel nothing. My life just goes on as always.

I can’t stand garlic though… we actually have to throw out the garlic in the house because the smell is too much for me. I eat more. My mother complains because she isn’t used to me eating so much (but I think she’d probably complain if I didn’t eat enough!)

So she fusses over me and I enjoy it. In fact I feel even better than I usually do!

My allergies seem to have disappeared – probably because of the good food I am eating. I am still active. My friends and family are shocked that I am still doing errands up to such a late date. But life continues doesn’t it? I haven’t gained too much weight and I only started showing late into my 5th month.

My worst symptom is the swollen feet! The baby is sitting more on my left side so my left foot has swollen up to almost double its size. It looks scary and ugly. Closed shoes are not an option and I only have one pair of sandals that I can wear. Or my house slippers!

I worry my feet will permanently grow and then what kind of ladies’ shoes will I find in such a big size? My Aunty from the village insisted that we consult a seer, but my doctor assured me that it was normal.

**MAMA HELP: Swollen feet (edema) during pregnancy can get worse as your due date nears. It may not be comfortable, but it’s harmless and normal. It should ease up overnight. If it doesn’t, or if your hands or face become puffy, visit your clinic for a check-up.**

pages.subtitle: A tiny drumbeat in your womb
pages.description: A tiny drumbeat in your womb
pages.title: Month 3
pages.content:
Your baby is still small enough to fit into the palm of your hand. She is growing hair on her head and fine, soft hair all over her body. On the tips of her fingers she is developing tiny fingerprints.

Inside your womb, your baby floats safely in fluid. She is protected from bumps and kept warm by the fluid. Babies can get hiccups. This feels like a regular drum beat in your womb, which can last a few minutes.

You may be feeling less nauseous now and find you are suddenly hungry. Eat well. Remember to eat a variety of foods each day. Eat an extra handful of food at each meal. Make sure your food is safe and fresh, not stale or old.

You will also gradually feel less tired and have more energy. The afterbirth or placenta has developed inside your womb now and this supports your baby. It will be delivered just after your baby is born.

You may find that your clothes feel a bit tighter around your waist and breasts. Your pregnancy will show soon, as a small bump low down on your tummy.

Being pregnant makes you less resistant to germs, so you may get more coughs and colds. Wash your hands with soap and clean, safe water regularly. It’s the best way to get rid of germs.

pages.subtitle: Why is my stomach still so big?
pages.description: Why is my stomach still so big?
pages.title: BigMAMA: My baby’s out!
pages.content:
I thought that once I delivered my baby, my tummy would go back to normal. But I gave birth 6 weeks ago and I still look pregnant! I cannot fit into any of my clothes and I am still wearing my pregnancy pants.

I tried to squeeze myself into a pair of pre-pregnancy pants 2 days after the birth. I was amazed that I could not get them higher than my knees! Yesterday I tried again.

I just couldn’t wait to get back into normal clothes. I tucked handfuls of fat into the waistband. I finally got the button closed.

“Come look!” I called to my husband. “I can fit back into my clothes!”

The look of surprise on his face said it all. It was not good. “Wear them round the house until you are comfortable going out in public in them,” he suggested.

I took them off 10 minutes later. But only because they were too tight to sit down in. Now I am really feeling worried. Will this stomach ever go down?

I spoke to some friends about it and one suggested I tie tight fabric around my belly day and night to keep it in. But this didn’t sound very healthy!

- “Give yourself time,” my other friends tell me. “The baby weight will come off in time.”

- “How much time?” I ask.

- “A year,” they promise.

I can’t believe it. A 40-week pregnancy and now I still look pregnant!

**MAMA HELP: It is normal for a healthy pregnant woman to put on 10 -14kgs / 20 – 30 lbs by the end of your term. The extra weight will give you a cushion for the months when you breastfeed your baby. You can work at losing the weight over time to get your shape back.**

pages.subtitle: Help your baby to breastfeed
pages.description: Here’s how to know she’s feeding well
pages.title: Help your baby to breastfeed
pages.content:
You and your baby learn how to breastfeed together. Sit comfortably with 1 or 2 pillows to support you. Your baby needs to be at the same level as your breast.

Turn your baby to face you, so her belly is against your chest. She may turn her head from side to side, making small sucking noises. This means she is ready to feed and is looking for your breast.

Stroke her cheek with your nipple. She will turn towards it and open her mouth wide. As she opens her mouth, bring her straight towards your breast. She needs some of the brown area around the nipple in her mouth so she can get your milk. She will use her tongue under your breast to get the milk, so she needs a good mouthful of breast.

Here are 3 ways to know your baby is feeding well:

Look! Does she have plenty of the dark area around your nipple in her mouth? Can you see her jaw moving up and down as she squeezes milk from your breast?

Listen! Can you hear her gulping milk, with short rests between swallows?

Feel! Feeding should not hurt! If your nipples are sore, she is not on your breast properly. Break the suction by putting your little finger in her mouth. Wait until her mouth is wide open and then bring her to the breast again. Get your baby checked by the health worker if she is not feeding well.

Remember, girls need breastmilk the same as boys do.

pages.subtitle: Why do I need minerals?
pages.description: Minerals help grow a healthy baby
pages.title: Why do I need to eat minerals?
pages.content:
Minerals help you to stay healthy and grow a healthy baby. If you eat foods from these 4 main food groups you will get the minerals you need.

- Fruit and vegetables. Eating lots of different coloured fruit and vegetables will give you lots of goodness.

- Starchy, filling foods, such as ugali, rice, chapati, bananas, potatoes, cassava. Base your meals around starchy foods. This will give you plenty of energy.

- Protein-rich foods, such as eggs, fish, chicken and meat. These foods are also good sources of iron. They will help you to stay strong.

- Calcium-rich foods such as milk and green leafy vegetables.

Adding iodised salt to your food will give you iodine. You need plenty of iodine in your diet to help your baby's brain to develop. Try to have some every day. If salt is iodised, it will say this on the packet.

By eating a range of these foods you will be able to stay fit and strong, as well as grow a healthy baby.

pages.subtitle: Ni nini kilitendeka katika maisha yangu?
pages.description: Ni nini kilitendeka katika maisha yangu?
pages.title: Mama wa mara ya kwanza: Mtoto wangu mchanga ananifanyisha kazi nyingi!
pages.content:
Nilishtuka kufahamu muda unaohitajika ili kutunza mtoto mchanga!

Kabla ya msichana wangu kuzaliwa, nilifikiri kuwa watoto wachanga walilala muda wote. Niliwaza: Kwani ni jambo kubwa, kwa nini wanawake hunung’unika kuwa na mtoto mdogo zaidi?

Hata hivyo, mtoto wangu angeamka na kulia punde tu nilipoanza kujaribu kufanya kazi yoyote. Hii ilinilazimu kumlisha wakati huo. Kwa kawaida ilinichukua takribani saa moja kuhakikisha ameteuka na kumbadilisha nepi na kumlaza tena. Singeweza kufanya jambo lolote!

Hapo mwanzoni, aliamka mara 2 au 3 wakati wa usiku. Ilinichukua muda kidogo kuzoea kuamka kila mara. Hatimaye, nilianza kulala kidogo sana kwani nilikuwa nikisikiliza kelele za mtoto wangu. Alilala karibu na kitanda chetu kwenye sanduku kubwa.

Hata hivyo, kutolala wakati wa usiku kuliniathiri. Nilikuwa mchovu na mwenye machozi wakati wote. Mtoto wangu alipofikisha miezi 6, alikuwa akiamka kula mara chache wakati wa usiku. Hata hivyo, kwa wakati huo, alikuwa akilala kando yangu kitandani hivi kwamba ningepinduka tu na kumpa titi. Kisha tunalala tena.

Wakati wa mchana, mtoto wangu alikuwa macho na hakulala. Nilikuwa na wakati mdogo zaidi wa kufanya kazi za nyumbani kwani alitaka nimmakinikie kila wakati.

Rafiki yangu mmoja alinipa ushauri mzuri. Aliniambia nichukue muda kumlisha mtoto wangu vyema wakati wa mchana ili asiwe na njaa wakati wa usiku. Kwa njia hiyo, mtoto hatakuwa akiniamsha kula wakati wote. Pia aliniambia kuwa kufikia miezi 6, watoto huwa tayari kulala hadi asubuhi.

Nilifurahi sana kusikia hivyo. Ninatazamia kupata usingizi wangu tena!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Watoto hupenda utaratibu. Hii huwatayarisha kwa yote wanayotarajia katika siku yao. Jaribu kutengeneza utaratibu mpole wa kila siku ambapo unafanya mambo sawa kwa karibu wakati sawa kila siku. Kuna uwezekano kwamba mtoto wako atakula na kulala bora zaidi.**

pages.subtitle: Nakondeana
pages.title: Mwanamke mwenye shughuli nyingi: Nimekonda sana baada ya mtoto
pages.content:
Wakati wote nimekuwa mwembamba. Lakini katika mwaka baada ya kuzaa, watu waliniambia kuwa nilifanana na kiunzi cha mifupa kinachotembea.

Juma baada ya kuzaa nilikuwa nisharejelea nguo zangu za awali. Lakini upotezaji wa uzani haukukoma hapo. Mtoto wako alionekana aliyejishikiza kwenye titi langu kila wakati. Na alivyonyonya, niliendelea kukonda.

Nilikuwa nimenyonyesha kwa miezi 9 nilipojiona kwenye kioo cha dirisha la duka mjini. Nilishangaa: Nilikuwa ngozi na mifupa tu. Wengine walikuwa wakinikodolea macho na kuuliza ikiwa nilikuwa mgonjwa. Kwa hivyo niliamua kumuona daktari.

Aliniambia kuwa mwili wangu ulikuwa umekoma kufyonza virutubishi na kuwa itachukua muda kurekebika. Niliwekwa kwenye mpango wa kula vyakula viletavyo afya. Nilipaswa kula vyakula vingi viletavyo nguvu na vyakula visivyotiwa chumvi wala kugandishwa ili kupata vitamin.

Daktari aliniambia pia kuanza kumpa mtoto wangu vyakula vya mango. Alinionyesha jinsi ya kufanya hivi.

Sasa kwa kuwa nimeanza kuongeza nguvu, nahisi vyema sana. Sijaongeza uzani wowote, lakini pia sijapoteza wowote.

Kwa muda mrefu, wazo la ujauzito mwingine lilitia hofu. Sikufikiri mwili wangu ungeweza. Lakini nimeanza kufikiria kuwa naweza kupata tena. Wakati huu, ningekula kwa makini na kuhakikisha kuweka vyakula vizuri kwenye mwili wangu. Sasa najua kuwa sharti nijitunze ndiposa niweze kuitunza familia yangu.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Ikiwa hauna hakika kuwa unaweza kudumisha lishe bora kivyako, muulize mhudumu wako wa afya kwa usaidizi. Utahitaji kula vyakula vilivyo na mafuta mazuri, vitamini na madini. Hivi ni muhimu kwa mama mwenye afya na mtoto mwenye afya.**

pages.subtitle: Month4 Swa Ke Pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 4
pages.content:
Mtoto wako sasa ana ukubwa kama wa mkono wako. Anakua, na anaendelea kukuza hisia zake zote. Atakapozaliwa ataweza kuona, kuonja, kunusa na kusikia.

Mduara wa ngozi nyeusi zaidi kwenye chuchu zako utakuwa unakuwa mkubwa zaidi matiti yako yanavyozidi kuwa makubwa. Eneo hili jeusi humsaidia mtoto wako kupata titi mara baada ya kuzaliwa na humwezesha kushikilia titi na kunyonya. Unaweza kuona matiti yako yanakua haraka zaidi na kuhisi mazito zaidi.

Ngozi yako inaweza pia ikawa inabadilika. Madoadoa meusi ya ngozi yanaweza kutokea usoni mwako. Au unaweza kupata mstari mweusi unaoshuka kwenye tumbo lako. Mambo haya yanaweza kuzidishwa kwa kukaa kwenye jua, kwa hivyo funika ngozi na kichwa chako, au kaa kivulini. Yatafifia baada ya mtoto wako kuzaliwa.

Ujauzito hulegeza viungo mwilini mwako. Kwa hivyo unaweza kuhisi unapata maumivu unapobeba kitu kizito. Kuwa muangalifu unapoinua vitu. Ukienda madukani gawanya vitu vizito viwe mizigo midogomidogo. Unaweza pia ukahitaji kupumzika mara nyingi zaidi. Jitahidi kupumzika kila siku wakati wa mchana na uende kulala mapema usiku ikiwa unahisi uchovu. Kukuza mtoto ni kazi ngumu!

pages.subtitle: Najihisi mwenye wazimu kiasi!
pages.title: Mama wa wanne: Homoni za kutisha za ujauzito
pages.content:
Nimegudua jambo kujihusu – Si rahisi kwangu kuishi na wanaume ninapokuwa mjamzito. Nilipokuwa na mimba ya mtoto wangu wa kwanza, nakumbuka nikishangaa jinsi ambavyo ningemkasirikia mume wangu. Tulikuwa na vita vya kutisha! Lakini sasa nina uhakika kuwa ilikuwa tu homoni za ujauzito. Kwa bahati, mtoto wangu msichana alipozaliwa kila kitu kilibadilika na kuwa sawa. Lakini hali hii haikuwa nzuri sana kwa ndoa yangu.

Sasa, miaka kumi baadaye, nikawa na mimba ya pacha. Na hizo homoni zisizo za kawaida zikaanza kuchezea hisia zangu tena! Kumekuwa na siku chache ambapo kwa hakika na kweli nilikasirika. Lakini wakati huu si mume wangu aliyeathiriwa na hisia zangu tu.

Hivi karibuni, nilitembea kwenye barabara iliyokuwa na vumbi nikilia huku nimeyakodoa macho kwa hasira kuhusu kitu kidogo sana hata siwezi nikakumbuka kilikuwa nini. Juma lililopita, nilinuna mwenyewe chumbani tulipotembelea familia ya mume wangu kwa mlo mkuu. Nilipotoka, nilipata kuwa mume wangu alikuwa ameufuata ushauri wangu na kuniacha akaenda nyumbani!

Pia niliwapigia kelele marafiki waliokuwa wakiishi nasi nyumbani kwetu niliporudi nyumbani kutoka kazini na kupata vyombo havijaoshwa! Kisha kuna siku ambapo nilibamiza mlango wetu wa mbele mbele ya mtu aliyekuwa akijaribu kuniuzia mboga.

Hata nilianza kulia mtu aliponiambia jambo la huruma na kunisaidia kuingia katika behewa la gari moshi!

Nashukuru niko karibu kuzaa... Natumai kuwa nitasamehewa kwa kubadilikabadilika kwa hisia zangu kabla ya mtoto kuzaliwa.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Ni kawaida kuwa na kubadilikabadilika kwa hisia wakati wa ujauzito. Hii kwa upande mmoja husababishwa na mabadiliko unayokumbana nayo katika maisha yako. Pia kwa upande mwingine inaweza kusababishwa na kuongezeka kwa viwango vya homoni mwilini mwako. Hii inaweza kuathiri hisia zako, na kukufanya kuhisi kulia au kukasirika haraka.**

pages.subtitle: HIV: how do I protect him?
pages.title: HIV: how do I protect him?
pages.content:
If you are living with HIV there is a lot you can do to protect your baby from getting HIV.

During pregnancy, take your antiretrovirals (ARVs) and go to the clinic for regular check-ups.

When labour starts, go straight to the health facility. You need extra care in early labour to prevent the HIV virus being passed to your baby.

When your baby is here, it is really good for him if you breastfeed and, at the same time, you both take ARVs. When you take your ARVS, it will make your milk safe for your baby.

Your baby needs a daily dose of ARV syrup for 4 to 6 weeks after the birth, to protect him from HIV. Your baby will need a blood test at the clinic at around 6 weeks to check if the HIV virus has passed to him.

Make sure you touch your baby with clean hands. Cover all cuts and wounds with a bandage until they heal.

HIV is a long-term illness. With the right medicines, you can manage and control it.

Breastmilk is all your baby needs for his first six months. Do not give him any other milk because this makes it more likely that your baby will get HIV.

pages.subtitle: What is high blood pressure?
pages.description: It can harm your baby inside you
pages.title: What is high blood pressure?
pages.content:
High blood pressure can mean that your baby does not get all the food and oxygen he needs, so he may be born very small and weak. It can also make you very ill, and cause fits, especially in later pregnancy.

You may not feel if you have high blood pressure, so it is important to see a health worker to check your blood pressure regularly while you are pregnant.

A wide cuff will be put around your arm to measure your blood pressure. It will not hurt but it feels tight for a few moments. Your health worker will write the results down so that you have a record of your blood pressure at each visit. She will compare the measurements at each visit so she can spot any problems.

You are more likely to get high blood pressure if you are very overweight. Do not add salt to food. If you already have high blood pressure, this will make it worse.

There are medicines to control high blood pressure. See a health worker regularly, so any problems can be found early and you can get the right medicine.

pages.subtitle: How to have a safe birth
pages.title: How to have a safe birth
pages.content:
It is safest, and recommended, to give birth in a health facility, where there is help if there are problems.

If you cannot have your baby at a health facility, here is how to have a safe birth.

- Plan to have a skilled birth attendant with you. She will help you to give birth safely and she will do what is necessary if there is a problem.

- Make sure you have her phone number so you can call her in an emergency.

- Have ambulance and taxi numbers ready and make sure you have enough airtime on your phone.

- Make sure your family knows how to contact the birth attendant when it is time.

- Make sure you have a birth kit ready. Your birth attendant may bring a birth kit. It will contain a plastic sheet, gloves, clean string and tools for cutting your baby's cord. All these items are important for a clean, safe birth.

If you cannot get a birth kit, find a clean sheet to have your baby on and 2 cloths, one to dry your baby and one to wrap her in. Have 2 pieces of string, a clean, sharp knife or a clean pair of scissors ready. Your attendant must wash her hands and you must wash between your legs. Get plenty of clean, boiled water and soap ready.

pages.subtitle: How to cut your baby's cord
pages.title: How to cut your baby’s cord
pages.content:
When your baby is born, he is attached to you by a cord, which needs to be cut. If you give birth at a health facility, the cord will be cut in a hygienic way that does not cause infections.

If you cannot have your baby in a health facility, you must plan how to take care of the baby’s cord.

Talk to the person who is helping you to give birth, so they know what to do when the time comes.

The birth attendant should have a birth kit ready. If you do not have a birth kit, then you will need a clean sheet to have your baby on, 2 pieces of clean string and 2 cloths: one to dry your baby and one to wrap her in, and a clean, sharp knife or a clean pair of scissors.

Boil the knife for 10 minutes and the string for 3 minutes to clean them, just before you use them.

Have clean, safe water and soap ready, so the birth attendant can wash her hands very carefully before she cuts the cord.

Wait until the cord stops pulsing. Then, tie the 2 pieces of string round the cord. One tie should be about the length of your hand away from your baby's tummy. The other, about 3 fingers away from the first tie. Cut the cord in between the 2 ties.

Keep your baby's cord stump clean and dry until it drops off.

pages.subtitle: Is your house smoky?
pages.title: Is your house smoky?
pages.content:
Breathing in smoke is harmful for you and your baby.

If your house is smoky, let in as much fresh air as possible. Open lots of windows and doors. This will help. Explain to other people what effect their smoking will have on your baby growing inside you.

Stay away from smoke. Smoke can make you weak and sick. Open the windows, if your house gets too smoky from cooking. If you live in a cold area where opening doors and windows is not possible, try to stay in the least smoky part of the house.

Ask family and friends to smoke outside.

You could also try some of these ideas:

- Move your stove outside if you can, so less smoke goes in the house

- Use LPG, electricity or a kerosene cooker if possible

- Make your stove about waist height so you do not have to lean over the fire and breathe in smoke while cooking

- Using a lid will keep the heat inside the pot, and you can reduce cooking time, so you will breathe in less smoke

- Soak food before cooking to reduce cooking time

- Mopping the floor can reduce the amount of dust you breathe in.

pages.subtitle: What if I'm living with HIV?
pages.description: You can protect your baby from HIV
pages.title: What if I am living with HIV?
pages.content:
If you are living with HIV, you are not alone; lots of pregnant women are living with HIV. But you can prevent it being passed to your baby with the right care during pregnancy.

If you have not been tested for HIV yet, you may be able to get tested at a health facility. Only you will know the results, but you could take a friend with you for support.

If your first HIV test was negative you will be offered another test later in pregnancy. Please take it if you can. You can avoid passing HIV to your baby with the right care.

It can be scary to find out you have HIV. Give yourself time to get used to it. No one can see it and lots of pregnant women are living with it. Medicine will help to prevent transmission of HIV to your baby. Some health facilities offer this medicine free. This medicine is offered in government and faith-based health facilities.

You can lead a normal life if you take all your medicines and look after yourself.

You will need medicines called antiretrovirals (ARVs). ARVs help you live a healthy life. ARVs also help to make sure that HIV does not spread to your baby.

You will be welcome at the antenatal clinic. Your health worker will do tests to make sure you do not have any infections that will damage your health or the health of the baby growing inside you.

You may also be given medication so that you do not get malaria and many other infections.
