Your baby will be given a special test to check that he did not get with HIV while you were pregnant and giving birth.

If you are living with HIV, then it is important to give birth in a health facility because staff know how to protect your baby from getting HIV during the birth.

Do not give birth at a traditional birth attendant’s home, because they often do not know how to protect you, your baby and themselves from HIV.

pages.subtitle: Get ready to be a Mom!
pages.description: Get ready to be a Mom!
pages.title: Month 9
pages.content:
Your baby can be born any day now! Inside your womb he is shedding the fine hair he grew in the middle of pregnancy. He is also losing the waxy coating on his skin which protected him while he was floating in the fluid inside your womb.

Your baby is developing layers of fat under his skin, which will help keep him warm when he is born. Newborn babies need to be kept warm. The best way to do this is to hold him close to your chest inside your clothes.

You may wonder how you will know when labour starts. There are three ways that labour may begin.

1. You may notice a bloodstained discharge on your underwear. This is a

sign that labour may begin in the next day or two.

2. You may have contractions that feel like period pains. They get stronger, regular and more painful as labour progresses.

3. You may have a gush or trickle of water. If this happens you should go straight to the health facility.

Make sure you know how to get to the health facility before labour starts. You need a midwife, nurse or doctor to care for you if you are in labour. Check that you have credit on your phone and money for a bus or taxi.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby stand up?
pages.description: When he is about 11 months old
pages.title: When will my baby stand up?
pages.content:
Most babies first try to stand up between 8 and 10 months. Your baby may pull himself up to a standing position, using your hands, or the wall, or a piece of furniture.

At first, your baby needs to hold on to you or a solid piece of furniture. By 11 months, he may be able to stand without you holding him. Give him lots of praise and cuddles when he does this.

As your baby becomes confident, he starts to move around, still holding on to furniture. When he can do this, he will soon be walking!

Your baby may stand up easily, but he might find it hard to sit back down again! You can help your baby learn to move from standing to sitting down. Instead of picking him up and sitting him down again, show your baby how to bend his knees. Then encourage him to try it! It may take a few days or weeks before he learns how to bend his knees and sit down.

Stay with your baby when he is moving around, then, if he does fall, you can make sure that he does not get hurt. It also means that when he takes his first step on his own, you will not miss it!

All babies develop differently, some more quickly than others. If you are worried about how your baby is developing, talk to a health worker.

pages.subtitle: Does she have diarrhoea?
pages.description: Check for loose stools, fever and weight loss
pages.title: Does she have diarrhoea?
pages.content:
Your baby may have diarrhoea if:

- She passes smelly, watery, stools streaked with sticky smelly fluid, called mucus.

- She passes these stools frequently.

- She has a fever.

- She appears to be losing weight.

Your baby can get diarrhoea if she eats rotten food or drinks dirty water.

Newborns often have a lot of bowel movements, sometimes up to 5 times a day in the first month, but this is unlikely to be diarrhoea.

Sometimes babies pass stools after every breastfeeding session. This is because, as her stomach fills up with milk, her bowels get stimulated.

Breastfed babies usually have yellowish stools which smell sweet, and they tend to be soft. After they reach 1 month old, most babies have 1 or 2 bowel movements a day.

Your baby’s stools may change at 6 months when she starts solid food. But bowel movements will settle down once your baby gets used to her new food.

So, notice your baby's stools. If your baby passes smelly, watery and mucus-streaked stools more often, has a fever or seems to be losing weight, then your baby probably has diarrhoea. Take her to a health worker.

pages.subtitle: 1monthold Swa Ke baby
pages.description: Mama! Tazama ndani ya macho ya mtoto wako.
pages.title: Umri wa mwezi 1
pages.content:
Kwa sasa, mtoto wako ataanza kuangalia kitu kwa macho yote mawili. Atatazama ukisogeza kitu cha kuchezea mbele yake. Lakini, kikitoweka, mtoto wako atasahau kama kilikuwepo!

Kumbukumbu ya mtoto wako inaendelea kuimarika wakati wote. Atasahau kitu hicho cha kuchezea, lakini anajua sauti yako kila wakati, na anaikumbuka kutoka wakati alipokuwa tumboni mwako.

Kumwogesha mtoto wako kunaweza kuwa wakati wa furaha kwenu nyote wawili. Tumia taulo safi na umwogeshe kwa maji mengi yaliyo safi na salama. Hakikisha maji hayo yana joto lakini si ya moto. Watoto wengi watatulia na kufurahia maji. Yanaweza hata kumkumbusha wakati alipokuwa tumboni mwako. Kamwe usimwache mtoto pekee yake akiwa ndani ya maji.

Ni vizuri kumwangalia mtoto wako usoni na kuangaliana macho kwa macho. Hili humsaidia kuanza kujifunza stadi za kijamii. Hivi karibuni, mtoto wako atatambua sura yako. Anaweza kukupendelea wewe zaidi ya watu wengine. Anaweza kutoa kelele za mtoto na kurusha mateke kwa furaha anapokuona. Utaona tabasamu yake ya kwanza hivi karibuni!

Mtoto wako pia anatambua mazingira yake. Kelele zitaanza kumvutia, na ataanza kupenda vitu vyenye rangi.

Kufikia sasa, mtoto wako huenda akaweza kuinua kichwa na kifua chake wakati amelala kifudifudi. Kujifunza jinsi ya kudhibiti kichwa chake ni hatua muhimu kwake.

Mtoto wako pia anakusikiliza zaidi kila siku. Ukiongea, anaweza kuacha alichokuwa akifanya ili akusikilize. Endelea kumzungumzia naye, ukirudia kelele zake. Kuzungumza na mtoto wako kutamtuliza na kumtia moyo kukuzungumzia.

pages.subtitle: What if my baby is early?
pages.description: He will need extra care at birth
pages.title: What if my baby comes early?
pages.content:
Most babies are born in month 9. But sometimes a baby comes early. If you go into labour early, you must to go to a health facility. Your baby will need extra care at the birth. If your baby is small and weak you may have to stay at the health facility until he gets stronger.

Giving your baby breastmilk is one of the best things you can do to build up his health. The first milk you make is very thick, creamy and full of goodness. Give your baby this precious gift.

A baby who is born early may not be strong enough to feed at your breast. Feed him by squeezing out your milk into a clean cup. Sterilise the cup, wash it well and rinse with boiling water to kill any germs before you start squeezing out your breastmilk.

Use a cup rather than a bottle, because a cup is easier to keep clean and the risk of infection will be less.

Hold your baby on your lap. Gently tilt the cup so it touches his lower lip and a little milk enters his mouth. He will soon learn to start lapping the milk.

Your baby will also need lots of warmth. Keep him firmly strapped between your bare breasts to give him warmth from your body.

Wearing a sling helps to make sure he is securely placed. This will comfort him, help you both bond, and will also help him to develop. It will also help you to produce breastmilk.

pages.subtitle: How to care for your baby's cord
pages.description: Keep the cord stump clean and dry
pages.title: How to take care of your baby’s cord
pages.content:
Keep your baby's cord stump clean and dry until it drops off. Do not put anything on it. The cord will heal by itself and will drop off in about a week. It will look quite black and odd but that is part of the healing.

If the cord stump is red, bleeding or smelly, take your baby to a health worker.

If your baby’s cord stump gets dirty, it could become infected. Infections are very dangerous to young babies. Keep the cord stump clean and dry.

Your family may suggest that you put other substances on the stump to help it heal. Do not let them do this. It is dangerous. Explain that keeping it clean and dry is safest for your baby.

After washing your baby, simply pat the cord area dry with a clean towel. If you are in a health facility, they may give you something to clean the cord with.

The cord will heal gradually and drop off in a few days. Do not pull on it. Let it fall off naturally.

If the cord stump is red, sore, and smelly or oozes pus, or your baby gets a fever, there is an infection. Show your baby to the health worker as soon as you can.

The best thing you can do for your baby is to keep the cord stump clean and dry.

pages.subtitle: Danger signs at the birth
pages.title: Danger signs at the birth
pages.content:
If you notice any of these things happening, go to a health worker or health facility as soon as you can.

**You:**

- If your waters have broken but you are not in labour after 6 hours

- Your contractions are lasting for over 12 hours, but the baby has not come yet

- You are bleeding heavily and the blood soaks more than 2 to 3 pads in 15 minutes

- Your placenta has not come out, and it is 1 hour after the birth of your baby

**Your baby:**

- You notice that your baby does not cry at birth, or has difficulty breathing

- You notice that your baby cannot breastfeed

- You notice that your baby has a fever, or feels cold

- Your baby is very small (less than 1500 grams or born earlier than 32 weeks)

- Your baby has fits

pages.subtitle: Talk to your baby to help her learn
pages.description: Talk to your baby to help her learn
pages.title: 2 months old
pages.content:
Your baby is much stronger now. She might be able to hold up her head for a few seconds.

She can now focus better with her eyes and her vision is improving. You might see your baby looking at her own hands. She is starting to understand that it is her hand and she can use it. Soon she will reach out to grasp things. She also listens better, and understands where sounds come from. You may see her turn her head toward sounds.

About now, you will notice your baby stays awake longer in the daytime, and has definite times when she wants to play. She is beginning to know night from day.

Soon, she will start stretching her arms and legs. Give your baby enough space to stretch. Lay a blanket on the floor and let her move around on it. If she is lying on her belly, she may start to push with her legs. This helps to strengthen her growing muscles.

You may think your baby is too young to sing or talk to, but it is a good idea if you do. Hearing you sing or talk to her will help her learn to talk.

If she looks the other way or loses interest while you are singing or talking to her, just try something else or give her time to rest.

pages.subtitle: Hivi ndivyo inavyohisi...
pages.title: MAMA anayejivunia: Wasiwasi kuhusi leba?
pages.content:
Swali kuu nililokuwa nalo wakati wa uajuzito ni hili: Leba yangu itakuaje? Mikazo huhisi vipi? Niliuliza marafiki ambao wamezaa. Mara nyingi, jibu nililopata ni kuwa mkazo huwa kama spazimu ya hedhi.

Wacha nikwambie ilivyohisi kwangu…

Mwanzoni mwa leba ilihisi kama spazimu kali ya hedhi. Nilikosa utulivu, nilihisi uchungu – lakini ya kudhibiti. Nilihisi maumivu kidogo chini ya fumbatio langu, kama tu spazimu. Hii ilidumu kwa saa 2-3.

Kisha maumivu yalizidi, leba yangu ilipoendelea kukua. Sikuhisi kama maumivu ya muda tena. Yaliendelea kuwa makali na yenye nguvu. Kwa bahati nzuri, kulikuwa na kuacha kwa uchungu kwa mapumziko. Maumivu yatadumu kwa sekunde chache na kupotea kabisa. Bado niliweza kufanya kazi wakati maumivu yametulia. Niliweza kuongea na mume na mkunga wangu. Nilihisi kuwa ningeweza kustahimili yaliyokuwa yanaendelea mwilini mwangu.

Kisha maumivu yakazidi. Hii ilikuwa awamu ya mwisho niliyokuwa nimejifunza. Mapumziko kati ya mikazo yalikuwa mafupi. Maumivu yalikuwa makali; siwezi kudanganya. Ilikuwa vigumu kupata hali tulivu. Ilinibidi nipitie kila mkazo tu.

Kulikuwa na nyakati kukaribia mwisho ambazo zilikuwa za kuogofya. Nilihisi nimechoka na nikataka kukomesha. Lakini wahudumu wa afya walinishauri hadi mwisho. Waliniambia nishughulikie kila mkazo kwa wakati mmoja... Mmoja baada ya mwingine. Na nilipoanza kusukuma uchungu ulipungua na kuwa kidogo. Nilijua kuwa ni lazima nisukume mtoto nje! Na nilifanya hivyo.

Sitaki kuogofya mtu yeyote ambaye yuko karibu kujifungua. Nataka kukutayarisha tu kwa tukio zuri la maisha yako. Leba inachangamoto. Lakini ikiwa unajua unachotarajia, si la kushtua sana.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Hakikisha kuwa uko tayari kuzaa. Panga mipango ya kufikia kliniki kwa wakati ufaao. Uliza marafiki kuhusu leba na uwe na maswala yake. Unavyozidi kufahamu kuhusu leba ndivyo unavyokuwa na uwezo wa kuwa na leba na kuzaa kulikotulia na kuzuri.**

pages.subtitle: Why am I so tired?
pages.title: Why am I so tired?
pages.content:
Yes, it is normal to be tired - you are not alone! Many mothers feel the same. Being pregnant puts a strain on your whole body. This can make you very tired. Even if you like to stay up late, you might struggle to stay awake past the early evening now.

In the early stages of pregnancy, you may feel constantly tired. Your body is using a lot of energy and food to grow your tiny baby. By 3 months you will feel less tired.

Your hormone levels and need for energy are also changing fast. Your blood sugar and blood pressure tend to be lower too. This all adds to tiredness.

Having low iron levels can also make you feel tired. Try to take a daily iron tablet. This will stop you getting anaemic, when you do not have enough iron in your blood. If your iron levels are very low, you will feel even more tired and lacking in energy.

pages.subtitle: Month5 Swa Ke pregnancy
pages.description: Je, unaweza kuhisi mtoto wako akisogea?
pages.title: Mwezi wa 5
pages.content:
Sasa mtoto wako tumboni mwako anakaa kama mtoto mchanga mara tu baada ya kuzaliwa. Macho, nyusi na kope zimekua na meno yake yanakua chini ya fizi zake. Vionjio kwenye ulimi wake vinaendelea kukua. Ataweza kuonja maziwa yako toka atakaponyonya kwa mara ya kwanza.

Ana ute mweupe unaofunika ngozi yake. Huu hulinda ngozi ya mtoto wako na husaidia wakati wa kujifungua.

Karibu wakati huu, unaweza kuanza kuhisi kusogea kwa mtoto wako. Utahisi kama viputo vidogodogo ndani yako. Mwanzoni, unaweza usiwe na uhakika ni nini hasa. Kwa utaratibu kusogea huko kunakuwa kwa nguvu zaidi kwa hiyo unakuwa na uhakika kwamba ni mtoto wako anayepiga mateke. Ni wakati wa kusisimua!

Unaweza pia kuanza kuhisi kupumua kwa shida na huenda ukajihisi uzembeuzembe. Hii ni kwa sababu umebeba uzito zaidi na mimba yako inaathiri hali yako ya kuwa sawa.

Unaweza ukawa na mvujo mkubwa zaidi na kutaka kwenda haja ndogo mara nyingi zaidi.

Ukigundua uvujaji damu wakati unapopiga mswaki meno yako, ni kwa sababu homoni zako za ujauzito zinafanya fizi zako kuvimba na kuuma, hali ambayo inaweza kusababisha uvujaji damu. Piga mswaki kila siku, lakini kwa ungwana.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby smile?
pages.title: When will my baby smile?
pages.content:
Many babies make their first smile when they are between 6 and 8 weeks old. But your baby may smile before or after this time.

If you want to encourage your baby to smile, find a time when she is calm and alert. Find a moment when your baby looks at you and examines your face.

Hold your baby opposite you and talk to her, with your faces close. If your baby does not like this, try holding her a little further away.

She may stare at you for a long time first, so keep talking to her quietly and you may be rewarded with that first grin!

After she has learnt to smile, your baby will soon be able to laugh!

Most babies start to laugh when they are between 2 and 4 months old. Try making silly faces and sounds, or tickling her.

pages.title: About
pages.content:
to use mobile technologies to improve the health and lives of mothers in

developing nations. This site is dedicated to MAMA’s activities in South

Africa. MAMA is making a three-year, $10 million investment to create and

strengthen programmes in three countries – Bangladesh, India and South Africa

– and to enhance global capability of new and existing mobile health

information programmes for moms in those countries and beyond. MAMA is a

partnership between the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID),

Johnson & Johnson, the United Nations Foundation, and BabyCenter and operates

through a secretariat hosted by the mHealth Alliance. It was launched on

Mother’s Day 2011 by U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. MAMA’s efforts

align with the UN Secretary-General’s Every Woman Every Child campaign and

efforts to achieve Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 4 and 5. To this end,

MAMA engages an innovative global community to deliver vital health

information to new and expectant mothers through mobile phones. **How to use

MAMA** Mothers are invited to register for the service by indicating their

expected due-date, or the birthday of their recently-born child, and receive

weekly health messages and reminders during the pregnancy and up to the

child’s first birthday. Timed messages include tips on everything from proper

nutrition, how to keep the baby warm after birth, and breastfeeding. Improving

the health and status of mothers acts as a positive multiplier. When mothers

succeed, they lift themselves out of poverty, and they lift their families and

their communities along with them. Mobile phones are one of the innovative

tools they can use. MAMA is a single resource for mothers to find life-saving

information on maternal and infant health, up-to-date support on HIV+

pregnancies and vital Help numbers. **Content Credits** Pages have been

donated for publication on this mobisite by BabyCenter, a leading maternal and

infant health resource. Images ©Thinkstock.
pages.intro_text: The Mobile Alliance for Maternal Action (MAMA) is a global movement that seeks

pages.subtitle: Warning signs
pages.title: Warning signs
pages.content:
Your body changes in many ways in pregnancy, and it is normal to wonder if you need to worry about any of these changes.

**This is normal** Are you tired one minute, fine the next, feeling nauseous in the mornings, getting indigestion, having to pass urine more often? Is your skin changing? Feeling breathless? Welcome to pregnancy!

**These are warning signs** See a health worker if you have any of these feelings:

- Pain in your belly

- A fever

- Blurred vision and you are seeing spots in front of your eyes

- Fluid leaking from your vagina

- Pain when passing urine

- If you are past 5 months in your pregnancy, and your baby has stopped kicking or is kicking much less

- If you have heavy bleeding or bleeding with pain.

pages.subtitle: Mbona tumbo langu bado ni kubwa sana?
pages.description: Mbona tumbo langu bado ni kubwa sana?
pages.title: MAMA Mkubwa: Mtoto wangu ametoka!
pages.content:
Nilifikiri kuwa baada ya kujifungua mtoto wangu, tumbo langu litarejelea hali ya kawaida. Lakini nilizaa majuma 6 yaliyopita lakini bado naonekana mwenye ujauzito! Siwezi kutoshea kwenye nguo zangu na badi vavalia suruali zangu za ujauzito.

Nilijaribu kujipenyeza kwenye nilizokuwa nikitumia kabla ya ujauzito siku 2 baada ya kuzaa. Nilishangaa kuwa singeweza kuzisongeza zaidi ya magoti! Jana nilijaribu tena.

Nilikuwa nataka sana kurejelea nguo za kawaida. Niliweka mafuta kwenye mkanda wa nguo. Mwishowe nikaweza kufunga kifungo.

“Njoo uone!” Nilimuita mume wangu. “Naweza kutoshea tena kwenye nguo zangu!”

Mshangao kwenye uso wake ulisema yote. Haikuwa sawa. “Zivalie ndani ya nyumba hadi utakavyoweza kuenda nazo mahali kwenye watu,” alipendekeza.

Nilizivua dakika 10 baadaye. Lakini kwa sababu tu zilikuwa za kubana sana kuketi kwazo. Sasa nina wasiwasi sana. Tumbo hili litawahi kupunguka?

Nilizungumza na marafiki kadhaa kuhusu jambo hili na mmoja akapendekeza nifunge kitambaa kilichokazwa kwenye tumbo langu mchana na usiku ili kulifanya liwe ndani wakati wote. Lakini hili halikuonekana zuri mno!

“Jipe muda,” marafiki wengine wananiambia. “Uzito wa mtoto utaisha kwa muda.”

“Kiasi gani cha muda?” Nauliza.

“Mwaka, wanaahidi.

Siwezi kuamini. Ujauzito wa majuma 40 na sasa hivi bado naonekana mwenye ujauzito!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Ni kawaida kwa mama mjamzito mwenye afya kuongeza kilo 10 – 14 / pauni 20 – 30 kufikia mwisho wa muda wako wa ujauzito. Uzani zaidi utakulinda kwa miezi ukinyonyesha mtoto wako. Unaweza kushughulikia kupoteza uzani huo kwa muda ili kurejelea umbo lako.**

pages.subtitle: My sister had fits
pages.description: You can avoid it with regular check-ups
pages.title: My sister had fits
pages.content:
The best way to avoid having fits in pregnancy is to check your blood pressure and urine regularly. You can get these tests from a health worker.

Having fits in pregnancy is usually because of pre-eclampsia. If your sister or mother had pre-eclampsia, your risk of getting it is high. You are also more likely to get pre-eclampsia if you had high blood pressure before pregnancy or if you have diabetes.

Experts think you get pre-eclampsia because your body cannot carry the baby any longer. If this happens, the baby will need to be born earlier than expected. A health facility is the best place to help you to have your baby safely.

Blood pressure checks and urine tests can identify problems early. So the best way to avoid fits is to see a health worker regularly for tests. Regular checks monitor your health and your body’s ability to carry your baby inside you.

Your health worker may suggest you start taking calcium tablets when you are about 4 months pregnant. Calcium tablets can help prevent problems in late pregnancy.

See a health worker, or go to the health facility immediately if:

- you have blurred vision

- you have a severe headache

- your face, hands and feet begin to swell suddenly

These signs may mean you have pre-eclampsia, and you may have fits if you do not get help quickly.

pages.subtitle: Are swollen feet normal?
pages.title: Are swollen feet normal?
pages.content:
Are your feet swelling? This is common, particularly in the last 3 months of pregnancy. Hot weather makes it worse.

In pregnancy, your body makes extra blood and can sometimes hold too much fluid. As your baby grows, some of your veins are squeezed. This results in blood being trapped in your legs. The pressure from the trapped blood forces fluid into the skin of your feet and ankles. This fluid would normally be absorbed by your body.

You will probably find that the swelling is worse as the day goes on. It will be better in the morning after you've been lying in bed. Try to rest with your feet up for some time during the day. Standing still for long periods can make the swelling worse, so try to sit down to do some jobs.

At the end of pregnancy, your hands might start to swell. Your rings may feel tight on your fingers. Wear them on a chain around your neck instead.

**Danger signs?** If you have sudden swelling or blurred vision, you need to see a health worker fast. This can be a sign of a serious condition that can lead to fits.

pages.subtitle: Breastfeeding - how to start?
pages.description: Get comfortable, find the best position
pages.title: Breastfeeding - how to start?
pages.content:
First, pour yourself a cup of clean, safe water, and put it where you can reach it. Breastfeeding can make you thirsty.

Then find a comfortable place to sit, where you can hold your baby in a position that will not make your arms and back ache. Make sure your back is supported and that you are not leaning backwards.

Have some pillows or blankets nearby to help you to support your baby. Try different positions. Many mothers find that cradling their baby across their chest, raised up on a cushion or pillow, works well. Or tuck your baby under your arm so his feet point backwards and his head is by your breast. Do what is most comfortable for you.

When you are both in a relaxed position, it is time to get your baby to take your breast into his mouth and start feeding. This is called latching on.

Your baby’s feed can take anything from 5 to 40 minutes. If you find noise distracting, find somewhere quiet. If you get bored, try feeding with the radio on or sit with a friend for company.

pages.subtitle: How do I know I am in labour?
pages.title: How do I know if I am in labour?
pages.content:
If this is your first baby, you may not be sure if you are in labour or not. If you have had a baby before, you will know, because you will remember how you felt last time.

You may get practice contractions. They come and go all the time you are pregnant. But if you are trying to decide if you are in labour and if now is the time to go to the health facility, answering these questions may help.

- Do you have pain in your lower back or low down in your tummy?

- Do you have cramp-like feelings, as if you are about to start your period?

- Is there a brown or blood-tinged jelly-like sticky fluid coming from your vagina?

- Are you having contractions that are getting longer and stronger? Contractions feel like period pains. They come and go at first. Go to the health facility when they are regular.

- Have your waters burst? Your baby has been floating inside a bag of fluid. If the bag breaks, with a trickle or a gush of fluid, you should go to the health facility. Your baby is on the way!

If you have some of these signs, it means that you are in early labour.

pages.subtitle: 2monthold Swa ke baby
pages.description: Mzungumzie mtoto wako ili kumsaidia kujifunza
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 2
pages.content:
Mtoto wako ana nguvu zaidi sasa. Anaweza kuinua kichwa chake juu kwa sekunde chache.

Sasa anaweza kuangalia vyema zaidi kwa macho yake na kuona kwake kunaendelea kuwa bora. Unaweza kumwona mtoto wako akiangalia mikono yake. Anaanza kuelewa kuwa ni mkono wake na anaweza kuutumia. Hivi karibuni ataanza kuelekeza mikono kushika vitu. Pia anasikiliza vizuri zaidi, na anaelewa wapi sauti zinapotoka. Unaweza kumwona akigeuza kichwa chake kuelekea upande wa sauti.

Kwa sasa, utagundua mtoto wako anakaa macho kwa muda mrefu wakati wa mchana, na ana nyakati maalumu anazotaka kucheza. Anaanza kutofautisha usiku na mchana.

Hivi karibuni, ataanza kunyoosha mikono na miguu yake. Mpe mtoto wako nafasi ya kutosha ya kujinyoosha. Tandika blanketi kwenye sakafu na umwache kujisongesha juu yake. Ikiwa amelala kifudifudi, anaweza kuanza kusukuma kwa miguu yake. Hii husaidia kuimarisha misuli yake inayokua.

Unaweza kufikiria mtoto wako ni mchanga sana kuimbiwa au kuzungumziwa, lakini ni vyema ukifanya hivyo. Kukusikia ukimwimbia au ukimzungumzia kutamsaidia kujifunza kusema.

Akitazama upande mwingine au akiacha kuwa makini unapomwimbia au kumzungumzia, jaribu kitu kingine au mpe muda apumzike.

pages.subtitle: Tutajikimu vipi na wawili?
pages.title: Mama ALIYECHOKA: Hakuna pesa
pages.content:
Miezi miwili iliyopita, niliacha kazi yangu ili kutafuta kazi ninayoweza kufanyia nyumbani. Nahitaji sana kufanya kazi ili niweze kupata pesa zaidi – lakini sasa nina ujauzito wa mtoto wa pili.

Hatukupangia kupata mtoto mwingine wakati huu. Hatuwezi hata kulipia utunzaji wa mtoto mmoja, na hivi karibuni tutakuwa na wawili. Mume wangu amekuwa akichukua zamu zaidi za kazi ili kusaidia. Ni vigumu kwa sababu wakati huu hapatikani nyumbani kwa urahisi na hatuonani sana. Nahisi vibaya kwa kumuongea mume wangu majukumu.

Kwa miezi miwili iliyopita nimekuwa nikiamka saa kumi na moja asubuhi ili kufanya kazi fulani za nyumba kabla mtoto wangu aamke na nimtayarishe kuenda shuleni. Baada ya kumpeleka shuleni, nitembee kwa majirani kutafuta kazi. Nauliza iwapo kuna kazi zozote za kusafisha ninazoweza kufanya. Mimi humchukua mtoto wangu saa nane mchana, na kisha napaswa kumtunza, kuanza kuandaa chajio na desturi ya kusafisha kuanza tena.

Kwa sababu ujauzito wangu umekua sana, mimi ni mzito na mchovu wakati wote. Nataka kukaa chini na kuweka miguu yangu juu, lakini hakuna muda wa kufanya hivyo. Napaswa kufanya kazi za muda na nijaribu kupata pesa ninazoweza. Sasa, nashangaa itakavyokuwa nitakapokuwa na wawili. Anayeanza kutembea na mchanga.

Sina muda wa mume wangu. Nina ujauzito na nimechoka. Kwa hivyo nitapataje muda wa mtoto wangu mchanga na mimi mwenyewe? Kwa vyovyote vile najua kuwa lazima nivumilie. Wanawake wengi wamefanya hili. Lakini wakati mwingine linaonekana lisilowezekana.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: je, unatarajia mtoto wako wa pili au wa tatu? Utahitaji usaidizi. Wasiliana na jamaa na marafiki wazee unaoamini walio na watoto. Iwpao umechoka na uko pekee yako, huende usiweze kuwashughulikia watoto wako vizuri. Omba usaidizi na ushirikiane na wengine katika kutekeleza majukumu yanayosumbua akili yanayohusu watoto.**

pages.subtitle: Make a plan for labour
pages.title: Month 7
pages.content:
Now your baby can open her eyes and turn her head towards light, even in the womb! She can hear now, and may kick and jump when she hears loud sounds, and settle down when you sing and talk to her.

Soon she will get into a head-down position inside you. Her head will be born first, so she turns upside down, ready for labour to begin.

As your bump gets bigger, it may be difficult to get comfortable and sleep well. Lie on your side and put a pillow between your legs so your bump is supported. You may start to feel some hip pain because the stretchy body tissue holding your hips to your pelvis may loosen. This is your body preparing for labour. Kneeling on your hands and knees may help.

You will need to make a plan for going to the midwife or doctor in labour. Plan how you will travel there, and perhaps ask a friend or relative if they will help. Talk to your family and make sure they know where you need to go.

Go to the health facility in late pregnancy so the nurse or health worker can check that you and the baby are well. They can tell you what you need for the birth and when to go to the clinic in labour.

pages.subtitle: Sing to your baby, he can hear you!
pages.description: Sing to your baby, he can hear you!
pages.title: Month 6
pages.content:
Inside your womb, your baby wakes and sleeps at regular intervals now. He can now open and close his eyes, and suck his finger or thumb! This helps develop his sucking muscles so that he is strong enough to feed as soon as he is born. His brain is growing and developing quickly now.

He can respond to sound now. At first, he will only hear sounds from your body, like your heartbeat. But slowly he will start to hear noises from outside your body. Sing to your baby so he can hear your voice.

It may feel like your womb is up near your ribcage, which will make you feel out of breath. Eating can be difficult because your stomach may be squeezed by your growing baby. Have small meals more often and snacks between meals.

As your baby grows so does your womb. The skin over your belly stretches and this can itch. You may notice red streaks on your tummy, hips, bottom and breasts. They are stretch marks and they will fade to faint marks after you give birth. You may have leg cramps or swollen veins.

Your breasts are fuller and heavier now. This is because they are getting ready to make milk for your baby.

pages.subtitle: Breastmilk combats HIV
pages.description: Breast is best if you are living with HIV
pages.title: Breastmilk combats HIV
pages.content:
If you are living with HIV, you may wonder if breastfeeding is a good thing.

Remember, you can significantly reduce the risk of passing on HIV to your baby by feeding him only breastmilk and his antiretroviral (ARV) medicine every day. Do not forget to take your baby to the health facility at 6 weeks so he can have a test for HIV.

Your baby will need lots of food to grow. The best food for him is your breastmilk. Your milk is full of goodness that is perfect for your baby. It has all he needs to grow big and strong. It can also help to protect him from some diseases.

If you feed him breastmilk and nothing else, not even water, for the first 6 months, you can help give him the best start in life. Even if you need to go back to work before this time, you can squeeze out your breastmilk and leave it for him. Your health worker can help you to learn how to do this.

Take advantage of your precious milk and let your baby have it as often as he wants. Let him feed until he has had enough. It will keep him healthy and happy.

Never mix breastfeeding with any other type of milk because this makes it more likely that your baby will get HIV.

pages.subtitle: 4monthold Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 4
pages.content:
Mtoto wako anabadilika haraka. Anaweza kutoa sauti za kawaida. Anaweza hata kusema kitu kinachosikika kama 'Ma-ma' mwezi huu! Usiwe na wasiwasi asipofanya hivyo. Watoto wote hukua kwa kasi tofauti.

Hadi sasa, amekuwa akihitaji uwepo wako muda wote. Sasa wakati mwingine anaweza kufurahia kujichekesha mwenyewe. Unaweza kumkuta akichezea mikono na miguu yake kwa furaha!

Katika umri huu, ni vyema kwa mtoto wako kuwa na wapendwa au marafiki wanaoaminika. Anavyokua, mtoto wako atahitaji kujifunza stadi za kijamii na jinsi ya kuhusiana na watu wengine. Familia yako itafurahia kumkumbatia! Unaweza kumkumbatia mara nyingi unaporudi.

Ingawa kulia ndiyo njia bora ya mtoto wako ya mawasiliano, anapata pia kuwa na hali ya ucheshi. Cheza naye mchezo wa kuficha uso. Angalia kama atacheka unapofichua uso wako kutoka chini ya blanketi.

Katika umri huu, ikiwa amelala kifudifudi, anaweza kuinua kichwa na mabega yake, akitumia mikono yake kujiinua. Mtoto wako anaweza hata kujibiringisha kutoka upande wa mbele na kulalia mgongo wake. Mtie moyo kwa kutingisha kitu cha kuchezea upande ambao huwa anajibiringishia. Piga makofi na utabasamu anapofanya hivyo!

pages.subtitle: Can I feed my sick baby?
pages.title: Can I feed my sick baby?
pages.content:
Food is what your baby needs to get her strength back.

All babies get sick sometimes. It is sad to see your baby sick, but you can help her to get well by giving her the right care and treatment, and by continuing to feed her well.

If your baby is less than 6 months old, your breastmilk will help her to get better. Your breastmilk is healthy for her. It will help your baby get stronger. If your baby has loose stools or diarrhoea, breastmilk is gentle for her stomach, and will give her all the goodness she is losing while she is sick.

If your baby is over 6 months old, continue to feed her mashed family foods. Add a little butter or oil to make it even better. Even if she is vomiting or has diarrhoea, she still needs to eat. Food will help her to recover.

If she refuses to eat, offer her small amounts of food, often, through the day. This will help her body to recover.

If your baby is still sick after a day, or her diarrhoea lasts longer than a day, take her to the health worker.

When your baby begins to feel better, offer her 2 extra meals a day for 2 weeks. This will help her get back to her usual health.

pages.subtitle: Worms: how do I protect her?
pages.description: Give her a clean play area
pages.title: Worms: how do I protect her?
pages.content:
You can catch worms from the ground and they can make your baby sick.

Clean the floor with soap and water before your baby lies, crawls or plays there. This will help to keep her safe. If you cannot clean the floor, put down a large, clean blanket or mat.

As she grows up, your baby may like to play outside but, in some areas, worms are a problem. Worms are picked up from the mud and soil, and can cause belly pain, coughing and fever.

Thick socks, slippers or shoes will help to protect your baby when she starts to walk outside. Wash her hands well with soap and clean, safe water. It is also important to clean her nails regularly. This will stop worm eggs from the ground from entering her body when she puts her hands in her mouth.

If your child has a worm infection, you may not even know it. Deworming medicine kills any worms your child may have caught. This is safe for your child to take even if she has not caught any worms. Ask your health worker if your baby should take deworming medicine.

pages.subtitle: My baby's first word!
pages.description: This happens when he is around 1 year old
pages.title: My baby’s first word!
pages.content:
From the moment your baby is born, he is learning how to speak.

His first form of talking to you is crying. He cries when he is hungry, uncomfortable or tired.

As he grows, your baby listens to you and the people around him and starts trying to copy you. He wants to talk to you!

Make eye contact and talk to your baby as much as you can. Point to people and things as you talk about them.

Between 3 and 4 months, he cries less and makes more sounds. He begins to recognise his name. Try calling his name from a short distance and see if he responds.

Between 5 and 6 months, your baby makes sounds to get your attention, and will babble to himself when he plays. He might say sounds like ‘ba’ or ‘ma’ over and over.

Between 7 months and 1 year, he tries new sounds and tries to copy what you are saying. He recognises the names of familiar objects, such as "cup".

From around 1 year, he may begin to use one or more words and know what they mean.

If you are worried that he is not saying any words by 15 months old, talk to a health worker.

pages.subtitle: I’m scared to let my baby go
pages.description: I’m scared to let my baby go
pages.title: TiredMom: Mother-in-law wants to help
pages.content:
By the time my baby boy was 3 weeks old, I was tired. I hadn’t slept a full night since the birth. I felt as if my baby only knew how to do three things: eat, sleep and cry!

My mother-in-law saw that I was tired and tried to help me. She said she would look after him while I lay down for some rest. I couldn’t refuse. But handing over my tiny newborn felt harder than hearing him cry!

I watched how she held him. I didn’t think that she was doing it quite right – it wasn’t the way I would do it. Even though I tried to take a nap, I could hear my baby crying in the next room. I just wanted to go and take him back!

I know mother-in-law was trying to help. And she did a good job raising her son because my husband is a wonderful man. But I was so protective. I just wanted to hold my boy and not let him go to anyone else.

I know no harm will come to him, so I am trying to relax when others want to hold him. But I still get a secret thrill when I see that his smile for me is the biggest!

**MAMA HELP: You’re a new mom – it’s perfectly normal to not want to let your baby out of your sight. It will get easier in time. When family members want to hold your baby, try to see it as a good thing. They are helpful and love him!**

pages.subtitle: When to have my next baby?
pages.title: When to have my next baby?
pages.content:
Your family may want you to have another baby. You could explain that your next baby will be healthier with a gap of at least 2 years.

If your mother had babies close together, she may not understand why you want to wait. Your partner may want another baby, too.

There are 3 reasons why it is better to wait.

- Being pregnant before your baby is 2 years old can put you at risk. Your body needs to recover from the first birth.

- Waiting 2 years keeps your next baby healthy, too. Getting pregnant too soon can mean that the next baby will be weak or early.

- Waiting gives you and your partner time to earn more money. You can use this money to save for the future. This will make it easier for you to pay for the things you need to keep you and your baby healthy.

A brother or sister for your baby might be just what your family wants. But waiting until your baby is at least 2 years old will give you a healthier and happier family. And give you time to enjoy this baby.

If you have not started using a contraceptive yet, now is the time. Talk to your health worker. They may be able to offer you free contraceptives.

pages.subtitle: When will he roll over?
pages.title: When will my baby roll over?
pages.content:
Rolling over means that your baby can flip from lying on his back to being on his belly, or from his belly to his back.

He will probably be able to roll over when he is about 6 or 7 months old, when his neck and arm muscles are strong enough.

If you put your baby on his belly at around 3 months, he may be able to lift his head and shoulders off the floor using his arms. This prepares him for rolling over.

You can encourage your baby by playing with him. Put him on his belly and wiggle a toy to one side of him. If he manages to roll towards the toy, smile and say "Well done!"

You never know when your baby will first roll over. To be safe, do not leave him alone anywhere he could fall off and hurt himself.

If your baby is not rolling over by 7 months old, you could talk to a health worker. Do not worry too much though: babies develop skills differently, and some more quickly than others.

pages.subtitle: When will my baby sit up?
pages.title: When will my baby sit up?
pages.content:
Your baby gets strong enough to sit between 4 and 7 months.

If you sit her on your lap or put her on the floor, she may be able to sit up for a moment without you holding her.

To help your baby to sit, move her legs so that they are spread out and balancing her weight. This reduces the risk of her falling over. Once she is in this position, put a favourite toy in front of her. Place pillows or blankets around her, so that she does not get hurt if she falls. Stay nearby to watch her.

You could also encourage your baby to play lying on her belly. Lifting her head and chest to see a toy will help her to strengthen her neck muscles and develop the head control she needs for sitting up. You can help her to strengthen her legs by standing her on your thighs and bouncing her up and down. This will probably make her giggle!

By the time she is 8 months old, she should be able to sit well without support.

pages.subtitle: Itawahi kupoa?
pages.title: Mama anayezaa mara ya kwanza: Miguu inayouma, iliyovimba
pages.content:
Nilidhani nitapata kichefuchefu cha asubuhi, hamu ya ajabu ya chakula na matiti yaliyovimba wakati wa ujauzito. Nilidhani nitahisi mwenye kupenda na kuwa na hisia. Au kuwa tofauti kwa njia nyingine. Lakini nahisi hali ya kawaida kabisa!

Kusema ukweli naelewa wale wasichana wanaosema hawakujua walikuwa wajawazito! Kama si kukosa hedhi na kuenda kliniki kwa uchunguzi singekuwa nimejua. Hakuna kichefuchefu cha mjamzito asubuhi. Hakuna hamu yoyote. Sihisi chochote. Maisha yangu yanaendelea kama kawaida.

Hata hivyo siwezi kustahimili kitunguu saumu...inabidi tuondoe kitunguu saumu nyumbani mwetu kwa sababu harufu ni kali sana kwangu. Nala zaidi. Mama yangu analalamika kwa sababu hajazoea hali yangu ya kula sana (lakini nafikiri analalamika ikiwa sikula vizuri!)

Huwa ananilalamikia na mimi hufurahia. Hata mimi huhisi vizuri zaidi kuliko hali ya kawaida!

Inaonekana aleji yangu imepotea – labda ni kwa sababu ya chakula kizuri ninachopata. Ningali na nguvu. Marafiki na familia yangu wanashangazwa kuwa ningali nafanya kazi hadi wa leo. Lakini maisha yanaendela au siyo? Sijaongeza uzani sana na nilianza kuonyesha mwishoni mwa mwezi wa tano.

Dalili yangu mbaya zaidi ni kuvimba kwa miguu! Mtoto anakalia sana upande wa kushoto kwa hivyo mguu wangu wa kushoto umevimba karibu mara mbili ya kiasi cha kawaida. Inashtua na kuonekana vibaya. Viatu vya kuingiza miguu si vizuri na nina aina moja ya ndara ninayoweza kuvaa. Au champali za nyumbani!

Nina wasiwasi miguu yangu itakua kabisa na nitapata aina gani ya viatu vikubwa vya wanawake? Mama yangu mdogo kutoka kijijini alisisitiza tushauriane na nabii, lakini daktari alinihakikishia kuwa ni kawaida.

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: miguu iliyovimba (edema) wakati wa ujauzito inaweza kuwa mbaya zaidi wakati unapokaribia kuzaa. Unaweza kukosa utulivu, lakini haitakudhuru na ni kawaida. Inapaswa kupoa usiku. Ikiwa haitapoa, au mikono au uso wako kuwa na uvimbeuvimbe, tembelea kliniki kwa uchunguzi.**

pages.subtitle: Is she constipated?
pages.description: Here is how to help her
pages.title: Is she constipated?
pages.content:
In your baby's first few weeks, it will take a little while for her bowels to settle into a routine. Her stools may be loose 1 day, and hard the next. Soon you will know what is normal.

While your baby is having only breastmilk, her stools will be soft and easy to pass. It is only when she begins to eat solid food that she may have constipation, when her stools are hard and difficult to pass, and do not pass as often as usual.

The signs of constipation are easy to spot.

- If your baby cries when she passes a stool, this may be a sign. You may also notice her stools are dry and hard. She may also pass fewer stools than normal, sometimes as few as 3 stools a week.

- Stools and wind that smell very bad are also signs. A hard, bloated belly is another.

What can you do? If you think that your baby is constipated, give her plenty of breastfeeds. Breastmilk is ideal. Do not give her water, or any other drink but breastmilk.

If your baby has started eating solids, give her lots of fruit and vegetables as well as breastmilk and clean, safe water. This will help to soften her stools.

Sometimes, very liquid stools are a sign of constipation. Liquid stools can move around hard stools that are blocking the digestive system. If you think this is happening to your baby, then see a health worker.

pages.subtitle: Is circumcision safe?
pages.description: Only for boys, if done in a hospital
pages.title: Is circumcision safe?
pages.content:
You may be worried about how safe it is to get your baby boy circumcised. Male circumcision can be unsafe if it is not done in a clean way. Take your baby to a medical health facility or a health worker for a safe, clean circumcision. It is never safe to circumcise a girl at any age.

A health facility has trained staff to do the procedure in a quick and easy way. So it is less likely to cause problems. If something does go wrong, staff know what to do.

Staff at the health facility also use clean tools. This will help to protect your baby boy from infections. Staff will also give him medicine to numb the pain. This will make him much more comfortable.

Friends and family may tell you to get a religious or traditional leader to do the circumcision. But a traditional leader may not have been trained and will not know how to keep germs away.

Tell your family and friends that getting your baby boy circumcised at a health facility is the safest way.

Remember: it is never safe to circumcise a girl at any age. Girls should not be circumcised at all.

pages.subtitle: What are practice contractions?
pages.description: Your body is getting ready for labour
pages.title: What are practice contractions?
pages.content:
Practice contractions are the body’s way of getting ready for labour.

Your womb has been practising gently since about 2 months into your pregnancy. The bigger your womb gets, the more you notice the tightening feelings when they happen. Each tightening usually lasts for about 30 seconds.

If you feel a tightening, place your hands on your bare bump. You can feel how hard your womb becomes. This is because it is a muscle, and when a muscle tenses it gets hard. It gets soft again when the practice contraction finishes.

In late pregnancy, practice contractions can feel quite strong. You may think you are in labour. So how can you tell?

**How long do they last?** Practice contractions usually only last for a short while. Then they stop completely. So wait for an hour or so and see if they go away. Practice contractions often stop if you get up and move around. So maybe do some housekeeping, or go for a walk and see if they stop.

**Are they getting stronger?** Real contractions get longer and stronger as they go on. If your contractions stay the same and do not get stronger, they are most likely to be practice contractions.

**Are they coming more frequently?** In labour, contractions gradually get closer together. So they may start every 20 minutes, then every 15, then every 10, then every 5 minutes. The gap between practice contractions usually stays the same.

pages.subtitle: Who shall I tell?
pages.title: Who shall I tell?
pages.content:
Some women want to keep their pregnancy a secret at first.

But telling your health worker does not mean you have to tell everyone else.

Talking about being pregnant with a health worker will be good for you and your baby. It will mean fewer problems if you get the right care early on.

You may be able to have tests to make sure that you and your baby are healthy. You can have blood and urine tests, and tests for HIV.

If you already know you are living with HIV, or test positive for HIV at any time while you are pregnant, when you give birth or afterwards, you may be able to have free medication to prevent your baby from becoming HIV+.

Even if you feel well, get regular check-ups so that you and your baby can stay healthy.

pages.subtitle: How much food to give my baby?
pages.title: How much food to give my baby?
pages.content:
Boys and girls need the same amount of food.

For the first 6 months of his life, all your baby needs is your breastmilk. After this, you can slowly increase the amount of food you give your baby. She still needs your breastmilk until she is 2 years old.

Here is how to slowly increase her food:

**6 months old:** Breastmilk is still your baby’s main food, but now she can start other foods. Feed your baby mashed family food twice a day. 2 spoonfuls is enough for each meal. You can feed your baby the same food that you and your family eat but make sure you mash the food well. Do not put salt in foods for your baby.

**8 months old:** Your baby will need 3 meals a day. Slowly increase the amount of food he eats at every meal, to about 3 spoonfuls.

**9 months old:** By now, one of her meals needs to increase to the size of half a bowl of food. For her other 2 meals, still feed about 3 spoonfuls of food. By now she will be able to pick up her food. So give her small pieces of food to pick up.

**10 months:** Feed your baby 2 half bowls of food a day. For his other remaining meal, she only needs a few spoonfuls.

**1 year:** She will need 3 or 4 half bowls of food a day, with snacks. Over the next year, slowly fill up the bowl.

pages.subtitle: Look out for signs of TB
pages.description: Being alert keeps you both safe
pages.title: Look out for signs of TB
pages.content:
If anyone in your family has tuberculosis (TB), everyone should get tested. Treatment will protect you and your baby.

Be alert to the signs of TB in your own body, and in those around you, TB is an illness which can be very dangerous. It spreads through the air by coughs and sneezes. It can stay in the air for a long time.

If you have a cough for more than 2 weeks or have lost weight unexpectedly, see a health worker. They will be able to check if you have TB, and they can give you the right medicines.

If you finish all the medicines, you can kill TB completely. Stopping taking them before you finish can make the TB come back.

You can catch TB more easily when you are pregnant. Try to take extra care by eating well and staying away from crowded areas and people who are coughing and sneezing.

If anyone in your family has TB, they will stop being infectious after taking medication for 2 weeks. Ask them to cover their mouth and nose while coughing or sneezing, and to wash their hands regularly.

pages.subtitle: 7monthold Swa Ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 7
pages.content:
Mtoto wako sasa ataanza kutaka kujilisha chakula. Labda atashika kijiko unachomlishia, au atachukua chakula kutoka kwenye sahani yako? Jaribu kuweka vipande vidogo cha chakula laini kwenye sahani yake. Atafurahia kukichukua na kukila! Kumbuka kwamba wasichana wanahitaji kiasi sawa cha chakula kama wavulana.

Mtoto wako anaweza kuwa na hamu kubwa ya chakula, lakini meno sio mengi. Anza na chakula anachoweza kutafuna kwa ufizi wake au anachoweza kutembeza kwa urahisi mdomoni mwake.

Katika umri huu watoto huwa wadadisi. Anaweza kurusha vitu vya kuchezea au kuvuta nywele ya dadake! Mtoto wako anajaribu vitu tu, si utundu. Hatakumbuka vitu kwa muda mrefu, kwa hivyo kumuadhibu hakutamaanisha chochote kwake kwa sasa. Lakini anaweza kukengeushwa kwa urahisi. Kwa hivyo mwonyeshe kitu cha kuchezea au mwimbie wimbo ili aache kufanya mambo ambayo hutaki afanye.

Usiwe na wasiwasi ikiwa ana mianya kati ya meno yake. Mianya hiyo kati ya meno ya mtoto wako huenda itafungika kufikia umri wa miaka mitatu, baada ya meno yake yote ya utotoni kuota.

Kwa sasa, mtoto wako anaweza kuwa na wasiwasi kuhusu wewe kuondoka. Amekuzoea sana kiasi kwamba kumwacha, hata kwa dakika moja, kunaweza kukamfanya alie. Hii ni kawaida, na kutengana naye kwa muda mfupi kutamsaidia mtoto wako kuzoeana na watu wengine. Muda si mrefu atatambua kwamba kila wakati huwa unamrudia.

Kwa sasa hisia za mtoto wako zinaanza kuwa wazi. Anaweza kuwapa busu akiwa mbali watu anaowajua. Anaanza pia kugundua hisia za watu wengine na kuziiga. Akimwona mtu akilia, anaweza pia kuanza kulia.

pages.subtitle: Month8 Swa ke pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 8
pages.content:
Mtoto wako anaweza kuwa anajitayarisha kuzaliwa. Watoto wengi hugeuza kichwa kielekee chini wakati kama huu. Unaweza kuhisi kuwa mtoto wako anateremka chini katika nyonga yako. Hii hurahisisha upumuaji, lakini pia humaanisha kwamba unahitaji kwenda haja ndogo mara kwa mara!

Unaweza kuwa na uvimbe upande wa chini katikati ya miguu yako pale unapoweza kuhisi kichwa cha mtoto wako. Pumzika ukiwa umelala, ukiweza, miguu yako iwe kwenye mto ili kupunguza uvimbe.

Viungo vyote vya ndani vya mtoto wako vimekua kikamilifu sasa. Ndani yako, anameza majimaji yaliyomo tumboni mwako na kisha kuyatoa. Mapafu yake yamekomaa kabisa na yatafanya kazi mara tu atakapopumua kwa mara ya kwanza.

Jaribu kupumzika kila siku na ufikirie kuhusu mtoto unayemkuza. Hivi karibuni utamwona. Mtoto wako anaweza kusikia sauti yako na atakutambua utakapomsalimia kwa mara ya kwanza!

Unaweza kuhisi kusogea kukubwa kumekuwa kuchache kwa sababu kuna nafasi ndogo tumboni mwako. Lakini bado utaendelea kusikia mtoto wako akipiga mateke mara kwa mara. Ikiwa huna uhakika, keti chini utulie baada ya mlo na usikilize mara ngapi anapiga mateke. Usipohesabu mateke kadhaa mwone mfanyi kazi wa kituo cha afya.

pages.subtitle: How to keep my baby warm?
pages.description: Dry him, hold him, cover him quickly
pages.title: How to keep my baby warm?
pages.content:
It is important to keep your baby warm as soon as he is born. Babies cannot adjust to the new, cooler, temperature outside the womb, and can lose heat very quickly.

When your baby is born, he will be wet, so make sure he is dried.

He does not need to be bathed for at least 6 hours. For the first 6 hours of your baby's life, clean only the cord. The rest of your baby does not need to be bathed. Bathing your baby too soon could make her sick and cold.

Ask your birth attendant to lay your baby on your bare chest. Your warmth will help prevent him from getting too cold. Hold him firmly so he does not slip and fall.

Lay a clean, warm blanket over both of you. This will keep the heat in. You can make a sling to keep him safe. Also put a small hat or a cloth wrapper over his head. Babies lose a lot of heat through their heads.

Keeping your baby warm through skin-to-skin contact will also give you and your baby time to get to know each other. You can see who has been kicking you all this time! Holding your baby this way will also mean that your baby can easily reach the breast and start feeding.

pages.subtitle: How your baby gets ready for birth
pages.description: How your baby gets ready for birth
pages.title: Month 8
pages.content:
Your baby may be getting ready to be born. Most babies turn head down about now. You may notice that your baby drops down into your pelvis. This makes it easier to breathe, but it also means that you need to urinate more often!

You may have swelling low down between your legs where you can feel your baby’s head. Rest lying down, with your feet on a pillow when you can, to reduce the swelling.

Your baby has developed all his internal organs fully now. Inside you, he is swallowing the fluid in your womb and then passing it out again. His lungs are fully grown and will work as soon he takes his first breath.

Try to rest each day and think about the baby you are growing. Soon you will see him. Your baby can hear your voice and will recognise you when you say hi to him for the first time!

You may feel fewer big movements because it is quite cramped inside your womb. But you should still feel your baby kick regularly. If you are not sure, sit quietly after a meal and notice how often he kicks. If you do not count several kicks see your health worker.

pages.subtitle: Hold your newborn close!
pages.description: Keep him warm against your skin
pages.title: Hold your newborn close!
pages.content:
Once your baby is born, your body delivers the afterbirth, called the placenta. You will feel contractions again, but weaker this time.

Hold your new baby next to your skin. He will look for your breast to suck. Offer your breast as soon as possible. Breastfeeding like this will increase your contractions to make the placenta come out more easily. Sit upright to help your body to push the placenta out.

The placenta, and the empty bag of waters, will drop to the bottom of your womb. They pass out through your vagina.

Hold your baby close to you. Holding him against your skin will help keep him warm, help him to breastfeed and help to reduce the amount you bleed.

Take time to rest after the birth and get to know your baby. You will need some pads or rags to soak up the bleeding. This will be heavy at first, like a very heavy period. It will settle down and become much lighter. Bleeding can continue for several weeks after your baby is born.

pages.subtitle: How do I make her stop?
pages.description: How do I make her stop?
pages.title: newDAD: Cry Baby Cry
pages.content:
Before my baby was born the one thing I knew for sure was that I made babies cry. How many times had an aunt or cousin put their baby into my arms and the baby had cried. It was as if it knew I was not meant to be a father!

Before mine came, I wondered: what if my baby does the same thing?

I decided I never wanted this to happen - so I made a point of finding out exactly why babies cry. I asked all my expert aunts! This is what they say: … there are four reasons for a crying baby: it’s hungry, it’s in pain, it’s got a wet nappy, or it’s tired.

But can’t babies also just cry because they are sad?

They can definitely be happy for no reason. The moment my daughter gave me a real smile for the first time she was around 6 weeks old. It was my best moment! It was as if she became a real human being. Babies smile at their mothers and fathers and other people they recognise. Then they grin and chuckle, gurgle and giggle.

Now I seem to spend a lot of time doing funny things just to make my girl laugh – I pull silly faces, make animal noises, jump around like a frog, pull her toes.

When she cries I do the 4-point check. I first make sure she’s well fed, has a dry nappy, had a good night’s sleep and doesn’t have a thorn down her pants.

When I’m sure she’s okay, then I work on cheering her up for real.... I know some great songs. I can dance for her. Read a story. Tickle her feet…

**MAMA HELP: A crying baby can cause a parent a lot of stress. First run through NewDAD’s 4-point checklist to make sure your baby’s comfortable. Once you’re sure she is, it may be time to bring out the singing and the dancing!**

pages.subtitle: Words about pregnancy and birth
pages.description: These may be new words to you
pages.title: Words about pregnancy and birth
pages.content:
**Antibodies:** these are proteins that are produced by the body’s immune system when it detects a harmful substance in your body, like bacteria or viruses. Each type of antibody is unique and defends the body against one specific type of harmful substance.

**Bladder:** the place where your urine collects.

**Blood pressure:** blood is pumped around your body by your heart. Measuring the speed of this can help health workers to know when you are sick.

**Carbohydrates:** these are starchy, filling foods that give you energy.

**Cervix:** the opening to your womb. Your cervix opens wide during labour to allow your baby to be born.

**Contractions:** these are the tightening and relaxing of the womb that happens in labour, sometimes called birth pains. They feel like strong period pains. Contractions gradually move your baby down through the birth canal, ready to be born.

**Dehydrated:** Your body needs water to stay healthy. If you are dehydrated, this means that your body does not have enough water.

**Folic acid:** this is a vitamin. You find it in food and tablets. It helps to protect your baby from developing faults in his spine, called spina bifida.

**Hormones:** these chemicals take messages around your body. They work slowly, over time, and affect many different processes in your body, like growth and development, your mood, sex, pregnancy and birth.

**Placenta:** or afterbirth, is the part of you which feeds your baby and keeps her alive in the womb and comes out after the baby is born.

**Pre-eclampsia:** this is a sudden rise in your blood pressure, which can happen in late pregnancy. It can be dangerous for you and your baby, and can mean that your baby needs to be born early.

**Protein:** proteins are body building foods.

**Vagina:** the passage leading from the cervix to the outside of your body. It is sometimes called your birth canal.

**Vitamins:** these are found in foods. Your body needs to have a variety of different vitamins to keep healthy.

pages.subtitle: Yournewbaby Swa ke baby
pages.description: Dunia mpya kabisa kwa mtoto wako
pages.title: Mtoto Wako Mchanga
pages.content:
Mtoto wako mchanga ni mgeni kwenye dunia hii kubwa, yenye kelele! Utamuona akishtukashtuka kadri anavyoendelea kuizoea. Hivi karibuni, kucheza kwake kutakuwa kwa ulaini zaidi.

Unaweza kuwa na wasiwasi kuwa mtoto wako hapati maziwa ya kutosha. Ikiwa mtoto wako ananyonya kila baada ya saa 2 hadi 3, au angalau mara 8 kwa siku, basi hiyo inatosha. Rangi ya kinyesi cha mtoto wako ni njia nzuri ya kukagua. Mwanzoni huwa cheusi na hubadilika kuwa manjano kufikia siku ya 4.

Mtoto wako anaweza kunyonya, kushika, kupepesa macho na kutafuta chuchu yako. Wakati mwingine ataangalia moja kwa moja machoni mwako. Ni vizuri wewe pia umwangalie machoni ukitabasamu na kupeleka kichwa juu na chini. Anajifunza haraka!

Baada ya kama wiki mbili mwangalie mtoto wako akijaribu kuinua kichwa chake wakati amelala kifudifudi. Anaweza pia kugeuza kichwa chake kutoka upande mmoja hadi mwingine. Hii husaidia kujenga nguvu za misuli ya shingo yake.

Anapokaribia umri wa mwezi 1, mtoto wako anaanza kuacha msisimko na utetemekaji wa uchanga. Anapata nguvu zaidi kila siku na kujifunza kuhusu dunia iliyomzunguka.

Badiliko moja la kusisimua ni kuwa anaanza kutoa kelele za mtoto. Hii ndio njia yake ya kuzungumza na wewe! Jaribu kujibu kwa kufanya kelele za mtoto pia. Endelea kumzungumzisha hata unapomweka chini na kuondoka.

pages.subtitle: Breastmilk is all she needs
pages.description: So feed only breastmilk for 6 months
pages.title: Breastmilk is all she needs
pages.content:
The reason you have breasts is so that you can feed your baby!

Your breastmilk is all that your baby needs to stay healthy for the first 6 months. She does not need solid food before 6 months. She does not need any other type of milk. She does not need water or other drinks.

Your breastmilk is special. It changes as your baby grows.

The first milk you make after the birth is creamy and high in vitamins and foods to help her fight infections. These help her to stay healthy.

Your milk then changes to become whiter and less thick. This satisfies her thirst, so she does not even need water if the weather is hot. Your milk changes to meet your baby's needs.

You make more milk the more your baby feeds. You can make the right amount of milk for your tiny newborn and for your baby when she is 6 months old.

Your breastmilk helps your baby to fight off germs in her belly, lungs, bladder, skin and ears. Babies who only have breastmilk in the first year do not get sick as much as babies who are fed other milks.

If you need to go back to work, you can squeeze out your breastmilk into a container so someone else can feed it to your bab. Teach your baby’s caregiver to feed your baby your squeezed out breastmilk using a cup. Clean the cup with boiling water.

After 6 months, your growing baby needs more than breastmilk. But your breastmilk is still vital while she learns to eat solid foods and until she is 2 years old.

pages.subtitle: Heavy bleeding?
pages.title: Heavy bleeding
pages.content:
If you are soaking more than 1 large pad or cloth an hour, go to the health worker or health facility now, straight away.

It is normal to bleed a little after birth because your body is clearing out the lining of your womb.

But if you suddenly start to lose fresh red blood, you need help. This blood loss may make you feel dizzy, sweaty or faint.

There are many reasons why you might be losing too much blood.

After birth, the womb usually shuts off the blood vessels that took blood through to the baby. If this does not happen, the blood vessels leak into the womb and cause heavy bleeding.

Sometimes the placenta does not come away cleanly, and this, too, can cause heavy bleeding.

A health worker can help to stop the flow of blood. You may be given an injection or tablets to take. You may also need extra fluid through a drip to replace what you have lost. Get help from a health worker as soon as you see heavy or bright red blood.

You will need lots of rest when you get home. Ask your family and friends for help.

If you have any medicines to take, finish them even if you feel better. This will help you to recover.

pages.subtitle: It’s painful to feed!
pages.title: MOMSlove: My breasts are sore and hard
pages.content:
When I started breastfeeding my newborn baby, nobody really told me what to do. I wanted to do everything as naturally as I could. After all, nursing dogs or horses don’t get taught how to feed their newborns, do they?

Well, I managed quite well for a few days. Then the nipple of my left breast got really sore. Soon after that I felt a hard lump in my breast. It was red and hot. My friend told me this was a blocked milk duct or mastitis. She said I had to be careful it didn’t turn into an infection!

How had this happened? My breasts had become very large and really full with milk. They had turned into tight soccer balls, with a tiny nipple sticking out. My baby tried to grab and suck on my nipple to get milk out. But I didn’t know that the breast actually has to go further into the baby’s mouth. My nipple had to be at the back of the mouth towards the throat and not at the front where the lips are. So my baby was not sucking properly.

But now my breast was hard and painful! I started massaging the hard spot while I was breastfeeding, trying to get all the milk out of the breast to take the swelling down.

Then friends told me about cabbage leaves! You put them into the fridge and wrap them cold around your breast. You keep them there for an hour or two. You can change them for fresh ones when they become warm and wilted.

So I tried it! And along with the massaging while feeding, I also put a warm cloth on to soften the lump. After 3 days, the lump was gone and my breast was soft again not hard and hot like before! Thank goodness!

**MAMA HELP: Mastitis will improve if you can keep the milk flowing through your breasts. Don't stop feeding, as this will make it worse. See that your baby gets a good mouthful of breast. Try different breastfeeding positions to help her latch on.**

pages.subtitle: Month9 Swa ke pregnancy
pages.title: Mwezi wa 9
pages.content:
Sasa mtoto wako anaweza kuzaliwa siku yoyote! Tumboni mwako nywele zake nyororo zilizokua kipindi cha katikati ya ujauzito zinaondoka. Pia anapoteza utando mng’avu uliokuwa kwenye ngozi yake uliokuwa unamlinda wakati akiwa anaelea kwenye majimaji tumboni mwako.

Mtoto wako anajenga tabaka za mafuta chini ya ngozi yake, yatakayomsaidia kuwa na joto atakapozaliwa. Watoto wachanga wanahitaji kupewa joto. Njia bora zaidi ya kufanya hivyo ni kumbeba mtoto karibu na kifua chako ndani ya nguo zako.

Unaweza kuwa unajiuliza jinsi utakavyojua uchungu wa kujifungua umeanza. Kuna njia tatu ambazo uchungu unaweza kuanza.

1. Unaweza kuona mvujo wenye damu kwenye chupi yako. Hii ni dalili kuwa uchungu unaweza kuanza siku moja au mbili zijazo.

2. Unaweza kupata mibano ya misuli ambayo ni kama maumivu ya hedhi. Inazidi kuwa mikali zaidi, ya mara kwa mara na inauma zaidi kadri uchungu unavyoendelea.

3. Unaweza kutokwa na maji kwa wingi au kwa kudondokadondoka. Hili likitokea lazima uende mara moja kwenye kituo cha afya.

Hakikisha unajua jinsi ya kufika kwenye kituo cha afya kabla ya uchungu kuanza. Unahitaji mkunga, muuguzi au daktari wa kukuhudumia unapokuwa katika uchungu wa kujifungua. Hakikisha kuwa una salio la kuongea kwenye simu yako na pesa kwa ajili ya nauli ya basi au teksi.

pages.subtitle: Why get him vaccinated?
pages.title: Why get him vaccinated?
pages.content:
Getting your baby vaccinated is one of the best things you can do as a mother.

Remember: you and your baby need to get vaccinated before you get sick. A vaccination cannot cure the disease once it has started.

If you and your baby are vaccinated, it means that you can fight serious illnesses if you come into contact with them. You cannot get vaccinated if you are already sick, so do it when you are both well.

Vaccination helps your baby to fight off some of the most dangerous illnesses. This will protect you both from suffering and distress. No mother likes seeing her baby sick.

Your baby needs to get vaccinated while he is well and it is important that you get it done at the right time.

Your baby will need more than 1 dose of some vaccinations. If you want to know what vaccinations your baby needs and when, talk to a health worker. They will tell you when to get your baby vaccinated.

pages.subtitle: Sikujua nilikuwa na ujauzito!
pages.title: Mama aliye na mshangao: Niko katika leba?
pages.content:
Hata sikujua kuwa nilikuwa na ujauzito hadi nilipoenda katika leba na nikajifungua mtoto wangu. Hili linaweza kusikika kama lisilo la kawaida. Lakini sikuongeza uzani wowote. Au, iwapo niliongeza, sikugundua kwa sababu hata hivyo mimi huwa na tumbo kubwa. Kisha siku moja kwa ghafla, niliamka nikihisi kizunguzungu sana. Nilienda katika kliniki ili nijue tu kilichojiri. Nilipowaambia wauguzi nilivyohisi, waliamua kufanya vipimo fulani.

Walirudi na kuniambia kuwa nilikuwa na ujauzito! Nilishtuka sana hadi nikashuka sakafuni.

Kisha wakaniambia kuwa shinikizo la damu yangu lilikuwa juu sana na mtoto pamoja na mimi tulikuwa hatarini. Waliniambia kuwa walihitaji kunipeleka hospitalini mara moja na wazalishe mtoto.

Waliwapigia wazazi wangu simu na kuwaeleza kila kitu. Wazazi wangu walishtuka sana, lakini pia walifurahi sana.

Nilipelekwa na gari la wagonjwa moja kwa moja na nikafanyiwa upasuaji wa kuzaa. Walinipa mtoto wangu mvulana. Saa chache kabla, sikuwa hata nimejua kuwa nilikuwa mjamzito na sasa nilikuwa na mtoto mvulana!

**USAIDIZI WA MAMA: Kukosa hedhi ndiyo ishara ya kwanza kuwa huenda una ujauzito. Kipimo kwenye kliniki kutahakikisha hili. Wahudumu kwenye kliniki hiyo watakuambia kuhusu safari za mara kwa mara za kliniki unazopaswa kutekeleza katika muda wa ujauzito ili kuhakikisha usalama wako na wa mtoto wako. Sikiza kwa makini watakayosema. Jaribu kufanya wanavyokuambia.**

pages.subtitle: Why wash my hands?
pages.description: Clean hands stop you getting sick
pages.title: Why wash my hands?
pages.content:
You do not want to get sick while you are pregnant.

Wash your hands regularly with soap. Encourage your family to do it as well. Keeping your hands clean helps to prevent illnesses like pneumonia and diarrhoea.

Wash your hands:

- when you come home

- after you go to the toilet

- after dealing with animals

- before cooking

- after handling raw eggs, meat or fish

- before you eat

Here is how to do it:

- You need clean water and soap

- Put a good amount of soap on to your palm

- Rub both hands together, palm to palm, to make a lather

- If you are using a bar of soap, turn it round in your hands until you work up a good lather

- Clean between your fingers

- Make sure you wash your wrists, hands and nails

- Continue rubbing your hands, on both sides, for at least 15 seconds

- Wash the soap off your hands with clean, safe water

- Dry your hands using a clean towel

You could set up a wash stand near your cooking area or near the toilet to make it easy.

Just by washing your hands, you can really reduce the risk of diseases like diarrhoea.

pages.subtitle: Why do I need calcium?
pages.title: Why do I need calcium?
pages.content:
You and your baby need plenty of calcium. Eat or drink foods containing calcium every day. They will help you to stay well and your baby to grow strong bones and teeth.

Calcium is a mineral that helps bones and teeth to grow. You need plenty of calcium, because your bones are still growing too. It may also help to reduce the risk of high blood pressure.

Calcium forms your baby's bones and teeth. It also helps to control the rhythm of his heart. If you are not getting enough calcium, your baby will not go without, but you will. That is because, where minerals are concerned, your body puts your baby first.

You can get calcium from:

- milk

- green leafy vegetables

- fish, especially oily fish like sardines

To help you to absorb calcium, you also need to make sure that you are getting enough vitamin D. Your body makes vitamin D from sunlight.

pages.subtitle: Stop smoking
pages.description: Smoking is bad for you and your baby
pages.title: Stop smoking
pages.content:
Try to stop smoking, it will make you and your baby more healthy, and it will save you money! You could save your money to help to pay for things that you and your baby might need.

Smoking when you are pregnant can make your baby weak and sickly. It is also bad for your baby when you are breastfeeding.

You could ask your family to help you to stop smoking. You might let them know that smoke in the house is also bad for the baby. Maybe you could ask them to stop with you. You should ask anyone who smokes in the house to smoke outside, now you are pregnant.

If you smoke, start cutting down or quit. It might be hard, but it is definitely worth it for your baby. Start by cutting down small amounts every day. If you are finding it really difficult to cut down, talk to your health worker.

pages.subtitle: Can I help my baby sleep?
pages.description: Yes, choose a routine that suits you
pages.title: Can I help my baby sleep?
pages.content:
You may carry your baby with you and let him sleep when he needs it. Or you may want to help him sleep in the evenings. It depends on the way you and your family live. Do whatever suits your lifestyle and routine.

If you want to settle your baby to sleep in the evenings, try these things:

- How you settle your baby to sleep is important. If you rock him to sleep every night for the first 8 weeks, he will expect the same later on. If you leave him alone to sleep, he will get used to that, too.

- So work out the best routine for you and your baby, and do that! Keep to the same pattern every night, so he gets used to it.

- When your baby is 6 to 8 weeks old, you could start helping him to learn how to fall asleep on his own. Put him down to sleep when he is sleepy, but still awake. Stay with him if you want.

- Stay quiet when you feed him at night. Keep the room dark, and do not talk to him much. Before long, he should begin to understand that night-time is for sleeping.

- Over the first few weeks, you may find that swaddling your baby helps him to sleep.

pages.subtitle: Where to have my baby?
pages.title: Where to have my baby?
pages.content:
As your baby’s arrival time gets closer, it is time to make plans.

A health facility is the safest place to have your baby. Work out how long it will take to get there. Talk with your family about transport and decide who you will have with you. Choose someone you trust.

If your baby comes too quickly or you cannot get to a health facility in time for the birth:

- It is vital to have a skilled attendant. Make sure your family knows how to contact the attendant. Your attendant may have a birth kit. It will contain a plastic sheet, gloves, clean string and tools for cutting your baby's cord.

- If you cannot get a birth kit, find a clean sheet to have your baby on and 2 cloths, one to dry your baby and one to wrap her in. Have a clean, sharp knife or a clean pair of scissors ready.

- Your attendant must wash her hands and you must wash between your legs. Get plenty of clean, safe, boiled water and soap ready.

pages.subtitle: 11month old Swa ke baby
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 11
pages.content:
Mtoto wako anaweza kusema maneno, au kutoa sauti zinazosikika kama maneno. Ubongo wake unakua, na pia uwezo wake wa kuongea. Msikilize kwa uangalifu na ujibu sauti anazotoa. Hii itamtia moyo.

Amekaribia umri wa mwaka mmoja sasa! Hata kama haelewi hasa kinachoendelea, katika umri huu, shangwe na sherehe pamoja na familia na marafiki zinampa hisia za usalama na ujamii. Atafurahia sherehe ndogondogo, karibu na nyumbani. Anaweza kuwa na furaha kupindukia ikiwa kuna watu wengi.

Unaweza kuona mtoto wako bado anachunguza vitu kwa kuviweka mdomoni mwake. Anaweza pia kupanda kwenye kiti ili afikie vitu vilivyo juu! Kuwa mwangalifu sasa, mtazame na uhakikishe hakuna vitu hatari karibu naye.

Mtoto wako anataka kukufurahisha, kwa hivyo sio mapema sana kumfundisha namna anavyoweza kusaidia. Fanya kazi za nyumbani ziwe za kufurahisha kwa kuzifanya kuwa michezo. Gawanya kazi ziwe kazi ndogo ndogo na ufanye naye.

Inawezekana mtoto wako anatembea tayari, au atapiga hatua zake za kwanza hivi karibuni.

Unaweza kufurahia kumfundisha mtoto wako kutembea. Simama au piga magoti mbele yake na unyoshee mikono yako. Jaribu kuishikilia mikono yake miwili na umtembeze akikuelekea. Huenda akapiga hatua zake za kwanza akiwa amenyoosha mikono yake kando na kuikunja kwenye viwiko. Anaweza pia kugeuza miguu yake nje na kuchomoza makalio yake ili apate urahisi wa kusimama.

pages.subtitle: Why am I breathless?
pages.title: Why am I breathless?
pages.content:
Even if you've never felt breathless before, like lots of women, you may sometimes feel breathless now. This is normal. Your body is adapting, and growing a baby!

You can help your breathing by keeping away from dirty air and smoky places.

Do you smoke? Stop, or cut down now. It is bad for health. Remember, you can save the money you spend on smoking to buy things you will need during pregnancy and for the baby.

Ask your family to smoke outside.

If your house is smoky, open doors and windows. You can reduce smoke when you cook:

- Use LPG, electricity, or a kerosene cooker if possible.

- Use a lid. The pot can conserve heat and you can reduce cooking time, and so breathe in less smoke.

- Soak food before cooking to reduce cooking time.

- When using charcoal, make sure that doors and windows are open.
