- If you can, put your stove at a higher level so you don’t have to bend over and breathe in smoke. Or cook outside so you don’t get smoke in the house at all.

- Mopping the floor can reduce the amount of dust you breathe in.

If you are breathless all the time, you may be anaemic. This means your body lacks iron. Taking iron tablets will help. You can also make sure you eat a variety of different foods like leafy vegetables, eggs, fruit, poultry and beans. They all help your body to get iron.

pages.subtitle: How will we cope with two?
pages.description: How will we cope with two?
pages.title: TIREDMama: Money is tight
pages.content:
Two months ago, I left my job to look for work that I can do from home. I do need to work to bring in extra money – but I’m pregnant with my second child.

We didn’t plan to have another baby right now. We cannot even pay for childcare for one child, and soon we will have two. My husband has been taking on extra shifts to help. It’s tough because now he is hardly ever at home and we don’t see much of each other. I feel bad for adding even more on to my husband’s plate.

For the past two months I’ve been waking up at 5am to do some housework before my little one wakes and I get her ready for school. After I have taken her to school, I walk around the neighbourhood looking for work. I ask if there are any cleaning jobs I could do. I pick my daughter from school at 2pm, and then I have to keep her entertained, start making supper and the cleaning routine starts again.

Because I am so far into my pregnancy, I am heavy and tired all the time. I want to sit down and put my feet up, but there is no time for that. I have to do odd jobs and try to make what money I can. Now, I am wondering what it's going to be like when I have two. A toddler and a newborn.

I have no time for my husband. I’m pregnant and exhausted. So how will I find time for my new baby or myself? Somehow I know that I must cope. Many women have done it before me. But sometimes it feels impossible.

**MAMA HELP: Are you expecting your 2nd or 3rd child? You will need help. Reach out to trusted older family members and friends who have children. If you are tired and alone, you may not be able to give your best to your children. Ask for help and share child-minding duties with others.**

pages.subtitle: 8monthold Swa ke baby
pages.description: Chunga! Mtoto wako anaweza kuwa popote
pages.title: Umri wa miezi 8
pages.content:
Kwa sasa, anaweza kuwa ameanza kutambaa, au kujiburuza kwa makalio yake. Mtoto wako anapoweza kujisogeza, ataanza kugonga vitu na kuanguka. Hii ni sehemu ya kukua. Furahia kumtazama akichunguza lakini hakikisha nyumba yako ni salama iwezekanavyo.

Mtoto wako anajifunza kuhusu vitu kwa kuvitikisa, kuvigonga, kuviangusha, na kuvirusha. Anajifunza kuhusu kile anachoweza kukifanyia kitu.

Mtoto wako ataanza kuonesha kuvutiwa na vitu unavyotumia. Polepole, ataanza kutumia vitu ipasavyo. Unaweza kumpata akijaribu kuchana nywele zake au kunywa kwa kutumia kikombe.

Mtoto wako anaweza kuona vyema zaidi sasa. Anakaribia kuona vizuri kama wewe. Sasa anaweza kuwatambua watu na vitu chumbani. Anaweza kuona kitu cha kuchezea upande mwingine wa chumba na atajaribu kutambaa kukielekea. Macho yake yamekaribia pia kupata rangi yake ya mwisho, ingawa unaweza kuona mabadiliko madogo baadaye.

Hivi karibuni, mtoto wako ataanza kusimama na kutembea chumbani akiwa amejishikilia kwenye ukuta na samani.

pages.subtitle: Can I use traditional remedies?
pages.title: Can I use traditional remedies?
pages.content:
Friends and family might offer remedies or tonics or suggest you go to a local healer. Maybe you used these in the past but now you are pregnant **you need to be very careful** about what you take.

When you are pregnant, and when you are breastfeeding, some remedies and tonics might harm your baby.

A good rule is to check with your doctor before taking any remedies or medicines. She will be able to tell you which are safe for you and your growing baby.

Another thing to remember is not to use pregnancy potions. They often contain alcohol, so are not good for you at all! They are bad for you and your baby.

pages.subtitle: Your baby can roll over!
pages.title: 5 months old
pages.content:
Your baby can't show her emotions in the same way as you, yet. But she will let you know when she is angry, bored or happy. She will show her love for you by raising her arms when she wants to be picked up. She may also cry when you leave the room.

About now, she is getting much stronger. Sit her on the floor and you may find she can sit up for a while on her own. Surround her with pillows and stay close in case she falls over.

She may surprise you by suddenly rolling over! Don’t leave her on a bed or raised surface in case she rolls off. You can change her nappy while she is lying on a clean cloth on the floor.

Your baby's sight is still developing. She can now see small objects and track moving things. Try hiding her favourite toy with just a corner of it showing. She will have fun finding it!

Your baby may now be able to copy you. Stick out your tongue, puff out your cheeks and see if she copies you.

Your baby now sees and hears the world almost as well as you do. Her communication skills are developing fast, too. Her sounds show her feelings. She may be happy, eager, or satisfied that she has solved a problem.

She may start to babble, repeating sounds such as "ba", "ma", "ga". This is all progress towards when she starts talking.

pages.subtitle: What helps in labour?
pages.title: What helps in labour?
pages.content:
When your labour starts, you may feel restless. Move around and keep busy while contractions are easy to cope with. Tidy up, pack your bag, get everything ready for when the baby comes. Go for a walk, eat a small meal, chat with a friend.

As your contractions get stronger, focus on them. Think about what is happening to your body and your baby. Relax and breathe deeply.

You may think you will be most comfortable lying on the bed. But keeping as upright as possible will help labour to progress.

You could try sitting on a chair with a cushion, or kneeling on a cushion and leaning forward on a chair or a bed for support.

You could kneel on all fours, or kneel on one leg with the other foot on the floor. This opens the pelvis (the big bones in your lower belly area) and makes more space for your baby.

Try rocking your hips backwards and forwards or in a circle. This helps your baby through your pelvis and is comforting. Just keep rocking, leaning forwards during contractions and straightening up in between.

Have short rests, sit or lie down. If your contractions start at night, try to stay in bed and relax for as long as possible.

You could also ask your birth attendant to massage your back with each contraction. This will help you to cope with the contractions as they get stronger and longer.

pages.subtitle: It hurts when I urinate
pages.title: It hurts when I urinate
pages.content:
Your baby is growing inside your body just above your bladder (where your urine collects before you pass it). The weight of the baby tends to squash the bladder, which makes you need to pass urine more often. This is common in pregnancy. Do not cut down the amount of clean, safe water you drink. You need it to stay healthy.

If you find that it is painful when you pass urine, you might have an infection. This can give you a high temperature, or make you suddenly feel hot and cold. Other signs of infection are blood in your urine, feeling sick, and shaking. Sex might be painful, too.

Getting treated is very important, so see a health worker. The germs in your urine can give you a kidney infection, which can be serious for your and your baby’s health.

You can also help to prevent urine infections.

- After going to the toilet, always wipe from 'front' to 'back', or pour water from front to back, or wash with soap.

- Drink lots of clean, safe water. This will help to wash out infections.

- If you need to urinate, go! Do not hold it in.

- Always urinate after sex, if you can, to get rid of any germs.

pages.subtitle: Your body after pregnancy loss
pages.title: Your body after pregnancy loss
pages.content:
It is important to rest after pregnancy loss. Try not to do any hard work until the bleeding stops.

Your body needs time to heal. You will bleed for a while. You may also have something that feels like period pain. Do not have sex until the bleeding has stopped, to protect your womb from germs.

Perhaps ask your family for help. They could help you with household tasks or care for your other children, if you have them.

Your breasts may leak and they could swell. This can be upsetting. You could wear a supportive cloth or bra. Put clean pieces of cloth in it to soak up leaks. Do not squeeze out the milk. It will go away slowly by itself over a few weeks.

Right now, your body needs rest and care. Try to eat well, with lots of fruit, vegetables, eggs, soy beans, fish or meat. If you take iron and folic acid tablets, carry on. They will help too.

For now, use a contraceptive. By waiting until your body has recovered before you try for another baby, you will be giving yourself the best chance for a healthy pregnancy in the future.

**Warning signs after pregnancy loss**

If the pain gets worse or you soak a pad in an hour, see a health worker immediately.

Also see a health worker if you have:

- Sticky, smelly fluid coming from your vagina

- A fever

- Faintness

- A pain in your shoulders

- Painful, red areas on your breasts

- Bleeding that will not stop.
